PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: COUNCIL OF THE AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL STUDIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young)-by leave - agreed to:

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies Act 1964, this House appoint Mr Gayler and Mr Miles to be members of the Council of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies and to continue as members until the dissolution of the Thirty-fifth Parliament.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (GENERAL REVENUE) AMENDMENT BILL 1987[COGNATE BILL:STATES (WORKS AND HOUSING) ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: — Before the debate is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill 1987 and the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill 1987.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill seeks to amend the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Act 1985 to give effect to decisions taken at the 25 May 1987 Loan Council meeting. Those decisions included: first, the allocation of $176m in interest free capital grants to the States as part of the 1987-88 State governments' Loan Council program; secondly, an agreement by the Loan Council that the States and the Northern Territory could use all of the balance of the Loan Council program for housing if they so desired-this year that will be around $386m; and thirdly, the prepayment of half the capital grant, that is, $88m in the first half of 1988-89 pending passage of similar legislation next year.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation comes before the House at a time when there are more people than ever on public housing waiting lists, when rents have skyrocketed, and when there are tens of thousands of people seeking to buy houses who are both unable to afford them and unlikely to be able to afford them under the current policies. For that reason I foreshadow that, in relation to the second Bill, I will move this amendment:

That all words after `that' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: whilst not opposing the provisions of the Bill, the House condemns the Government for the delay in the reinstitution of negative gearing and for the pursuit of economic policies which have:
(a) forced a record number of over 161,000 Australians on to public housing lists,
(b) resulted in a long period of record high interest rates, and
(c) resulted last year in the lowest number of housing starts for the last 20 years excepting the drought year of 1982-83.

The economic policies of this Government over the last four years have had a devastating impact on the housing aspirations of young Australians. No other industry in Australia is more reliant on stable and consistent government economic policy making than is the housing industry. Instead of the stability, consistency and predictability required for sustainable growth, we have had instability, inconsistency and lack of certainty in policy making.

Under the Hawke Government the housing industry has suffered firstly from rapidly expansionary economic policies and then, secondly, that was reversed and we had more contractionary Budgets. Along with this we have had Government-inspired record high interest rates and on again off again tax policies such as negative gearing. This economic instability together with conflicting tax policies has resulted in the housing industry being subjected to four years of exaggerated booms and busts, reflecting the stop-start policies of this Government.

Treasurer Keating's first four big spending Budgets accumulated $23 billion in deficits, with borrowings to match. The Commonwealth's interest bill on government debt for this financial year will be almost $8,000m-more than the Government spends on defence and education and about six times the amount that it will spend on housing this year. This massive program of debt, borrowing and interest repayment has put upward pressure on interest rates, and it is these record high interest rates which have put the purchase of a private home beyond the reach of tens of thousands of Australian families.

Home builders and home buyers are extremely sensitive to changes in interest rates, and this Government has presided over the highest interest rates in our nation's history. It is no wonder that the housing industry has experienced such a decline under the Hawke Labor Government. Recent studies on home loan affordability by the Real Estate Institute of Australia indicate that mortgage repayments are taking more and more of the average income earner's wage. Home owners, on average, are paying up to 17 per cent more of their income on mortgage repayments than they did a decade ago. That is still the case even though recent marginal falls in interest rates have been of some slight-and only slight-assistance. Regrettably, the future is not bright, with little prospect for sustained reduction in interest rates under this Government's current policies, and in fact the latest news suggests that increases in interest rates are in the offing. In Sydney, home owners are paying 45 per cent of average earnings on an average home loan. Ten years ago they were paying 28 per cent. All of our major population centres are showing an increase in the proportion of income going on mortgage repayments. In Melbourne the increase is 14 per cent; in Brisbane, 9 per cent; in Canberra, 10 per cent; in Perth, 3 per cent; and in Adelaide, 15 per cent.

In addition to the increase in interest rates and the decline in home loan affordability, under this big spending Government taxes have risen to record levels. Research by the Legislative Research Service of the Parliamentary Library indicates that for a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children who is on average weekly earnings, the proportion of earnings paid in income tax today is treble that paid in 1961-62. This increase in taxation means that families have less disposable income to spend on items such as housing. No wonder housing starts have declined to record lows with this double squeeze being applied to families: less money to spend because of higher taxes, and housing repayments more unaffordable because of record high interest rates.

The year 1986-87 was one of the worst years on record for housing starts. In a year in which the former Department of Housing and Construction's Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry said there was a need for 147,000 new houses, there were in fact only 117,000 starts-a shortfall of 30,000 new homes. Whilst some recovery is expected this year from last year's record low number of starts, the unmet demand for new houses, that is, the gap between the number of new houses needed and the number of new houses actually built, continues to increase. This year the Indicative Planning Council estimates that there will be a demand for between 160,000 and 170,000 new houses, but that there will be only 128,000 new housing starts. The gap of 30,000 of last year has now gone up to between 32,000 and 42,000.

Instead of new houses being built to meet the demand, the cost of borrowing has been so high that families cannot afford to buy. The high cost of finance has kept buyers out of the market, depressing demand and serving to keep increases in home prices constrained. In fact in the last 12 months in Canberra and Adelaide there was actually a fall in the median house price. When there was an easing in interest rates the rush of buyers, especially in Sydney, forced up prices, in many instances leaving the young home buyers no better off. As interest rates eased marginally, more and more home buyers started to enter the market in such numbers that this Government's generated pent up demand resulted in house prices skyrocketing.

Not content with pricing many families out of the home market, government policy in the rental accommodation market has compounded its effect in the open housing market. Two years ago, the Treasurer, against the advice of the Opposition, the housing industry and many economic and financial commentators, disallowed negative gearing for investment in rental accommodation. This Federal Government action was further exacerbated by State governments, such as the New South Wales Government, which introduced new tenant laws which scared even more investors out of the market. For two years we have watched the rental accommodation market dry up as a result of Commonwealth and State Government action. Rents have risen, availability of affordable accommodation has declined and more Australian families have been forced to become clients of the Government and seek government assistance through public housing or rental assistance programs.

Public housing waiting lists have soared. The States have been unable to keep pace with the demand for public housing. By the end of June this year a record 161,857 applicants were on the waiting list for public rental accommodation, an increase of 20,000 since the elimination of negative gearing, and the numbers continue to grow.

In his typically stop-start fashion the Treasurer has finally restored negative gearing, but after what damage? What he has done is to give the green light to the real estate investors at the same time as first home buyers were starting to re-enter the market following the slight decline in interest rates. The result, of course, has been a surge in the price of private housing. The Treasurer has engineered a situation creating an intolerable level of demand which, in Sydney in particular, is seeing a sudden increase in housing prices. The Commonwealth Government and the New South Wales Government have generated a short term overheated market which has led to gazumping and all the other side effects of yet another round of this boom and bust policy.

Earlier this month the Treasurer, in a knee jerk reaction to spiralling housing costs in Sydney, tried to shift the blame to overseas purchasers. He tried to place a ban on foreign investment in Australia's established urban housing stock. Apparently it took Hong Kong investors a whole four hours to find enough holes in the proposal to drive the latest Mercedes through. Apart from being cosmetic and ineffective, the Treasurer's announcement was years late. If he really wanted to do anything he should have moved a couple of years ago when there was some Japanese buying, but there was not a New South Wales election around the corner then so he did nothing.

Last week in London, after four years of erratic and inconsistent economic policy-making, this same Treasurer had the gall to blame volatility in world trade and foreign exchange markets on the slow pace of economic policy adjustment by the United States, Japan and West Germany. The blame for the chaotic state of the housing market does not lie overseas. It is the Hawke-Keating Government's irresponsible economic policy which has resulted in the abysmal housing situation today. The Government, through its inept economic policies of big Budget deficits, massive borrowing, high inflation, record interest rates and record taxation, has created a crisis in housing in Australia.

In the housing area we do not need the diversion of a wealth inquiry. The disastrous Hawke-Keating record is clear: a record number of 161,857 applicants waiting for public housing; a record number of more than 64,000 applicants waiting for home purchase assistance under State schemes; a cut of $468m to public housing funding in this, the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless. In addition, 1986-87 was the year in which we saw record high interest rates. Also 1986-87 gave us one of the lowest number of housing starts on record, with the number of starts falling 30,000 below predicted demand. In 1987-88 housing starts are expected to fall by up to 42,000 houses short of demand. Home owners are paying up to 17 per cent more of their income on mortgage repayments than they were a decade ago. What a disastrous record!

Some might say, `Ah! But the Government has seen the light. It has seen the error of its ways and after three years of extravagant over-spending it is starting to rein it in. It has listened to what the Opposition has been saying and it has reintroduced negative gearing. Surely the worst must be over'. Regrettably that is not the case. For example, Government policy has resulted in the buildup of tens of thousands of Australian home buyers wanting to buy a house as soon as the interest rates come down sufficiently to enable them to afford a house. Hence, recently when they did come down a fraction there was a stampede. This stampede of young home seekers was joined by the real estate investors who were again offered negative gearing. The combination of this demand, especially in Sydney, has meant that house prices have sky-rocketed-again sidelining many first home buyers.

In addition, in order to cut its previous extravagant expenditure, the Government has looked around for scapegoats and chosen public housing. At a time of unprecedentedly long queues of families seeking housing, the Government has cut $468m from its public housing program. Last year the effect of the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill was to provide the States with $585m in Loan Council programs funds for public housing and capital grants of $476m.

The Bill we are considering today provides for $386m in Loan Council programs funds for public housing and $207m in capital grants. These figures represent a decrease of almost $468m in Commonwealth funds available to the States for housing and capital programs. At a time when, instead of fostering private housing activity, its irresponsible and irrational economic policies have put more on public housing queues than ever, the Government has decided to cut funds for various housing programs with the result that the assistance going to those in need of housing will be drastically cut.

What are the Government's estimates of the impact of its action on the hundreds of thousands of Australians currently waiting for housing assistance? At last year's level of funding, the States were able to accommodate 48,000 applicants for public rental accommodation. Does the new level of funding mean that in the coming year only 27,000 will be able to be accommodated? If it does, it means that the public housing queues will blow out to a staggering 190,000. That is not 190,000 individuals; it is 190,000 applicants, with their spouses and children. Honourable members will recall that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in one of his expansive election moods earlier this year, promised the nation that no child would live in poverty by the year 1990. Yet the public housing waiting lists of this country continue to be a scandal and the Bill before us will aggravate the situation.

What will this $468m cut in Commonwealth funding mean to the numbers on the waiting lists of the States' various home purchase assistance programs? This year started with 64,000 people waiting for home purchase assistance. Will we end the year with 80,000 families waiting for home purchase assistance? The New South Wales Government, acting in concert with the Commonwealth, has increased the interest rate on their State-subsidised home mortgages by as much as 6 or 7 per cent. These are low income earners who had joined the program because of the low interest mortgages offered by the State. This increase in interest rates, together with new repayment schedules, means that many low income home buyers under the New South Wales Government's supposedly affordable home loans scheme will, in effect, just be paying rent with no chance of ever owning their own homes. For example, one home buyer under this scheme today owes more than $44,000 on a $46,000 loan. As a result of the changes, by the year 2000 he will owe $8,000 more on his home loan than he does today.

The Labor Government's record, both in relation to its housing policy and its general economic policy, has undermined the housing industry, has undermined the confidence of home buyers, has put housing beyond the reach of tens of thousands of Australians, has put more people on public housing queues than ever before, and in concert with Labor States such as New South Wales, has forced up the cost of housing for those most in need. Having caused this awful mess, the Government has now decided to cut $468m from public housing and capital funding to the States, further aggravating an already intolerable position. The housing problem is of the Government's own making. It is causing despair to those families seeking housing. Until the Government gets its economic policies right, the calamitous housing situation will continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a litany of part truth, half-truths and the wolf's cry from the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). Last night the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), speaking on these Bills, the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill and the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill, called for an increase in road funding. The honourable member for Barker now calls for an increase in State grants. We heard the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) last night calling for an increase in Commonwealth expenditure. They seem to ignore the headlines in today's newspapers, which tell us `One Billion Dollars Wiped from Share Values Around the World' and `United States Economy in Tatters'. These gentlemen criticise the Government for restraint. They criticise the Government for recognising the very tenuous position of Australia in the world economy today. They ignore the reality. They ignore their stated position on expenditure during the last election. They stand condemned from their own mouths.

SPEECH.PARA: What, in the last election, did they offer the Australian public? What did they suggest they would do should they be elected? They were going to slash taxes. They were going to increase consumer spending and suck in further imports as a direct result of their shallow call for decreased taxes. But that was not the only thing they were going to do. They were going to slash 16 per cent from Commonwealth programs-a minor cut, just 16 per cent across the board.

Professor Porter of Monash University was going to go further. He wanted cuts of over 20 per cent to Commonwealth expenditure. Among the Opposition's right wing allies is Mr McLachlan of the National Farmers Federation. He was going to cut $11 billion in one quick, massive cut: $240m from defence; $1,000m from education; $150m from school funding; $5,800m from health; $500m from family allowances; $500m from unemployment benefits; $100m from discount benefits; $125m from supporting parents and $140m from pensions. But Mr McLachlan wanted more. From the Australian Broadcasting Corporation-Special Broadcasting Service he was going to slash $577m; from employment schemes, job training, $530m; and from culture, $80m and recreation, $46m. But from the States what was he intending to do? He wanted to slash a mere $1,006m, from local government a mere $47m, and from roads, $128m.

We did not see members of the National Party of Australia wandering around the countryside telling their local councils that they, with their friends, the National Farmers Federation, wanted to cut $128m from local government. Nor did we hear the National Farmers Federation or its spokesmen, National Party members in this House, tell the local councils in their electorates that they were supporting cuts to road funding. But we hear them bleat like little lambs in this House, as we heard them last night, that they oppose any restrained or proper cuts that this Government puts into effect. And the Liberal Party of Australia in the last election did not detail what the effect of its cuts would be on the Australian community. It took the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-I refer to the Australian Financial Review of 29 June 1987-to detail the effect of those massive cuts in expenditure. According to the Treasurer, the cuts would mean an increase in nursing home charges of $46 a week; a $173m cut to home and community care; cuts in pharmaceutical benefits would mean an increase of $1 for each prescription to pensioners; school class sizes would need to increase to cut $275m from education; 60,000 tertiary places would be abolished; education allowances would be cut; and there would be a cut of $112m in public housing assistance. I did not hear the honourable member for Barker speak about that, but as usual the Liberal Party members and their colleagues in the National Party will stand in this House day after day criticising the Government. Their own program, which they have not yet resiled from, is never mentioned by them.

It is interesting when one looks at the world today and particularly at the market in the United States of America to realise that the supply side economics they still espouse was adopted by President Reagan. But the massive cuts to the American taxpayer that Reagan put into effect some four years ago have achieved precisely nothing. The theory of supply side economists that if taxation is cut massively there will be an automatic increase in production, a surge in the internal markets of production, has not eventuated in America. Instead, the United States has become the biggest international debtor in the world, with the largest current account deficit in its history and the largest internal deficit in its history, teetering on the brink, and partly responsible for the many problems facing world financial markets today.

Opposition spokesmen since the election have had a chance to explain what they meant in the campaign. They have had a chance on every one of the Bills we have debated so far to explain to the Australian people where they stand and to detail how they would make their economic changes. The speech of the honourable member for Barker was 20 minutes of criticism. As shadow spokesman, he did not make one positive contribution or offer one suggestion as to what the Opposition would do if it were in government and had the carriage and responsibility in the dreadfully difficult economic times in which we live. Last night the shadow Treasurer, speaking on these Bills, spent 20 minutes criticising the Government, criticising the level of debt, and criticising the macromanagement. But not once in that speech did he have the courage, indeed the fortitude, even to suggest an alternative program. What would the Opposition do? He did not answer. He did not make a suggestion. It is a sort of mindless approach, the coward's approach, that the Opposition continually runs in this House, for it has no capacity to make reasonable alternative suggestions. Indeed, it has no capacity to debate the Government on economic management. The Opposition can only criticise.

We will hear other speakers today who will just criticise. They will pick and pick and pick. They will point to everything that the Government, they say, is doing wrong in economic management. But anyone who listens to the daily carping of Opposition members never hears from them a solution that they would run with. We only know that they would cut expenditure massively. Or do we know that? Within a week of the shadow Treasurer being appointed-was he elected or was he forced?-he was reported in the Australian Financial Review as suggesting, as though not game enough to say what he really thought, that maybe the supply side economic theory espoused by his Leader was not quite the way to go. But since that one, almost brave, statement, he has been very quiet on alternative economic management policies.

Where does the National Party of Australia stand? My friend the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) is sitting right behind me. Does the National Party support the National Farmers Federation proposals to slash expenditure on rural councils, on road funding and on social service programs which affect the aged in country towns? It has never said it does not, and in fact by implication it supports the supply side economic approach of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). Not one Opposition spokesman will say, `That is nonsense'. I challenge the next Opposition speaker to detail, for once-if, indeed, he has a view on it-where he stands on such nonsense.

If we are to spend the next three years in government, it is no use there continually being a lack of rational debate on economic management. Why should the Government come into this place every day and listen to the criticism and negativism of the Opposition when it is not prepared to put its proposals forward? Do honourable members remember the Opposition's tax policy? For two years we attempted to glean from the Opposition what its tax policy would be. Remember its Leader standing up on his little soap-box saying, `We will tell you when we are ready. When we are ready, we will tell the Australian people what our tax policy is going to be'. It took an election before we finally made any sense out of the Opposition-and then we found that the Opposition's policy was one unmitigated disaster economically.

We tried to debate the Opposition's health policy. We asked where it stood on Medicare. We could not have a debate on that. Year after year during the last Government we asked where its policy on Medicare was.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was our policy on the Australia Card?

—I am happy that the honourable gentleman interjected. The Opposition's policy on the Australia Card is like its policy on all tax cheats and welfare frauds. It supports anyone who rips off the system. But it will not have a decent debate on macroeconomic management. It will support the tax cheats and the tax frauds, and it will look after its mates who rip off the system. It will support its big National Party friends. We know who they are in Queensland. A few inquiries are going on up there now. We know where the National Party's friends are. The inquiry that Mr Fitzgerald is chairing is telling us exactly who the National Party's friends are. We would also like to see an inquiry into the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation. We would like to know the truth about where the money that goes into that fund comes from and where it goes to. We would like to know what favourites get paid out of what funds. While on this matter, we would also like to know the facts about planning. We would like to know how the Minister, Mr Hinze, has doubled his family fortune by his planning proposals. That was the honourable gentleman's approach.

SPEECH.PARA: When we want to talk seriously about macro-economic management and about really serious policy matters in this House, the best we can get from the honourable gentleman is, `What about the Australia Card?'. That is the concept of serious debate coming from members of the Opposition. They have a long way to go before they can better this Government, or even humble backbenchers like me, in discussing any of these serious matters. But it was not a bad attempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a drink of water.

—It is not Queensland water, so I can drink it. In conclusion, I just want to say that there are no external economic forces at work which threaten the very fabric of this nation. They are not to be joked about or to be sneezed at. Since first being elected, this Government has taken some very serious decisions to change the fabric of the Australian economy. They have not been easy decisions. Indeed, they have caused a diminution in the living standards of all Australians. No one on this side of the House runs away from that fact. In fact we are proud of what we did because we knew, and we know now, that the economic forces at work in the world threaten this country. If we needed proof of that, the last two days have put it right on the front page.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet the Opposition opposes even a Bill of this nature, which reduces responsibly the ability of State governments to enter into consumer spending arrangements, which is designed to reduce the demand of the Government on the available capital of this country and to enable an increase in the export potential of secondary industry in this country. Members of the Opposition still oppose such a simple economic proposal. They will never say that they would have cut more themselves. But they would have cut without reason. They would have cut without a policy framework to counter where their proposals would cause the most damage. They would have cut simply to gain the vote from the Australian public.

This is a shallow Opposition. Its spokesmen reveal their lack of concern. Its spokesmen reveal their lack of ability to debate the serious issues in this country. I suggest that its spokesman today gave the same speech as he gave in the last Parliament, without one word changed-and this on a morning when billions of dollars have been cut from the value of trading in shares throughout the world. He has not changed his view even on such a day. He still opposes responsible economic management. For that this shallow Opposition stands condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the contribution of the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) but I remind him that the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill and the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill are part and parcel of the legislative program for the Parliament on a yearly basis and that there was no reason for him to castigate the Opposition as much as he did. I want to pass the initial remark that one realises that these Bills are essential for the functioning of the government process. But there does appear to be some conflict of interest insofar as the Commonwealth Government has reserved for itself the right to be the big spender but is requiring the States to take up the slack and put up with the pitfalls when there is a cost cutting mechanism in place.

SPEECH.PARA: I will comment briefly on the situation from an Australia-wide basis. I note that the honourable member for McEwen used some of his time to comment on the Queensland situation so, as a Queenslander and being a quick learner, I will take the cue from him and comment on the situation as it particularly affects Queensland. The States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill seeks to fix the actual dollar amount of financial assistance grants and identified health grants and to limit the contribution to State higher education superannuation schemes, thereby, I submit, operating on an emerging cost basis. This is probably fair. I understand from the contribution by the honourable member for McEwen that Australia is in a fairly difficult climate at present, and that, of course, the Commonwealth cannot be expected to be the only one bearing the burden. There needs to be a fair distribution of the tax revenue between the States and the Commonwealth.

The States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill, on a superficial examination, given those parameters, would appear to be particularly generous, but when one looks at it, it is not. It seeks to bestow upon the States capital grants that are free of interest or conditions attaching to the manner in which they are applied by the States. This grant is then coupled with an additional grant allocated for the purpose of public housing. This, of course, is designed to be an incentive for the States, thereby encouraging them to increase their own housing expenditures. It is expected that the effects of the grants will be to relieve the States of debt charges, specifically those encompassing interest payments and sinking fund contributions.

In reality these Bills represent the Government's decision to renege on its past promise to assist States by way of subventions to their bud-gets in financing their recurrent outlays. This promise was made by the then Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford), when he introduced the 1985 version of these Bills in Parliament on 11 September 1985. On that day the Minister announced to the Australian people that they could expect `payments to be made to the States in each of the three years 1985-86, 1986-87 and 1987-88 in the form of general revenue grants'. Now that we are in the financial year 1987-88, the Government has seen that it is necessary to amend the Bill in respect of 1987-88. In this context the word `amend' appears to mean `forget about'.

The Bill also incorporates amendments relating to the decision announced in the Budget requiring States to contribute to the cost of higher education superannuation schemes. We now see evidence that the Government has attempted to camouflage the real issue by focusing on the positive aspects of the original Bill and, with the use of pious rhetoric, justifying its actions. According to the Government, this decision constitutes part of the Government's policy of reducing the calls made by all levels of government on the nation's savings. We see, therefore, the image of a person giving with one hand yet taking back with the other. Clearly the good that is done through the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill is offset by the burden that has been placed on the States by the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill.

In the light of the recent Budget wherein the Government failed to go far enough to cut expenditure-and all commentators now agree with that-in order to reduce its astronomical foreign debt, one cannot help wondering whether the Government is expecting the States to compensate for its failure at the Commonwealth level to make these cuts. It is a matter of great concern that the Government is now looking to the States to bail it out of trouble. In the Budget Speech the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tried to restore confidence in the economy by talking it up. But as we see now, talk is no substitute for action, and it is on actions such as this that the Government should be judged. As I said previously, these Bills look good on paper, but in practice the amendments in these Bills serve only to put the States in a more precarious position in comparison with the Commonwealth.

Let us turn our minds back to 11 September 1985 when the Government, through the Minister at the time, sought to introduce the 1985 version of the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill. We are afforded the opportunity of recalling a premise on which the Bill was originally sold. We were told that the Bill provided for-I am referring to page 763 of Hansard of 11 September 1985-a pre-determined real level of financial assistance grants which were designed to be a more certain basis for assisting the States, as opposed to year to year variations in grants under tax sharing arrangements. The Government has also reneged on its previous promise of allowing for a 2 per cent growth in its payments. Instead, the payments to the State remain static at a fixed rate. According to the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), the then shadow Treasurer, who responded for the Opposition in the second reading debate on the Bill on 21 November 1985, and I quote from page 3371 of Hansard:

The three-year financial assistance grants represent a move away from the Fraser federalism concept of tax sharing, providing instead a predetermined real level of financial assistance grants in each of the years.
In the light of the current amendments this move now has even more serious implications, as the honourable member actively predicted. He said:
We are, in fact, going back to the Napoleonic postures of the Whitlam Government by having the Government determine exactly how much the States will get-
or in this case, not get-
in terms of general purpose grants.

As I said, the Government has reneged on its previous promise to make payments to the States in the form of general revenue grants by deciding to treat 1988 as a year outside the normal triennial funding process. In the sphere of higher education this effectively means that the Government has reduced its support of State higher education superannuation schemes. The Federal Government will limit its contributions to State higher education schemes operated on an emerging cost basis. Moreover, it obliges States to make payments to the Commonwealth covering their share of higher education superannuation costs. It does so by making the payment of financial assistance under the Act conditional on such a payment being received by the Commonwealth by 31 May 1988. These are obviously very important matters in the area of education, particularly in these difficult days when people do not have the skills or education to allow them to have meaningful employment. The Federal Government wants others, namely the States, to practise what it preaches but cannot put into practice itself.

I said initially that I wanted to talk a little about the situation in Queensland. Queensland has always practised spending restraint. In terms of total expenditure, Queensland stands out as the low spending State, spending 15 per cent less than the six-State average. Queensland has chosen to have a low spending, low taxing, fiscal regime relative to other States. In light of this fact, Queensland has led the way with its responsible financial management, low taxes, no petrol or other such taxes, and a willingness to place firm limits on expenditure so that year after year the Budget is balanced. However, contrary to Queensland's efforts to curb public expenditure, the Federal Government has increased its expenditure between 1982-83 and 1986-87 to the tune of 22 per cent which, incidentally, matches the very significant increase in revenues in the same period. During this same period when the Commonwealth Government's revenue and expenditure went up by 22 per cent, payments to the States grew by only 6 per cent. One therefore wonders how the honourable member for McEwen can talk in this House about responsible economic management when we have the big spending Commonwealth Government and low spending State governments such as the Queensland Government. It is not a fair spread of the burden of lowering taxation and expenditure restraint.

Quite obviously, the Queensland Government stands ready to play its part in supporting the right policies to solve our national economic problems. But, as has been stated before in the forum of the Queensland Parliament, if it is only the State governments that are playing their parts this will have only a limited effect on the nation's economic ills when the real villain in the piece, the Federal Government, actually increases its expenditure outlays at the same time as it forces the States to reduce theirs. The Federal Government, through these Bills, is in effect merely reinforcing its tactic of passing the buck to the States.

I want to talk briefly about the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Amendment Bill, particularly insofar as it affects the housing industry in my State of Queensland. The Bill is designed to provide a portion of the borrowing component of the State governments' Loan Council programs as concessional loans for public housing which it is envisaged will provide an incentive for the States and the Northern Territory to increase the amounts they direct to public housing. In monetary terms, this effectively means that the Bill authorises payments of $176m as a capital grant to the States and it has the effect of allowing payments of up to a maximum of $414m to the States and Northern Territory as loans for public housing on concessional terms under the principal Act. The actual amount paid in 1987-88 under the principal Act depends on the proportion that each State and the Northern Territory nominates for the purpose of public housing. Therein lies the incentive.

Let me now explain why such a program is imperative to relieving a deteriorating housing situation not only in Queensland but Australia- wide. On a national scale, June 1987 saw a rise of some 12.6 per cent in lending for housing. Additionally, there was a median decrease of a quarter of one per cent in the rate of interest set in July over that set in June. On the basis of these figures, consequently for the whole of Australia, the underlying requirement for new housing is projected to increase from 138,000 dwellings in 1985-86 to nearly 160,000 for 1987-88, representing an average growth of almost 6 per cent a year. Clearly then, the national trend of lower interest rates and an increased availability of funds for housing has stimulated demand for household formation.

The Queensland situation, of course, reflects this trend. The value of loans approved to individuals for the construction or purchase of dwellings in Queensland over the first 11 months of 1986-87 was $1,521.2m. This represents a 5.5 per cent increase in the value of loan approvals for the same period in 1985-86. Within Queensland alone at least $140m is available for expenditure under three types of home ownership schemes in the year 1987-88. They are: firstly, the interest subsidy scheme; secondly, the second loan scheme; and thirdly, commercial schemes. Furthermore, up to 4,000 Queensland families are expected to obtain finance through one of these schemes during the year. By virtue of the fact that the subtle increase in the availability of finance is conducive to an increase in home purchasing, pressure is obviously then redirected on to the supply of new houses. The number of new dwellings approved in Queensland during 1986-87 was 22,540, compared with 26,696 for the previous year. This substantial downturn in the number of new dwelling approvals was mainly the result of tight monetary conditions. Although some slowing in new production was expected during this 1986-87 period, activity fell well short of the underlying requirement for new housing. Unfortunately there has been significant tightening in the Brisbane rental market, with vacancy rates at one per cent for all but overpriced below standard properties.

Currently, on a national scale, housing still remains relatively affordable. I note that in yesterday's Press some authorities indicated that housing is now more affordable on an Australia-wide basis than it was 12 months ago. I think there are still great difficulties out there, particularly for single income families, in affording their own homes. However, with any appreciable improvement in demand higher prices can be expected. That will just exacerbate the position. This will tend to offset the advantages of lower interest rates. Of course, many of us are not convinced that with the macroeconomic and microeconomic policies of the Hawke-Keating Government, interest rates will remain at their present level. They will probably increase because of the inability of the Government to control its expenditure and to decrease the ever-ballooning overseas debt.

In addition to lower interest rates creating a greater demand for housing, which in turn forces housing prices up, the situation is further exacerbated by the sheer numbers of people actually on the housing market. Predictably, a bigger flow of people on the public housing market then forces people to be placed on a waiting list before becoming eligible to purchase a house. In a seller's market such as is the current situation, the buyers merely become the abject pawns. Public dwelling commencements are clearly dependent on both Federal and State funding programs. To be fair, these have been maintained at reasonably high levels following a substantial lift in 1982 which, of course, was in the period of the Fraser-Anthony coalition Government. Contrary to what the honourable member for McEwen said, we in the Opposition do not oppose merely for the sake of opposing. When the Government appears to be making the right decisions, we acknowledge that. I acknowledge those contributions to the States, particularly in the works and housing area. I just make the observation again that it appears to me that the Commonwealth has itself wanted to be the big spender while it has put the belt tighteners on the State governments.

Year after year we debate Bills which appear to be of a machinery nature. I understand that they are important in themselves, but we are now in the modern era of communications and it appears to me that the legislative program of the Government could be improved by including a lot of these Bills in the one debate. There are some very important wider areas of debate which should be canvassed in the Parliament. We saw also that at Question Time yesterday some Ministers were obviously floundering. The new Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) did not really know anything about his department in the early days. Even yesterday, having been a Minister for four months, he had to take on notice what seemed to me to be a fairly innocent type of question.

We would like to see more time devoted to questioning the Government, so we can bring it under close scrutiny, analyse its decisions and seek further information. We need a tightening of the process so that a question honestly asked receives an honest answer. That is certainly not the norm in this Parliament under the Keating-Hawke Administration. More time should be devoted to the critical analysis of matters under debate and there should be more time for things such as matters of public importance when the Government would have to be accountable, and be seen to be accountable, rather than indulging in a litany of legislative debates which, because they have been the norm ever since the Commonwealth Parliament has been part and parcel of the government of Australia, we continue with. Now we are moving to a new Parliament House, maybe it is time to encapsulate various matters into a tighter administrative arrangement and bring the Parliament more up to date by looking at some of the practices of the past. These are important pieces of legislation; I just ask why we have to spend so much time debating what I believe is but machinery legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the two Bills being debated is the States Grants (General Revenue) Amendment Bill. We have heard in the debate the suggestion that the States are being unfairly asked to tighten their belts. But I want to reflect briefly on what I believe to be one of the great mysteries of the recent Federal election, because it impacts directly on what has been a quite distorted and perhaps even hypocritical response by Opposition speakers to this legislation. The fact is that in the recent Federal election campaign spokesmen for the Opposition parties were counselling 16 per cent cuts across the board to programs which they now say require additional expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great ironies of the Tasmanian election campaign was the performance of the State Premier, Robin Gray. There is a famous book about the great detective Sherlock Holmes, who solved the riddle of one important case by looking at the dog that did not bark. The clue in that detective novel was that a dog failed to bark in circumstances where one might reasonably have expected it to bark very loudly indeed. In the context of the Tasmanian election, the dog that did not bark was Robin Gray. The Premier of Tasmania wanted a Liberal Party win like he wanted terminal cancer. That was because spokesmen for the Liberal Party, for the Opposition, were on record as saying that State grants would be cut. The present Liberal shadow Treasurer came to Tasmania and went on record as saying that State funds would be cut. Even he refused to specify the amount, but a 16 per cent across the board cut would have amounted to something in the order of $145m being slashed from State expenditures. In Tasmania, where Commonwealth expenditure constitutes 52 per cent of total Budget funds and all loan funds, such a threat to the fundamentals of Tasmania's economy was obviously something that terrified the Premier.

The clue to the reason why Labor was so successful in the last election lies in the fact that the State Premier was silent throughout the election campaign, failing entirely to support the Liberal coalition. But now, after the election, Premier Gray becomes rather more vocal. He continues the tradition of Tasmanian governments of a Liberal persuasion of blaming the Commonwealth whenever the State Government seeks to set aside its own election commitments whilst seeking credit for projects into which it has put no funding whatsoever.

A very interesting double, if I may say so, is the twin examples of the Claremont senior secondary college-on which the Tasmanian Government has sought to blame the Commonwealth for its failure to proceed with its own election commitments-and the opening of the Davey Street extensions, a project which involved a commitment of some $7m of Commonwealth funds and a pittance of State funds. Those two examples reveal something about the reason Tasmania finds it so difficult to have a credible and respected voice that is listened to by the Commonwealth Government. I have already raised the matter of the Claremont senior secondary college by asking questions of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). Following the recent Federal election, the State Minister for Education and the Premier took the opportunistic approach of seeking from the Commonwealth Government special funding for a project which had been a leading promise of the State Government in its 1985 election campaign. Indeed, the State Government had gone to the extent of bringing in bulldozers, levelling the site and putting up signs saying that a new Claremont senior secondary college would be built on the site, courtesy of the State Government.

Of course, the State Government never intended to proceed with such a construction, and although it made a number of commitments and reasserted those commitments at all stages during the Federal campaign, immediately after the election we found that the project had disappeared from the Tasmanian Government's program entirely. The Premier and Treasurer of Tasmania says in his Budget Speech that his Government has not proceeded with this college because of a shortfall in Commonwealth funding. As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training has responded, very properly, priorities for educational funding are entirely a matter for State governments. The fact is that the Tasmanian Government has been allocated $4.6m in this year for capital funding for schools, and not one dollar of that has been used either in planning or in the first stage construction of a school that the State Government at the time of its election had suggested to the people of Denison was its first priority. Contrast that irresponsibility shown to a sector of the community in very great need with the manner in which the State Government has dealt with road funding.

As part of the bicentennial road development program, the Commonwealth Government made available to the State over $6m to upgrade a very difficult section of road leading from the eastern shore to the city, which caused traffic jams and problems for commuters. Although almost all of the funding for that project was provided by the Commonwealth, the State Government decided to usurp any recognition of that contribution by holding its own private opening ceremony before the joint ceremony. Two months ago the State Government sent two of its Ministers to press a button to operate a set of lights and get the traffic flow moving. That was done without any recognition of the Federal contribution. Subsequently, last week, the Federal Minister was in Hobart to launch that road project formally. It was not just the Federal Minister who was snubbed by the State Government but also the Lord Mayor of Hobart, who expressed her view that it was somewhat disquieting that although she was on the platform for the official opening she was surprised that she had not been present at the earlier purported opening.

Hypocrisy of this kind makes it very difficult for spokesmen such as I who seek to speak out for the real problems in Tasmania because the legitimate concerns of Tasmania are often clouded by the distortions that are built into practices of that kind: practices that seek to blame the Commonwealth when the State fails to accept its responsibilities, practices when the State seeks to accept the entirety of the credit for projects that are substantially funded by the Commonwealth.

It is important in the context of discussing the funds made available to the States to recall that the object of the reduction in demand for the government sector was agreed to by all of the Premiers at the Premiers Conference. There was a national agreement that it was important for the Commonwealth and the State governments to reduce their claims on the financial resources of the country in order to sustain the lowering of interest rates that has occurred in recent times. But today we have heard a suggestion that the burden has unfairly fallen on the States, that they have been unfairly asked to take too great a share of the financial burden. The reality is, however, that the States have been increasing State taxation at a very substantial rate.

Let us look at the picture in Tasmania. The Tasmanian Treasurer has increased taxes by 37 per cent over two years. This year there has been a 15 per cent increase in taxation. It is most severe and is certainly well above any taxation increase imposed by any other State. I note in this regard that my colleague the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who continually bewails the price of petrol, should pause to reflect on the fact that the reason why Tasmania's petrol is significantly more highly priced than petrol in certain mainland States is a State duty on petrol of 7c a litre.

In Tasmania, Commonwealth revenue has declined. It has declined in a way that the Premier acknowledged to be fair; in a way that the Opposition said at the most recent Federal election was insufficient. In practice $42m has been lost to general revenue in Tasmania but, by contrast, tax receipts by the Tasmanian Government have gone up by $80m. In other words, having lost $42m in general revenue for two reasons-the general Commonwealth reduction and the effects of the Commonwealth Grants Commission on bringing about fairer relativities between the States-the Treasurer and Premier of Tasmania has remedied that deficiency by taking twice that amount in taxation. He has not just brought revenues up to what they would have been otherwise but to twice the amount. That has occurred in a circumstance in which, clearly, the State Government is now seeking to set aside hidden funds, hidden reserves, to cushion itself against future election commitments that it may intend to make. I invite those who are interested in looking at the details to look at page 114 of the Budget documents of the Tasmanian Parliament and to consider the hidden figure of $29m which has been plainly set aside, outside any disclosure by the Tasmanian Government. It is obviously intended for political purposes.

The brutal reality is that the Tasmanian Go-vernment is one of the most political governments in Australia. It is crudely discriminating against the south of the State in favour of the north. Over two-thirds of funds allocated in capital works for education and health services have gone to the north, rather than the south, of the State. This reflects the clear political priorities of the Premier and his concession, in a political sense, that he has lost support in the south of the State and will do anything to shore up his support in the north.

I regard it as a real tragedy that those who went to the last election on a program of slashing social expenditures-16 per cent cuts across the board-have to this date failed to condescend to give any particulars. They have totally failed to detail to this Parliament the cuts they would now make or the measures they would take. We continue to hear the simplistic nostrums of the New Right-slashing taxes, slashing social services-and the failed rhetoric of those who would seek to expose Australia even further to the rigors of the free market.

We have heard a lot about exposing ourselves to what is said to be the discipline of the free market. But surely after the experiences of the last couple of days, even the most ardent free market supporters are grateful that the mechanisms which were put in place by State intervention following the 1930s are still here. Compulsory State intervention has made certain that the banks must have adequate arrangements to protect depositors, arrangements that make sure that networks of social services are in place so that the processes that might otherwise have been unleashed on this country and on the international sphere are ameliorated and mitigated.

We still have the crude nonsense of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) who, in his first response following the Wall Street crash, sought to raise the spectre of wage reductions in a context where plainly the further cutback of domestic demand would only plunge the eco-nomy into recession and would move us to a prolongation of whatever effects are likely to arise from the recent disturbing events in the stock markets. Certainly, no one would pretend that we now have sufficient information before us to know whether the events of recent days have blown themselves out, whether they have stabilised or whether the market will recover. One can only hope that there will be a substantial recovery in the market place as soon as possible because one of the significant effects of a substantially reduced market would be that investment in the kind of processes we need to revitalise our economy would be less likely. Reduced prices of equity capital would tend to mean that investors inclined to make investment decisions would choose to buy existing equity rather than the new plant and new equipment which is necessary to restructure our economy and to continue the process of bringing it into a competitive edge with the rest of the world.

I conclude my remarks by saying that I find it extraordinarily disappointing that this debate has been conducted in such broad generalities in a context in which the Opposition appears to be ostrich-like, unable to realise that its failed nostrums have been rejected by the Australian public. It has not come to terms with the impact that the discredited rhetoric and nostrums of the New Right would have had on the Australian domestic economy. Even the Tasmanian Premier, the Liberal Party's only State Premier, failed to support the Opposition because of those very policies. I return to where I started in this debate and the point that I made: there is only one side in this House playing the game and that is the Australian Labor Party which is seeking to place the economy in an ordered way so that it can face up to the rigors and disciplines of our new investment environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard an interesting speech from the temporary honorary member for Denison (Mr Kerr), who is keeping the seat warm until Michael Hodgman gets back here. This House awaits the day of Michael's return so that the State of Tasmania will have full, effective and proper representation. We have in the chamber the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), a man who is dedicated to the real interests of Tasmania. I suggest that if the honourable member for Denison were really committed to Tasmania, as he claims to be, he would have nothing to do but support Robin Gray. The Tasmanian Premier has done more for that State than any Premier in its history and the way in which this Labor Government in Canberra has tramped over the State's rights of Tasmania is disgraceful. The economic problems that may be present in that State have all been caused by the gross uncertainty and unfairness-the victimisation of that State-created here in Canberra. I see that the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) is in the chamber and he is nodding in agreement. I know that these two fine members from Tasmania-the honourable members for Franklin and Bass-are right behind Robin Gray and what he has achieved despite victimisation from Canberra. It is a real record of effective and efficient economic management by a State government. If those same principles that are being exercised in Tasmania were to be exercised by the Labor States in Australia we would see quite a different scene. The honourable member for Denison spoke about hollow logs. The hollow log in New South Wales contains more than $2,000m. That money has been tucked away by Barrie Unsworth and his mob to bring out at any time they wish to do so. That is a disgraceful way of managing a State.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to look at States grants and the management of the economy one needs to spend a brief time looking at the Federal scene and then seeing how that is related to the finances of the States of Australia. The Federal Government has had a difficult time and continues in a difficult time because it has failed to take notice of the advice that it has been given by a wide range of people. For instance, its own bank, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, in its economic newsletter of August this year states:

Due to the magnitude and intractability of the problems Australia faces, this two-pronged approach, at both the macro and micro level, is essential if the necessary structural adjustments are to occur. Even with this comprehensive policy approach, turning around the current account deficit (which was $13.6 billion in 1986-87) and bringing the foreign debt position into balance (net foreign debt was $84.5 billion in March 1987) will take a considerable time.

The Commonwealth Bank is saying to the Government that its management technique has to be very careful and restrained. That publication came out prior to the last Budget. It is interesting to note that the comments of the Commonwealth Bank are endorsed by Westpac Banking Corporation in its newsletter of August 1987 when it said:
To ignore the opportunity to reduce the deficit further would be a mistake.
Another summary says:
. . . a radical attack needs to be made on all aspects of business life which retard economic performance.
Westpac has also issued a warning to the Commonwealth Government which was ignored in the opportunity of the Budget. Westpac said:

An essential for longer-term economic performance will be a revival of investment spending. In the year to March 1987, spending on new plant and equipment fell by over 3 per cent in real terms and a further real decline could eventuate in 1987-88.

That is the framework of the Budget. What did the Commonwealth Government do in response to the warnings it was receiving right across the board from all sectors of the community as to how it should manage the then forthcoming Federal Budget? What it did, of course, was to increase its own outlays and cut the outlays to the States. One could say that that was a political approach that would retain the popularity of the Federal Government. That is not so. A government in its first term of office has a one-off opportunity to take serious and proper decisions. Those opportunities have been missed and they are lost. The occurrences of the last couple of days in the stock markets of the world underline the significance of a Federal Budget of the type suggested by economic advisers. That chance has been lost and the poor circumstances in which Australia finds itself have been exacerbated by the failure of this Government to apply itself rigorously to economic management and its own expenditure.

For instance, in the Budget outlays for this year the Commonwealth Government expenditure is up by a total of 4.3 per cent to a total figure estimated at roughly $78 billion. The areas in which the Government chose to increase its own expenditure are interesting. Basically, it increased its expenditure in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is running the Bicentenary and keeping an eye on everybody else. The Parliament received some increase but the economic areas that were necessary for the Government to pursue, in order to provide a dynamic approach to an economy which was failing and uncompetitive, can be summarised by the failure of the Government to inject funds into productive areas such as transport, communications and defence. Those areas were the real losers in the Federal Budget. The real winners were areas that were not really significant for economic sustenance, output and growth.

The Government's Budget produced a phoney deficit. The real deficit of $1.5 billion is the right figure. On top of that, the Government increased its outlays into areas that are not of economic significance for the future of Australia. The House would be aware that in that same Budget comparisons were made between total Government outlays over a period. I draw to the attention of the House the fact that in the last 20 years total government expenditure has increased more than 15-fold from about $7 billion in 1966-67 to a massive figure in 1986-87. If one looks at this expenditure in constant terms one will see that over the last 10 years Commonwealth expenditure has increased by 30 per cent above inflation. So we have had inflationary increases in government expenditure plus an additional 30 per cent increase. That is profligate spending by the Commonwealth Government. I refer the House to table 3 of Budget Paper No. 1, which clearly sets out the massive 30 per cent increase in constant terms in government expenditure over inflation over the 10-year period.

What has the Government done to the States? This legislation is connected with the funds provided by the Commonwealth for State government expenditure in the current year. Budget Paper No. 4 provides some of the details. The total increase in expenditure for State governments, that is, by borrowings and by way of grants, is 2.4 per cent, half of the increase the Government has allocated for itself. I have no problem with the smaller increase in the allocation to State governments. Great concern has been expressed at the Commonwealth level about the accountability of State governments for their use of the funds they get from the Commonwealth and for the way in which those funds can be siphoned off or allocated in a notional way. All the Commonwealth requires is an Auditor-General's certificate. I have no problem with the 2.4 per cent increase to State governments this year. What I have a problem with is the fact that the Commonwealth was prepared to cut State government expenditure but was not prepared to do anything about its own expenditure.

An analysis of expenditure by the Commonwealth in the form of specific purpose grants to the States indicates that again in areas of economic importance the State governments have had their allocation reduced. There is a 16 per cent real reduction in the allocation for housing and community amenities and a 0.3 per cent increase in the allocation for transport and communication, a line ball situation. In real terms it is a decrease. There is a decrease of 24 per cent in the allocation for industry and development, a 26 per cent reduction in the allocation for labour and employment, and a reduction of 42 per cent in the allocation for other economic services. So the Commonwealth Government is screwing down the States in areas of economic productivity and economic importance, blowing out its own Budget and claiming more tax from pay as you earn taxpayers and small business but failing to cut its own outlays.

One must note the favouritism that is reflected in these allocations-in the massive reduction of assistance to the Northern Territory, which is deplorable. On the same political basis, Tasmania has been selected by the Commonwealth Government for damaging cuts. But the Northern Territory and Tasmania have capable managers. They will live with the cuts that have been made. States such as New South Wales scream and claim that they cannot live with the reductions that have been made. State and local public authorities currently constitute about 40 per cent of the public sector and account for about 22 per cent of the gross domestic product. They are also responsible for about 40 per cent of the national public sector debt and about 60 per cent of overseas borrowings. They are big business and they need to be accountable. The Government has reined in expenditure to those States mainly in economic areas where there would be some economic flow on.

State governments obtain about half of their revenue from the Federal Government. The rest they raise themselves. The lack of accountability State governments have to the Commonwealth is a matter of some concern. It has been estimated by the Australian Chamber of Commerce that in New South Wales the total hollow log, the largest holdings by any State government available for use but tucked away in reserve, is probably about $2,096m. The total of the hollow logs around the States is about $5,230m. That is a lot of money to be lying at the beck and call of State governments. The accountability process for State governments needs to be improved. It has been a constant problem for the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth must either make the States responsible for their own revenue raising or have a better accountability process.

The reduction in the Budget of the allocation to State governments comes on top of the lavish spending programs of some State governments. Instead of concentrating their effort on economic output, governments such as the New South Wales Government choose to provide entertainment centres and lavish and expensive projects such as the Darling Harbour project. The state of roads and hospitals in New South Wales is deplorable. In our own western Sydney area there are empty beds in Westmead Hospital. Ward after ward has been closed in Westmead. This is the Yes, Minister concept: if one does not open a hospital it is cheaper than opening it. So there are empty beds with patients clamouring for attention but nobody to provide the care that is needed. In the Mount Druitt Hospital, right in the centre of a massive and growing area, there is not even a maternity ward. The planning of the New South Wales State Government for health services in the State is absolutely dreadful.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was planned by the Liberal Government.

—That is an interesting interjection. When the Liberal Party claims the planning and development of Westmead the Labor Party says, `That was all Labor Party'. It is wrong on both counts. The health services of western Sydney, in that fast growing area, are deplorable, as are the conditions of roads. Yet the State Government of New South Wales, pandering to its mates, to those people who selectively support and donate to the Labor Party in New South Wales, has chosen to deny opportunity to the people of western Sydney, to deny essential services and to roll all their money into the circuses it is providing in central Sydney, such as entertainment centres and the Darling Harbour project. It is an incredible way of managing a State. The Government of New South Wales will certainly get the result it deserves at the next election. It will lose, and lose massively, mainly because it will be voted out of office by ordinary tax paying citizens paying who want to see some return for it in the community where they live and not see it floated off into grandiose projects which support the ego of the Premier of the day but which are of benefit to few people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth has reduced expenditure to the States but has not reduced its own expenditure. This is a serious situation. The Government would do well to take note of the need for immediate economic adjustment. It needs to rein in its own expenditure. It needs to look at where it is putting money. Australians are paying far too much in taxation for what they are getting back. This year every Australian worked from 1 January to 9 June just to pay the Commonwealth bill. The rest of the year they had to themselves. So for almost half the year total government expenditure was provided by Australians working. That is not the way to run Australia, with the difficulties we face at the moment. The average family is paying heaps more in taxation.

I remind the Government of the election campaign in which it was clearly indicated-it was never denied by a single Government spokesman-that every family in Australia paid $37 a week more in tax after the Labor Party was elected in 1983. That is the way to destroy the will and the commitment of Australians. I call on the Government to change radically its process of evaluation of State programs or give the States their own revenue raising processes, and to reduce its own expenditure. The Hawke Government made heaps of promises and has broken nearly all of them. The Hawke Government said that it would not have early elections, that there would be no capital gains tax, that interest rates would fall after the 1984 election, and that the one per cent levy would be sufficient for Medicare. It is grab, grab, grab all the time by this Government. It is prepared to put restrictions on State and local authorities, but none on itself. I appeal to members of the Australian Labor Party: now is the time for a bit of discipline among your ranks so that you can bring this nation under effective management. The Labor Government has not endeavoured to do that. It is prepared to allow the Prime Minister-whose name, from what I read in the Press, is O'Hawke rather than Hawke-merely to be popular, and it is time Labor members disciplined him. He wants popularity for the sake of it and has no sense of responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —They cheer him at football over there. That is why he likes it.

—Yes, they cheer him at football, but he has to go to Ireland to get a cheer because he would get only raspberries in Australia today. I cannot find a person who voted for the Prime Minister because people are sick and tired of the populist approach instead of a responsible approach. It is time that this Government became rigorous, dedicated and efficient in its management.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was fascinating to hear the remarks of the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). He was a member of the Government of the day that gave this country the worst unemployment, the highest inflation, the highest interest rates ever in the history of this country. But this morning the honourable member said in the earlier part of his speech, `Why should not this Government be providing more for Tasmania and more for the Northern Territory?'.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order on the matter of relevance. The Minister is not talking about this subject, but he is the bloke who did the deal with Amann Aviation. He has no credibility at all-none.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not propose to grace the honourable member by responding to that kind of comment. The facts stand for themselves and one has only to refer to the Hansard. This morning the Opposition complains as to why more money is not being provided by this Government for the State of Tasmania and for the Northern Territory. This afternoon Opposition members will be complaining that too much is being spent. By tomorrow morning we will be told that the deficit is too high and should be lower. But what Opposition members seem to forget is that only weeks ago their proposals were put to the community and rejected.
—We got more votes than you did.
—Order!
—That is the test and the assessment-the ballot box.
—More Australians agreed with us than agreed with you.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell has had his opportunity to debate the issue.

—The honourable member for Mitchell is sitting where the people of Australia put him; that is their judgment. I note that the Opposition does not oppose the legislation before the chamber. I thank those members who have participated in the debate and for the manner in which they have facilitated the passage of this Bill. I suggest that the question be decided.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (WORKS AND HOUSING) ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 September, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not opposing the provisions of the Bill, the House condemns the Government for the delay in the re-institution of negative gearing and for the pursuit of economic policies which have:
(a) forced a record number of over 161,000 Australians on to public housing lists.
(b) resulted in a long period of record high interest rates, and
(c) resulted last year in the lowest number of housing starts for the last 20 years excepting the drought year of 1982-83'.

This amendment has been circulated and I look forward to hearing the Government's response to the comments I raised in the cognate debate. There is a crisis in housing in this nation at the moment. There is a record number of people on public housing waiting lists, a record number of people waiting for home purchase assistance under State schemes, yet the Government is now cutting public housing and capital funding by $468m. There have been record high interest rates, the lowest number of housing starts last year for 20 years, bar the drought year of 1982-83, and according to the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry the number of housing starts this year is expected to fall between 32,000 and 42,000 houses short of the expected demand. We know that home owners are now paying up to 17 per cent more of their income on mortgage repayments than they were a decade ago. This Government's record on housing is a disgrace. Much needs to be done, and I look forward to a response from the Government as to the changes in economic policy that it will make to address the drastic needs facing home buyers, especially young home buyers, in this nation.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Legislation Amendment Bill proposes a number of amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act and related Acts. This is almost a matter of `Here we go again', because this is the legislation that seeks to change the cash bidding legislation. This saga began in 1985. With the support of the Australian Democrats, an amendment was put through then to provide that there be a two-year trial period in highly prospective territory of the Ashmore and Cartier Islands adjacent areas with regard to the cash bidding legislation. Clause 19 of this Bill seeks to remove that sunset clause. It is interesting to reflect that the Democrats were originally against the whole concept of cash bidding-which I shall talk about shortly-but at the last moment they put forward the sunset clause, which got through the Senate.
