Although we will have to wait and see what happens in the Senate, I understand that the Democrats will now join with the Government to allow this legislation to go through. It is my view, and the view of the coalition, that this is a black day for oil exploration in Australia, because it will become a thing of the past if this legislation goes through. I hope that the Democrats will reconsider their position.

SPEECH.PARA: The arguments outlined by the coalition back in 1985, when the Government introduced the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Cash Bidding) Amendment Bill, have changed little. In fact, the continuing downturn of off-shore oil exploration and development since then further strengthen our arguments. When that Bill came in in 1985 the coalition parties rejected the notion of cash bidding for oil exploration. We argued then, as we do now, some major points and, if anything, those points have greater credence today.

Cash bidding is an upfront impost dressed up as an auction system for the right to undertake the risk of exploration. The work program which applies to the bulk of applications for oil exploration permits has successfully operated for years and is the most equitable means of allocating off-shore exploration permits. Smaller companies, of which there are a great number involved in exploration in Australia, will not be able to finance their offers or their payments at a cost equivalent to that of larger companies. Cash bidding, in combination with the resource rent tax, which interestingly is being introduced into the House this afternoon, in legislation which is also coming back again after being previously rejected, would be a disincentive to oil exploration. It was argued then, and is now, that both seek to capture the same economic rent-the resource rent tax from the production phase where the end value is known, and cash bidding from the exploration phase where the end value is unknown. Unlike the Government, we recognise that Australia can ill afford the diversion of high cost risk capital from exploration budgets.

The coalition also believes that the revenue raised from cash bidding is likely to be far less than that from taxes on production. The cash bid concept is linked to high prospectivity. However, it is widely recognised that Australia is not prospective enough to warrant cash bidding. The coalition argues that the Government's paramount objective is to raise revenue and not, as is claimed, to assist off-shore activity. Indeed, it is interesting to look at some international experience with cash bidding and to see what was said as long ago as 1985 in the Oil and Gas Journal, an international journal. It talked about Senator Evans, who originally proposed this legislation, and about what had happened in the United States of America, the United Kingdom and Canada. It stated:

The U.K. nearly squeezed the life out of all but the biggest North Sea fields until it eased its tax loads on operators. Canada's industry was all but shut down until recently by an onerous energy program that kept offshore activity alive only by virtue of frontier subsidies. And U.S. cash bidding is such a triumph that the U.S. has managed to lease all of 20% of its federally owned offshore in 30 years, has tried for the last decade to find some other leasing method, and has shut industry out of some of the most promising acreage on the whole Outer Continental Shelf.
Tellingly it then stated this:

Governments get into trouble with offshore programs when they forget that the reason for granting exploration rights is to accommodate exploration-not to enrich national treasuries or to cater to antidevelopment interest groups.

It is quite clear that the reason for this legislation is to raise revenue. It ignores the real need to ensure that exploration in this country continues. Interestingly, I will seek leave of the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris), who is at the table, to incorporate a graph in my speech later. Perhaps the Minister can have a look at it in the meantime. Since the introduction of cash bidding exploration we have seen the number of exploration wells decline. Only 44 wildcat wells have been drilled in the past 30 months, compared with 47 in 1983 alone and 32 in 1985. While part of this fall can be attributed to a decline in oil prices, the application of cash bidding will not, the industry warns, help to overcome this clearly undesirable trend, and will in fact accentuate it.

The inability of the Government to accept that there is a relationship between tax levels, especially those imposed before exploration has begun, and exploration activity and discovery is of particular concern, given the rapid decline in the ability of domestic crude oil supplies to meet domestic demand. No one denies the community the right to a return from the development of community owned natural resources. But this particular well is running dry as a source of government revenue. This legislation demonstrates the Government's ignorance of oil exploration financing mechanisms in its grasp for revenue. Indeed, referring again to international experience, the Government seems to have ignored that as well. The Government seems determined to kill the goose but not before it has extracted its pound of flesh. We as a nation will regret this legislation if it goes through.

The coalition opposes the whole concept of cash bidding. The industry, represented by the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association Ltd and the Australian Institute of Petroleum Ltd, opposes it also. The Northern Territory Government opposes it. The West Australian Labor Government opposed it in 1985. It is most interesting that we have not heard from Premier Burke about this legislation. It is very puzzling to know why. With regard to one of the other amendments in this legislation, Western Australia has a special arrangement existing at present, and that will be changed. It is surprising that we have not heard from Premier Burke. The Western Australian Liberal Government in 1980 agreed to it only on the basis of special arrangements which applied to Western Australia and the Northern Territory; this Bill seeks to remove those special arrangements. The present Liberal Party of Australia in Western Australia is totally opposed to the removal of the special arrangements. Indeed, its Deputy Leader, Mr Richard Court, has made that perfectly clear on many occasions. But, as I have said, we have not heard a word from Premier Burke. Under the arrangements relating to the joint authority set in place to determine a lot of the issues involved with off-shore exploration, any problems were to be resolved on a Premier-Prime Minister basis. That has now been removed. One may well speculate that that is because Mr Burke no longer gets on well with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

As I have said, the Democrats initially opposed the whole concept of cash bidding and proposed the sunset clause which this Bill also seeks to remove. Where is the general support claimed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin)? It is regrettable that he is not here today. I know that the Minister for Resources is here; he has some joint responsibility in some of these areas. But this is a very significant and important Bill. The amount to which we in this country rely on petroleum duties for revenue is excessive. I know that the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who will be speaking in this debate, will allude to that.

I add, by way of information to the House and to those people who will read the Hansard, that the honourable member for Franklin has been a tireless fighter on the whole issue of petrol prices, trying to protect the little people, who will be the ones who will suffer if we have to import oil in the future. I know that many people have heard the honourable member for Franklin speak previously-indeed he spoke most eloquently yesterday-on the whole issue of petrol prices. I am sure that those who take the time to listen to him will learn a bit more about the very detailed and complex issue of petrol prices. That in itself is one reason why the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy ought to be here. These issues are complex; they are detailed; they are not matters that ought to be just slipped through the House without his presence and without his contribution to the debate.

Where is that general support? It does not seem to be there. The Government says that it has reviewed the effectiveness of cash bidding. It says that it rejects the concerns expressed by the oil exploration industries, the States and the Northern Territory. One wonders what kind of review could be achieved in the short time that cash bidding has been operating. The review, done only one year after cash bid permits were granted, could hardly pretend to examine adequately the effect of cash bidding on exploration activity, or indeed be sufficient for the system to be well understood by the bidders themselves.

If anything, what the Government ought to be doing is extending the sunset clause. I asked the Minister in a letter whether I could look at the review upon which he has relied and to which he referred in his second reading speech. It is really a rather pathetic document. It goes for about four or five pages and does not tell us anything. It relates the arguments that were put originally against cash bidding; that is about all it does. It makes assertions that we ought to have cash bidding because in effect we need the revenue. As I said earlier, what will happen is that this Government will get into trouble because what is important in the oil industry is that we facilitate exploration, not look at oil exploration activity as a mechanism to enrich national treasuries.

The Government, in introducing this Bill, appears to miss the very real crisis that will soon face Australia in the form of massively increasing oil import bills. I do not know whether Australians are aware of the crisis that awaits us a little further down the track. We all know what is happening today. But any government is entrusted not only to look after the issues of today but also to think about what will happen tomorrow. This Government does not appear to be thinking clearly or strategically about the very difficulties that we will face in the oil industry in the years ahead.

World oil prices are low and uncertain. Australia's known petroleum reserves are declining, and petroleum exploration is severely cut back. In this environment it is particularly important to ensure that the tax system does not continue to make petroleum exploration and development projects unattractive relative to other investment opportunities in Australia, or relative to petroleum exploration development in other countries. The latter is already happening. A recent report in the Australian had an interesting headline `Oil groups pump up to $180m offshore'. Australian companies are going off-shore. They are going to other countries, rather than to Australian territorial waters, to explore. I quote from the article:

Among the companies recently announcing the acquisition of US gas or oil interests are Lennard Oil NL, Lakes Oil Ltd, Peko Oil Ltd, Stirling Petroleum NL, Bligh Oil and Minerals NL, BHP Petroleum Pty Ltd, Barcoo Petroleum NL, Orca Petroleum NL and Bridge Oil Ltd.
The article goes on:

One of the biggest overseas commitments has been made by Peko Oil Ltd which, according to the group executive . . . is hoping its US base of oil reserves can be doubled or tripled in the next six months.

So we have $180m of Australian equity being spent in the United States-not here-looking for oil. That money is lost to us. We have to make sure that we can make it attractive for them to be spending those exploration dollars here wherever we possibly can. I know that the issue is complex and all of us would accept that, but it is intriguing to see what is happening. I would like to quote from another interesting article in the Australian Financial Review today because it indicates the thinking of some of the Australian companies. Mr Jamieson of Orca Petroleum, one of those companies that are going off-shore, is quoted as saying:

Access to international acreage is much more attractive in highly prospective areas compared with Australia, chances of discovery are better and exploration costs-particularly in the US-are much lower.

It is also going to be active in Colombia in South America. The problems of the lack of prospectivity in this country, the costs of exploration and the very large distances that are involved in getting any finds to markets have to be taken into account and be factored into possible activities by companies when they are assessing the financial viability of a search. If we put in place a taxation regime that works against the activities of Australian companies we are working against our own best interests. In time, when the Bass Strait oil fields, which are declining, finally dry up we will end up having to import oil. I will make some remarks about what that will do to our economy if that trend continues. We are denying Australia the capital necessary to find those additional reserves of oil. This outflow of funds does considerable damage to our balance of payments.

The Government also appears to ignore the fact that off-shore exploration has failed to find an oil field in excess of 50 million barrels and that Australia needs to find the equivalent of two to three such fields each year if it is to maintain liquid fuel self-sufficiency at 50 per cent by the year 2000. We have not found a field of 50 million barrels and we need to find that equivalent of two to three a year if we are to maintain self-sufficiency given that the Bass Strait fields are declining.

I do not know whether the cash bidding legislation and the RRT legislation, which I understand is coming in this afternoon, have changed in form from what was originally proposed-I suspect that they have-but I would like the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to tell me how this legislation is going to enhance the opportunity for us to find those 50 million barrels when we have Australian companies going elsewhere to look for oil. One must accept that we do have a degree of prospectivity. I seek leave to have a graph incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the document depicts a graph and not a table. Graphs cannot be incorporated. The honourable member could seek leave to table it.
—I seek leave to table the graph.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we look at the exploration levels that have been taking place in Australia in terms of dollars invested, we will see that in 1983, $520m was spent; in 1987 it is estimated that only $137m will be spent. If we look at this table graphically-I can see the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), who is at the table, looking at it in a very puzzled way-we can see that we really have a major problem in front of us.

SPEECH.PARA: With known reserves of crude oil now around 1.9 billion barrels, at current annual rates of consumption of some 170 million barrels, the demonstrated economic reserves here in Australia will last only another 11 years. So a little further down the track we face a window of crisis in this country in terms of self-sufficiency in oil. We must be thinking about that today when we are putting into place taxation mechanisms that apply to the oil industry. Exploration is the very basic and fundamental requirement to determine whether we are going to be able to be self-sufficient. We must not do anything that is in any way going to act as a deterrent to Australian companies or investors, even though some of them are international companies, to put forward risk capital-and it is risk capital-to find oil. There is no prospect of establishing quickly enough an alternative to oil in the time frame we face to cover the crisis.

We must be thinking far more deeply than we are at present. Without further oil discoveries, net import costs would rise to $3.2 billion per year by 1992. The year 1992 is not a long way away. By the year 2000, Australia could be dependent on foreign sources for up to 60 per cent of its oil supply. Currently we have 80 per cent self-sufficiency. So that equation will turn around dramatically. The predicted decline in oil self-sufficiency will only be accentuated by a continuation of cash bidding and consequent suppression of off-shore drilling activity, which seems to be the area where we have the greatest prospectivity.

The Minister argued in his second reading speech in September that cash bidding is a more efficient and equitable system than the work program system, especially in areas where the competition is expected to be intense. By contrast, the industry argues that the work program, which applies to the bulk of applications for oil exploration permits, has operated satisfactorily for some years. Companies have participated in cash bidding as this was the only way they could obtain interest in highly prospective acreages. Santos Ltd, for example, says that it would have been committed to an active exploration program in the territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands and adjacent areas under the work program alternative.

Although the work program bidding system is more regulatory, it is superior to the cash bidding alternative. The Minister claims that exploration risks and costs are reduced by cash bidding because the cash bidding system is more flexible. He instances the fact that 39 per cent of work program permits sought deferments after the fall in oil prices. However, under the cash bidding system, successful bidders need to give no undertakings of what work will be done or when it will be done. This is hardly the way to provide the systems and incentives to encourage the pace of exploration in the face of declining reserves. The work program requires such a commitment.

There seems little reason why the present work program system cannot be flexibly administered to take into account oil price rises and falls. The Government's claim that administration costs are lower and the award of permits is faster under the cash bidding system belies the fact that companies face increased costs before a drop of oil is found. The oil industry has argued strongly that money siphoned off as cash bids cannot be spent on seismic acquisition and drilling, a fact that is lost on the Minister. It is estimated that $30m paid recently in the cash bid for the Ashmore and Cartier permit could have been directed to another five or six wildcat wells. If one looks at the graph I have tabled one can see the massive decline in the number of wildcat wells that have been undertaken in Australia in recent years.

The prospectivity of the Timor Sea is now in question. The cash bid concept was introduced in the belief that because prospectivity was high the Government stood to collect substantial income. Subsequent drilling in the Timor Sea has delineated reserves of less than 20 million barrels at Jabiru and possibly 40 million at Challis. It now appears that this area is more likely to contain a number of relatively small fields, and extensive exploration will be required to discover its potential. We will recall that cash bidding was originally proposed in 1985, a completely different climate of the understanding of the level of prospectivity in the Ashmore-Cartier-Timor Sea area. We now know that it is not as rich as we thought it was, but still the Government persists in coming back with this legislation. It really is economic lunacy.

Under the cash bidding arrangements an offer may be rejected if the Government deems it `inadequate' in relation to the assessed prospectivity of the area, or because of insufficient competition. Cash bidding is meant to be based on allowing companies to indicate their assessment of the economic merit of an area. One would think that the Minister would understand that the lack of competition in itself indicated the lack of worth of an area-and hence a low cash bid. In addition, the fact that cash bids may not be accepted if inadequate introduces an arbitrary element into decision making. That the Government rejects such bids in indicative of its real purpose-a disguised form of taxation, despite all Government claims to the contrary. When the Minister responds he should answer that charge.

The Minister also argued in his second reading speech that the two-year sunset clause was to check the possible negative effects on exploration and on the ability of small companies to participate. The Government points to the successful bidding round in 1986. However, this was essentially prior to the collapse in oil prices. Again I say: we were looking at a totally different environment. Subsequent to the price fall, exploration activity was lower in both work program and cash bid areas. However, the activity in the cash bid areas has almost come to a standstill. To date not a single well has been drilled on any permit awarded on a cash bidding basis and very limited seismic work has been carried out in one permit only. While it is acknowledged that this lack of activity in itself says nothing about the deficiencies or otherwise of cash bidding, it clearly demonstrates that any review is premature and any conclusion based on such a review must be viewed accordingly.

The Minister claims that Australian companies have not been discriminated against and that Australian equity in oil exploration in the cash bid permit areas is high at 62.7 per cent. However, if the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is excluded, the equity is only 25 per cent, versus 47.8 per cent for work program blocks. Although some small companies are included in the Australian consortia, the danger that small companies will find in the United States a more attractive investment climate is already being demonstrated, as I illustrated earlier.

While the Government views cash bidding and the resource rent tax as complementary measures-a view which it admits is a philosophical judgment-a more pragmatic view is possible: that both forms of taxation seek to capture the same rent; that oil companies can ill afford a diversion of high cost risk capital from exploration budgets; and that taxes which seek a take from the exploration phase, where the end value is unknown, act as a disincentive to exploration. I quote from a letter that I received from one of Australia's primary explorers, Santos Ltd:
What does not seem to be understood is that the funds Santos need to direct to a successful cash bid means that we will be carrying out less exploration work than otherwise.

Equally philosophical might be the view that the Government, like the oil companies, should be willing to wait for its revenue rewards. The community is likely to benefit far more from the industry being able to expend fully its exploration budgets on acquisition of seismic data and on drilling than by diverting much needed capital to cash bids for off-shore acreage that is very high risk.

There are some other elements in the legislation that are of concern to the oil companies and the States. Again, I am at a loss to know why Western Australia's Premier has not put up his hand to be heard on this issue. The legislation removes the special arrangement with Western Australia, making the Act uniform to all parties. Western Australia has been very successful in oil and gas exploration and production under the current arrangements. The Liberal Opposition views as a complete breach of trust the removal of the very practical and realistic recognition which Western Australia enjoyed under the submerged lands legislation. The Joint Authority is not constrained as to how it makes a judgment about whether a petroleum pool extends under one or more blocks. This can be seen in clause 9. Previously this was not an issue in that the location was automatically granted over a certain configuration of blocks depending upon the actual location of the nominated block in relation to permit boundaries. This amendment could cause problems with the size and definition of a location and could lead to disagreement between the permittee and the Joint Authority. That locations are to be defined by reference to petroleum pools is surely putting the cart before the horse. Currently the declaration of locations is a technique to allow the grant of a licence large enough to contain an as yet undefined pool. In other words, one of the purposes of declaring a location was to allow the size of the pool to be determined.

Also in question is the effect of clause 8, which relates to royalties payable on secondary licences. Although the Government states that, except for the repeal of the cash bidding sunset clause, the amendments are not expected to have any financial impact, this amendment is most likely to increase the amount of royalty payable, with the increase going to the relevant State government.

As a large part of Australia's remaining undiscovered oil reserves are believed to be located off-shore, the Government should be doing all in its power to encourage off-shore exploration. While cash bidding is only one factor influencing investment in the off-shore oil search, it is a real deterrent to activity, as I have already demonstrated today. No convincing evidence has been put forward by the Government to support the continuation of this experiment. The review that was given to me by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy certainly does not make out a case for the removal of the sunset clause and the retention of the cash bidding system currently in place. Indeed, if that is the only review that he undertook, I am led to the view that he has been very badly advised. Perhaps he ought to go back and ask a few more questions. It is interesting that he seems to have rejected totally all the information that has been given to him by the industry at all levels-both international companies and local companies. We are seeing local companies start to vote with their feet; they are starting to go.

The effect of continuing this experiment would be to increase government revenue derived from the petroleum industry-a fact which, of course, is not lost on the Minister-at a time when it is becoming increasingly difficult to attract capital for exploration projects. After what has happened in the last two days, how do honourable members opposite think companies in Australia will go trying to raise risk capital in one of the riskiest businesses in the world to explore for oil in Australia? Why does not the Minister stand up and tell us how he will answer that question? He just cannot answer it. But here is the Government putting in place a tax today. This is government gone mad, acting on inopportune and short term advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a tax.
—Where will the honourable member be in 1992 when we have to pay out $3.2 billion to import 60 per cent of our oil requirements?
—I will be on this side of the House.
—I will tell the honourable member: when the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) gets up he will tell us about what will happen.
—Oh, we have heard his speech so many times.

—There is nothing in the legislation to indicate that the ambit of cash bidding will in future be limited to the existing areas. That is an important point. Cash bidding originally was for off-shore exploration. As I understand this legislation-and I would like the Minister to respond to this-cash bidding will now be able to be applied to any exploration in Australia. Should the legislation pass, what is to stop the Government extending the process of cash bidding to all areas of exploration around Australia? The coalition parties plead with the Government to reconsider, especially in light of the events of the last few days. We plead with the Australian Democrats to be sensible and to stand up as they did in 1985 and say that they reject cash bidding as inappropriate. We ask them to take account of what has happened in the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Canada with regard to cash bidding regimes. They do not work; they act as a disincentive to exploration. We in this country will face a very fundamental problem in about 1992 with a lack of self-sufficiency, a need to import and a consequent cost to our balance of payments. If ever there was a time for us to ensure that we do not add any further burdens to our current account and balance of payments it must be now. Decisions in the oil industry are long term decisions. We must make sensible decisions now. When this legislation was first proposed in 1985 it was a very different climate from the present one. Things have changed. We oppose this legislation and we hope that the Government will see the sense of our arguments and those of the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to speak on the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Legislation Amendment Bill. I always welcome an opportunity to probe the latest developments in the mystery and intrigue that surround the petroleum industry. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) spoke fairly extensively about the cash bidding clause. Cash bidding is one way that the Australian people can receive some compensation for the resources that belong to all Australians. These resources do not belong just to the petrol companies. They do not belong to the multinational oil cartel. They belong to all of us, and why should we not get some money back for them? From the way that members of the Opposition have spoken so far in this debate today one would think that Australia was already owned by Esso Australia Ltd or BP Australia Ltd or any other company in the multinational cartel. It is wrong that we just give away our resources to overseas companies for them to plunder and exploit. Those resources belong to all of us here, and we all should share in the wealth of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unfortunate that the prospector that mines the black gold that is so vital to our day to day existence is able to operate beyond the glare of public scrutiny for so much of the time. A very recent occurrence in Frankston has hardened my resolve to protest once again at the insanity of the industry's crazed pricing structure and the absurd marketing practices that it continues to inflict upon the Australian people. A BMW car was parked in a street in Frankston, and it had on its bumper bar a small sticker which said, `I own the car. Still paying for the petrol'. At the time I chuckled to myself, but clearly the obnoxious policies of the avaricious petroleum industry cartel are no laughing matter. Moreover, the fact that BMWs do not run on the smell of an oily rag is even less amusing. I suspect that the car's owner had placed this succinct adhesive label just above the car's exhaust pipe only a few days after the price of petrol in Melbourne rose overnight by almost 12c a litre. I also believe that the wealthy owner was seeking to show that each and every member of the community is a hostage in the hands of the multinational companies, who care only for the bottom line of their annual reports to their shareholders.

It is my purpose today to ask again: why is the speechless, powerless, abused, inadequate and naive motorist the butt of the oil companies' wheeling and dealing? It is my duty today to ask again: why is the honest, battling and hard-working site owner on the receiving end of the oil companies' taunts and threats? Finally, it is my task to ask again: why is the Government's oil industry policy labelled by the cartel as deficient and one which stunts economic growth? The very fact that the price of a product can rise by 23 per cent overnight is an indictment of an industry that is seriously burdened with inequities and racked with problems. Of course, the Australian oil industry has gone through an intense period of rationalisation in the last few years, and no sector of the industry has been left unscathed in the wake of a profound economic change. However, I do not accept that the appalling plight of the motorist or the many service station operators forced out of business is the result of fair competition. The process of slimming down the number of participants in the industry mirrors more closely the wasting of Mafia mechanics than the healthy run-down of an overpopulated industry.

The rules of the game played by the oil companies are simple: there are none. Australians must humbly scrape and bow to the petrol bowser and its supplier in the increasingly forlorn hope that they will be seen in a benevolent light and granted an affordable tank of petrol. However, before most Australian motorists can reach below their belt to the wallet in their hip pocket, the price of petrol will have skyrocketed to such an extent that cash must usually take a back seat to the credit card, and to the interest rates charged by our banks.

I am enraged to hear the explanations of oil industry representatives as to why these price variations occur. Its spokespersons wrongly categorise all motorists as mugs when they orate the industry's usual fairy tale of a market so competitive that once price variations occur anywhere, the word spreads very rapidly. Their well-worn fantasy that price variations take place because of the interplay of market forces, competition amongst dealers and competition amongst wholesalers is about as monotonous as a worn- out revolving fan belt, or a speech from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). `Collusion' may be a dirty word, but I wonder whether an arrangement exists among the oil companies to allow prices to increase uniformly overnight throughout a city of 3 1/2 million people. Virtually every other commodity in our shops sometimes sells at a discounted price. Invariably one store will sell a product at a much lower price than the other stores. As the market forces come into play, the price of items rises and falls, reflecting the basic independence of shopkeepers and their ability to draw customers. However, it would be ludicrous if all prices rose overnight, at the same time. It appears that our benevolent oil company executives all happen to raise their prices at exactly the same time. Maybe this comes about when business clones are produced by an oil cartel.

So if motorists are the victims of the oil companies' profit assault, spare a thought for the service station proprietors who are the fodder in the big petrol war. The lessees of service stations were once the stalwarts of the petrol retailing industry. Now they are desperate and battered victims who operate Claytons businesses and have their livelihoods manipulated by forces beyond their control. The situation has been particularly torrid during this last winter in Victoria. I know that many more lessees expect to be out of business by Christmas. Tragically, it appears that reindeer will have to pull their sleigh again on Christmas Eve, because these honest and hard-toiling Australians will not have access to the fuel tanks from which they derive their livelihood.

The operators make no bones about where the blame lies. They highlight the unreasonable oil company practice of dumping petrol as the cause of their plight. In some instances oil companies are selling discount petrol to independent operators, thereby forcing their lessees to sacrifice their margins to fight discount wars. A spokesman for the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce recently said:
The oil industry is obliging the retail sector to carry the cost of the manufacturers' fight for the market share.

Of course, the lessees and commission agents, to use the words of one advertising campaign, do more than sell petrol-they also go to the wall. At the same time, the oil companies remain unperturbed and continue to report healthy profit results. Caltex Australia Ltd, for example, recently turned a $28.2m loss into a 1986 $22.1m net profit. Likewise, Shell Australia Ltd, whose business has been so successful, reported a 1986 profit of $45.8m. So the oil industry continues to perpetuate the myth that price competition exists in the market-place. However, this bitter and unfair competition is really greed by another name. The fact that Melbourne service station owners recently voted to picket petroleum refineries if oil companies did not agree to hold negotiations on higher profit margins within a month is a blatant sign that the industry is facing a terrible fate. No individual service station operator has a say; only the multinationals run the petroleum industry. They have taken over the whole lot.

Of course, it is suggested that the vast size of Australia means that ensuring that each and every motorist pays the same price for petrol is a complicated business. I could find this explanation palatable if the price of petrol in Frankston were cheaper than the price in Broome, but it is not. Moreover, I could even accept the protestations that discounting wars are of no benefit to anyone if the share of profit for the service station owners was not becoming smaller, or non-existent. I believe that the multinational oil companies are happy to foster the consumer misconception that service station proprietors are penny pinchers and are pocketing the rewards when petrol prices increase. Sadly, such a stance is not only irresponsible but also it encourages desperation in an industry where common sense, conciliation and calm are urgently needed.

Furthermore, the unfeeling and heavy-handed tactics of the oil companies in painting the service station lessees as the inefficient operators in a free market competition serve to deflect attention from their substantial profits. A recent publication of the Australian Institute of Petroleum entitled Petroleum Gazette and circulated as `an aid to public understanding of the oil industry' attempts to paint the oil industry as the poor cousin of other industries in general. It is a tear jerking journal that vividly describes, no doubt to attract the sympathy of motorists and the faint-hearted, the open wounds that oil companies receive in price wars. The knot in one's gut is wrenched even tighter as the journal goes on to describe how the oil cartel must lick its wounds and assist dealers to maintain a reasonable income. If only I could believe that the sincerity of its words would be matched in its deeds. Perhaps the production of all the tears was intended to fuel the water-powered car that appeared in Brisbane and captured the attention of the Queensland Premier a couple of years ago.

The Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Legislation Amendment Bill proposes a number of amendments that are essential to the effective and efficient administration of the Commonwealth's off-shore petroleum legislation. Clearly, this Bill will not directly alleviate the dire problems facing the motorist and the service station operators within the industry. I suppose it is a little like calling the Royal Automobile Club for assistance when one's car has just been written off around a tree or a pole. The symptoms of the petroleum industry's disorder require a fundamental and much greater solution. However, before a proper prescription for reparation may be written, a proper diagnosis of the ills must be made. Unfortunately, the oil companies litany of misinformation and inappropriate self-image are a major barrier to the petroleum industry attaining a new and better elevated pedestal.

In conclusion, it is possible to make a precis of the hostile and forbidding environment of the oil industry. The retail market-place is all but totally controlled by the major oil companies and the consequences of this are disastrous. Today's motorists face wildly fluctuating prices which are discreetly manipulated by the oil companies. It is not reasonable to expect service station lessees to exist on a shoestring margin of 1.8c a litre during a discount war. It is even more outrageous to believe that oil company rebates during a price war are anything but manifestly inadequate. Truly the glorious age of motoring is in danger of being left in the garage because motorists cannot afford to speculate on the roller-coaster price of petrol. Service station owners have locked their doors because of bankruptcy.

While speaking on this Bill I would like to mention the situation in Iran which will have enormous repercussions on the oil industry if the conflict there escalates any more. I can start in 1979 with the deposing of the Shah of Iran. Slowly but surely since then the heat has been turned up. The United States was involved in selling weapons to Iran as late as 1986 and possibly it is still selling it arms even though Iran is now looked upon as the enemy. Some of the wars the West has fought in the Middle East were to look after the interests of the oil companies-large, privately owned companies, companies that were not owned by the United States, British, French or Dutch governments but by private investors. Of course we all recognise that our economy needs oil but why should taxpayers' money, in the form of the defence forces and equipment, be used to protect the interests of private companies? These companies are not owned by all the people of the United States, all the people of the British Isles or all the people of Holland. The power these companies have over government is beyond the understanding of the average citizen. As a hypothetical situation, imagine the power one would have if one could stop 60 per cent of Australia's oil production by refusing to put a card into the computer that controlled the valves and the flow of oil from Bass Strait. I am certain one would have the ear of any Australian government.

With the collapse of the share market, and if the world goes into a recession or depression, one of the traditional ways some governments get their economy moving again is to be involved in a conflict somewhere. I trust that the oil fields of Iran will not be the trigger or an excuse to stimulate our world-wide economy. One can only hope that the leaders of the major nations of the Western world will think long and hard about this major concern and reach an amicable solution for all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) mentioned many matters for which I have some sympathy. In particular, he referred to the problems associated with service station proprietors. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), said that she has heard Bruce John Goodluck speak before on the petroleum industry. She may have because I have spoken on this industry on many occasions. There are many points which I continually bring out because they need to be heard and we, as parliamentarians, need to take them up. In the lovely city of Canberra the roads are better than the footpaths in Tasmania.
—Very well represented.

—Canberra is a beautiful place. The Minister represents Canberra and I assume that she is doing a good job because she would not be re-elected if she were not. Canberra has called for an inquiry by the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) into the price of petrol. As far as I am concerned, the PSA is one of the real problem areas, the root of the problem. For example, in Canberra in 1983 the price of petrol was 46.3c a litre. In about December 1986, when I did my survey, the price of petrol in Canberra was 55.4c a litre; so it has gone up by about 9c a litre since the Hawke Government came to power. Across the board in Australia it has gone up by an average of 13c a litre in every capital city. The honourable member for Dunkley will say that that figure is fictitious because all of a sudden one can purchase petrol for 51c a litre or 45c a litre. At the moment the supposed retail price in Hobart is between 64c and 67c a litre but one can buy it there for 52c a litre.

SPEECH.PARA: We spend a lot of money on the PSA. I do not want to criticise or knock its Chairman because the PSA always takes it personally when one says something about it. Its job is to fix a maximum wholesale price for petrol in Australia. That is what it is paid to do and that is what it does. We hear about injecting finance into the PSA so that it can look into the prices of commodities, such as a packet of sugar. Great play is made of the fact that it will look into such prices. It fixes a maximum wholesale price for petrol in every capital city. In March 1983 the maximum wholesale price of petrol in Hobart, for example, was 43.85c a litre. Today across the board in Australia it is roughly 50.17c a litre in every capital city. We pay the Prices Surveillance Authority to fix a maximum wholesale price for petrol, but what do we see? We find that in some heavily populated areas of Australia petrol is sold below that price.

The honourable member for Dunkley made a very pertinent point. The dealer, the poor service station proprietor, is the pawn in the game because he is the one who gets all of the blame. When people buy petrol they say, `You have put the price up; you have put the price down'. They are not interested in governments; they are not interested in the PSA; they are not interested in this Parliament. At the point of sale they say to themselves, `Why?'. Somebody in Hobart who is paying 67c a litre for petrol will get the Melbourne Herald and see that the price of petrol in Melbourne is 52c or 53c a litre. Of course he gets upset because his motor vehicle is probably one of his biggest investments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Same speech.

—The Whip remarks that I am saying the same sorts of things. They are hurting his Government because it has not been able to do something. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that when he came to government he would reduce the price of petrol by 3c a litre. He has put it up by 13c a litre. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that it was taxation by stealth at the petrol pump, but what has he done? He has not been able to contain prices. We are now seeing crocodile tears about what is happening to the price of petrol. If the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) wants a serve, he will always get one from me. He is the new member from Hobart-I am from Hobart-and he will last about five minutes. He interrupted me and said, `You have been talking about the price of petrol for 12 years. What have you done about it?'. That is the sort of thing that gets my Irish up-not the Irish blood that the Prime Minister has. I have real Irish blood in me.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member will have an opportunity to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 12.46 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to his statement at a news conference a short time ago that nobody, including the Government, the employers or the Australian Council of Trade Unions, could know the implications for the Australian economy of the recent collapse in the world stock markets and that the Government might have to rejig its approach to wages policy. How does the Minister reconcile that eminently sensible position with claims by the Treasurer as recently as this morning that, notwithstanding the recent collapse in global stock markets, world economic growth would be stronger than forecast in the Budget, Australia's trade and net export performance would not be affected very much and no change in domestic policy settings would be necessary?

—The Treasurer is more than capable of speaking for himself in this place and outside. My statement, which was made on behalf of the Government, simply says that in the light of the movements in the stock markets internationally and in Australia, it is prudent for the Government to put to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the national wage case today that the Commission should postpone the case so that the Government and the parties can assess and clarify as fully as possible the implications of recent developments for wages policy, if there are any such implications. That seems to me to be a prudent position for us to adopt. The Commission agreed with that. There is no problem in reconciling that statement and that action by the Government with anything that the Treasurer has said. The Treasurer was simply making the point that there is not going to be an international recession. Indeed, if the question were directed to the Treasurer, I am sure that he would explain fully why there is no conflict between the two statements.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an unusual announcement to make. I inform the House that we have present in the gallery 15 young Aboriginal cricketers, some of whom will form part of a bicentennial cricket team, which will tour England in 1988 to celebrate 120 years of Aboriginal cricket in Australia. In doing so, the team will play at venues and against the same clubs which fielded teams against the original and successful Aboriginal team in 1868. On behalf of the House, I bid them welcome.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware of concern expressed about the future role of the Australian Research Council (ARC)? Now that the Minister has announced new advisory structures for his Department, will he assure the House and the research community that the Government will recognise the need for independent assessment of research grants and the role of basic research?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Bendigo for his question. I think there has been some misunderstanding of the Government's intentions in relation to the funding of research. The first point I make is that before and during the election campaign the Government undertook to establish the Australian Research Council. We have now decided that that Research Council should be included under the general framework of the new advisory arrangements which we released last week. The establishment of the Australian Research Council flows from recommendations of the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) which, of course, has been looking in great detail at the way in which research and development activities are supported throughout Australia. ASTEC wanted the ARC to support both fundamental research and research which will directly contribute to national economic and social development, to enhance the training of research personnel and to improve the interaction between the higher education research sector and industry and other government research sectors.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government makes a very substantial contribution to this country's research effort. One of the problems in the past has been that in Australia-unlike in many other countries-the commitment from the private sector has not been as great as it might be. Therefore, this is an attempt to ensure that the public and private dollars can lead to the best possible outcome for Australia's research activity. It would be quite wrong to suggest that in this move we were in any way denigrating or undermining the very substantial contribution that fundamental research makes both to the community generally and, more importantly perhaps, to more applied research later on. I do not think there is any essential contradiction between the idea that we should support fundamental research of the highest quality in order that Australia can keep pace with international research developments and the idea that that research effort in our higher education institutions should also be relevant to Australia's social and economic needs.

I conclude on the note that in establishing the Australian Research Council, we have brought together some $67m worth of research and related funds for distribution on the advice of the ARC to ensure that we get the best result out of that very substantial expenditure. However, I point out that even though there has been a transference of some $5m from what previously went to universities through the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to the Australian Research Council-and, indeed, that trend may continue-it is still the case that there is a substantial contribution made to fundamental research effort which goes to the institutions, mainly the universities, through the recurrent funding arrangements of the Commonwealth. In the future I would foresee that there would continue to be substantial support for research coming from that area. As a result of these changes, we will not only continue to support the very high quality research which is carried out in this country, but also add to that by bringing together industry and others who have an interest in these matters to maximise the results.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STOCK MARKET MOVEMENT: DOMESTIC ECONOMIC POLICY

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer whether he adheres to the view expressed yesterday and this morning that no change in domestic economic policy settings is required or will be required consequent upon last Friday's record current account deficit and recent volatile movements in world stock markets.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I answered points about the current account deficit and referred to the fact that the quarterly pattern of the current account was entirely in line with the Budget forecast for a decline in the current account deficit for the year as a whole. Yesterday and this morning I said that the implication in the questions asked of me yesterday was that because there was a sell-off in the stock exchanges of the world we, in a panic-stricken way, had to reset all the domestic macroeconomic settings. I said that we did not see a need for that-that is, we thought that the world would not move into a 1929-type depression and therefore the adjustment we made was quite adequate to shift our current account. I made the more general point that Australia is better equipped now to face whatever comes its way than it has been for a very long time. Certainly in terms of fiscal policy--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me take Opposition members through this. The last time we were this competitive was in 1970. We have had a 10 per cent decline in real unit labour costs. We have reduced the Budget deficit from the 5 per cent of gross domestic product that the Opposition left us to zero. These are three pretty good points for a start. I made the other point this morning that in respect of the wage case my colleague, the Minister for Industrial Relations, would be saying something about that today. I enjoin journalists to see what we said at the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's hearing because the Minister for Industrial Relations and I discussed this yesterday and we thought that putting the view that he put would be prudent in the circumstances. That does not mean that there will be a major change to the settings of economic policy. This idea that when we have a fall in the stock market the Cabinet sits in an emergency session and recasts fiscal policy, monetary policy, wages policy and everything else is the kind of slapdash policy that honourable members opposite used to dish up to us.

—My question is directed to the highly successful Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and concerns the question of chemical residues in Australian export produce. Can the Minister inform the House of the steps that have been taken by the Government to ensure that further residue problems do not occur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and for his close interest in this issue. I address the question in four areas: marketing, activities being undertaken, funding, and commodities other than meat. Because of the testing regime we have put in place Australian produce is moving into all our markets. In Japan and Canada all produce is moving into the market-place. In the United States post-25 May produce is moving freely. Pre-25 May produce, when we increased testing after having first become aware of the problem, is moving in the United States despite import testing, although the produce from plants with a number of violations is yet to undergo testing.

ANSWER.PARA: We believe that the actions we have taken in Australia have brought the situation under control. Those actions include testing. We have taken some 110,000 samples so far. Some 340 properties have been identified as having problems and have been quarantined or have had movement restriction orders placed on them by the State authorities. The industry, the States and the Commonwealth, through the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council, should be in a position in November to recommend areas where more normal activity can resume. In other words, the drive is to get areas cleared to enable concentration of testing in those areas requiring extra surveillance to ensure that there are no problems. The Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council is co-ordinating all policy aspects and the Standing Committee on Agriculture is co-ordinating the regulatory aspects. The State governments have played a significant role in the progress we have made. The other area we are still working on is traceback for sheep. Research is still under way. Traceback procedures for cattle and pigs are now in place.

The Commonwealth has allocated significant funds to assist producers, including $1m to assist in the storage and transportation of recalled, banned chemicals, $0.5m towards testing costs in the United States and publicity in Australia, at least an additional $1m in manpower for the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service over the full year and $5.7m over the next three years for the upgraded national residue survey and the establishment of a national database. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation's annual general meeting will be the place and time for the industry to determine how any industry funding questions are handled. In the interim I have asked my Department to take up with the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories the cost of individual tests to ensure that the industry costs are minimised.

For commodities other than meat the Government is also taking positive steps to ensure that problems do not occur. The Bureau of Rural Science has already participated in an evaluation of dried vine fruits, dairy and fish products as well as a number of other commodities. We are doing this to establish the profile of any potential residue problems. The Bureau is also in the process of evaluating what other chemical groups need to be monitored to ensure that problems do not arise in the future in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the latest forecasts of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) are for a current account deficit of 3.3 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) in the United States compared to 4.6 per cent in Australia? Is it also a fact that the figure for Australia on a current account deficit to GDP ratio in 1987 is the second highest of all the 24 OECD countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that makes much of a point.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members are such an uninformed and crass lot. Let me make the point again that in 1981-82, that is, when the present Opposition was in government-we can put those two facts together-we had a current account deficit at 6 per cent of GDP. It came back temporarily to about 4 1/2 per cent under the weight of the enormous recession the previous Government gave us in 1982-83 which choked off imports. As demand-any demand-was put on the economy and as the terms of trade, in particular, started to slide, our current account exposure opened up. As I said yesterday, since 1984 Germany has had a 30 per cent improvement in its terms of trade and Australia has had a 16 per cent deterioration. It is a fact of life that the breaking of inflation in the Northern Hemisphere has broadly been accomplished by breaking the terms of trade of the primary exporting nations, including Australia. It is under that burden that this Government has had to adjust the economy.

ANSWER.PARA: But instead of having a decent tradable goods sector and a services sector which would take up some of the running when the primary export sector slackened as commodity prices fell, where was our tradable goods sector? It was in the dustbin which the previous Government left it in. Let us recall the views at the time. I recall Mr Stone, now a senator and one of the Opposition's trusted and cherished advisers and colleagues, saying, `What we need are more imports'. Remember the thesis that was being put in the late 1970s?-`What we need is more imports to hold the exchange rate down'.

We got the imports all right. They wiped out or decimated our manufacturing industry and while they were doing that they destroyed the incomes of Australian farmers. That is the legacy the previous Government left with us. It left us with double digit inflation, double digit unemployment and the worst state of competitiveness since the Depression. That has all been restored by this Government's policies. We have taken the current account deficit down from 6 per cent of GDP in 1985-86 to 5 per cent last year and to 4 per cent in prospect for the current year. In other words, the pace of our decline is marked and sharp.

The United States is heading in the opposite direction. At a time when it ought to be pulling its current account down, when it is running huge domestic budget deficits and borrowing money from the rest of the world to fund current consumption, it is also running a massive and growing current account deficit. It is probably the September current account deficit number in the United States which has been part of the trigger for the sell-off in the stock markets around the world. I have never for a moment said that the United States current account deficit is larger now. Of course it is not. It is a statistical fact that it is lower. But the fact is that the policy adjustments in this country have been rapid, ambitious, large in magnitude and high in quality. We have not seen comparable adjustments in the United States.

At a Press conference this morning I made the point that a domestic budget deficit of $200 billion-odd, a growing current account deficit and increasing increments to the capital values of the American stock market was an unsustainable scenario which had to be worked out either by a massive collapse in the United States dollar, by a collapse in the bond markets or by a collapse in the stock market. The collapse has come in the stock market and the United States exchange rate. In other words, the markets will finally eke their result from any administration or country that does not make the adjustments. That is what has happened to us. The markets eked the result when the previous Government never made the adjustments and left it to us.

The question illustrates very clearly and succinctly my point, which is that this country has adjusted and is in better shape now to face whatever comes its way than it was in 1983. If such adjustments were occurring with the same ambition in Germany, the United States and Japan, the world would not be suffering these imbalances--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members must be the only people in the world who think that the imbalance in trade between Japan and the United States and between Germany and the rest of Europe is a laughing matter. So long as they hold those pre-Copernican views they will be as irrelevant as they have been in the last 4 1/2 years.

—I also direct a question to the Treasurer. Is it true that Australia has a lower proportion of public debt to gross domestic product than all but one other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country? Is it true that Finland is the only Western country that has a lower proportion of public debt to gross domestic product than Australia? Is it true, therefore, that the Government's policies in reducing public debt have been very successful?

—The Government sought to reduce the call on Australian savings and public debt by reducing the Budget deficit, and also the rate of growth in servicing that debt by the growth in public debt interest, which has been the fastest growing component of Government budgetary outlays. I would need to check my colleague's assertion about our place in the table in terms of public debt abroad, but I am sure that he would be right in saying that the Commonwealth's debt abroad is relatively small compared with most Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. Indeed, the Commonwealth's debt abroad is far outweighed by the Commonwealth's reserves. If one takes public debt in the broader sense, including Commonwealth and State debt, our State and Commonwealth debt combined is still modestly above the general reserves which the Commonwealth enjoys. It is a fact of life that most of the debt of this country, about 60 per cent of it, is privately held, but of course it is generated by the current account deficit. The way to diminish that indebtedness is to diminish the thing that is pushing the growth of that debt, and that is the current account imbalance. That is what policy is directed towards.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is it a fact that at the end of 1986 the gross foreign debt to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio in the United States of America was around 13 per cent, while in Australia the figure was around 40 per cent? Is it also a fact that even in the relatively favourable international economic environment assumed in the Budget, the Government expects Australia's debt to GDP ratio to continue to worsen in the year ahead?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is like a recital of the Commonwealth Year Book statistics. If the Deputy Leader of the Opposition wishes to pluck questions from the Commonwealth Year Book statistics and have me comment on them, I am quite happy to oblige him.
—Just answer yes or no.

—I do not think the honour- able member would understand that answer. He is back over there in opposition. He is not doing too well, and is enjoying it, I hope. It is a fact of life that countries which run persistent current account deficits increase their exposure to international indebtedness abroad. The very essence of the Government's policy changes have been about diminishing that debt exposure, about pulling down the generator of that debt, which is the current account deficit. I said in the Budget Speech that the current account deficit, even at the level projected, was unsustainable and too high-let me repeat that now-and that it would take some time before we stabilise our debt to GDP ratio, let alone bring it down. I said that in the Budget Speech in Statement No. 2. I have said that in other places and, of course, in Europe since and in North America, and I am happy to repeat it here today.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not quite sure what point the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is seeking to make. If he is saying that the smaller debt to GDP ratio in the United States is a cause of little concern and that the United States should wait until it is in the high thirties before that economy, with its massive GDP, and therefore a high proportion of that massive GDP, puts a call on the rest of the world's savings of gigantic proportions, which it is doing now even at the current debt to GDP ratio, I do not understand the point. The honourable member is saying that the United States debt to GDP ratio, which he says is 13 per cent and which I would need to check, is not much of a worry. But 13 per cent of the huge GDP of the United States as a call on the rest of the world's savings is massive. That is why the world's wealthiest nation cannot continue to be a major debtor nation borrowing from the rest of the world, calling on the savings of the rest of the world to fund its Budget deficit or its current account deficit. I should have thought that was pretty elementary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support aware that the Australian Institute of Criminology has recently released a report entitled Death and injury on the road? Can he say how the report relates to Federal Government road safety initiatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question on this important topic; I know that he has had a long interest in road safety questions. I am aware of the report to which he refers, prepared by the Australian Institute of Criminology. That report, as I understand it, makes a number of proposals which are designed to reduce death and injuries on our roads. These include, I am told, novice driver proposals which are designed to introduce a graduated licensing process, an approach which has previously been supported by the Federal Government; and an extension Australia-wide of high level random breath testing, an initiative also supported by the Federal Government. They also include the targeting of enforcement to better deal with traffic offenders. The Federal Government also supports that initiative in policing practices designed to save lives on the road. Finally, the report suggests the promotion of greater community responsibility concerning the consumption of alcohol in this nation, a recommendation which we also support.

ANSWER.PARA: Much of the report's value lies in the information it contains on research carried out in Australia and overseas, and I would recommend it to the House for that reason. There were in this country 2,883 road fatalities in 1986, a figure lower than for any year between 1964 and 1982. Road fatalities in 1987 to 30 September have fallen to 1,972, and that compares with 2,149 in 1986. I think that demonstrates the good work that is being done in this nation already in relation to road safety. This Government has been playing an important role in that regard and our strategy has consisted of three fundamental elements. The first is to provide safer roads. The second is to ensure safer vehicles, and new certification procedures have been introduced together with the new Australian design rules. The cost of this system is only $5 per vehicle for the compliance plate. The third is research and promotion designed to counter the so-called human factor. The aim of this element of the Government's strategy is to change attitudes and promote responsible road user behaviour. To this end we have implemented a number of highly successful public education campaigns and we are also in the process of preparing a road safety resource package for community groups to assist them in developing their own road safety. This is in marked contrast to what was done under the Fraser Government. This Government has spent in excess of $10m on road safety.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If Opposition members think that road safety is a matter for some amusement, that is for the Australian community to judge. This Government has spent in excess of $10m on road safety, which is in marked contrast to what was done under the Fraser Government. If Opposition members had had their way, they would not have spent a cent on road safety in this nation. Our record is second to none in this matter and the statistics prove it.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Did he receive $19,760 in travelling allowances for the 1986-87 financial year for residing principally in Canberra? Does he still claim travelling allowances on the basis that his home base is Sydney? Does he actually reside with his family in Canberra? What possible justification can he provide for his ongoing rorting of the travel allowance system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one thing about the Opposition in this country: its members can never get out of the gutter. Even when the big issues are on, they never get out of the gutter. Even supposedly the youngest and freshest of them is taking up the mantle. I only say to the honourable member that he should have just checked with his former Leader, Mr Anthony, and with Mr Nixon, and with his current Leader, old Sinkers over there, and asked Sinkers what his travelling allowance is and where he lives.
—You check where I live.
—We know where the right honourable member lives-around here in Deakin, where he has always lived. Or where he says he lives; not where he gets off the plane every Friday night.
—You check where I live.
—Order! I call the Leader of the National Party to order.

—Let us start by making the point that in the last three years the Leader of the National Party has not published his travelling allowance or his place of residence. Before the Leader of the Opposition asks any questions of us, he should publish all of the claims from his front bench.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point I make is that I have claimed 191 days in Canberra, and of course, the corollary of that is that were I to have stated my principle place of residence as being in Canberra, I would have claimed the balance of the year mostly in Sydney. So I would spend 191 days in Canberra and 175 in Sydney, in which case the cost would be about the same.

The third point I make is that I am the Treasurer. I have to be here as much as most Ministers. I have 191 days here, while my colleague Senator Walsh, who enjoys a similar responsibility to mine, was here for 153 days. But the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate-not the Treasurer and not the Minister for Finance-claims $23,500. That is $4,000 more than I claim, and about $8,000 more than Senator Walsh claims. When we come to our total establishment costs, is it not interesting that my costs and those of my staff come to $30,000, but the costs of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, and those of his staff come to $90,000-three times as much. Because he decides to drag his staff around like a travelling gypsy caravan, to suit his own express convenience, his staff costs-listen to this--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are rorting the system.

—No wonder he does not like the answer. My staff costs figure, for an office of 12, is $10,000. It costs $10,000 because I live here and they live here, and they do not trek backwards and forwards to Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I do live most of the time here.
—Order!
—You cheat.
—Order! The House will come to order.
—Of course I live here.
—Order! The House will come to order. The honourable member for Mackellar will not interject.

—My staff costs come to $10,000 for 12 people, because they reside in Canberra. For 18 staff, the staff costs of the Leader of the Opposition costs are $77,000. What he is enjoining me to do, as the principal economic Minister in the Government, is to treble my costs to his level. So instead of having establishment costs of $30,000 for me and my staff, he would prefer the cost to be $90,000, which is the cost for him and his staff.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that this is a phoney, fallacious and dishonest issue which the Opposition has run so dishonestly. It had its little mate Tony Street claiming 320 days living on the south coast of Victoria. The last time the Leader of the National Party put anything on record, he had not 190 days in Canberra but 290 days. He cheated and rorted the system year in and year out. He even got to the stage that during his annual holidays he changed the place of residence back to his farm so that he could claim it through the holidays. That is the truth. They are the things the Opposition is up to. I make no apologies for my position. I never have and never will. My principal place of residence is the one property I own in Sydney. I live here to do this job as Treasurer--

TALK.START.PARA: —So you live here. That is exactly the point.

—I see Sinkers every Friday night on the plane, so I take it that he does too. The fact is that if I were not claiming 190 days here, the balance, taking 190 from 360, would be claimed for the days spent in Sydney, or that part of the time which is not part of my annual holidays. Here we have the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate claiming $23,500. Senator Walsh, who also lives in Perth and who is a senior Minister, claims $16,500.
—But he lives in Perth.

—So does Senator Walsh. He claims $16,500 and Chaney claims $23,500. Chaney's staff costs are almost as large as those of the Leader of the Opposition. He claims $31,000. So Senator Chaney's total establishment costs are $54,000; those of the Leader of the Opposition are $93,000; and mine are $30,000. I thought that those mathematics would penetrate even the mind of the Leader of the Opposition-$90,000 to $30,000 should make some impact even on him.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, the Leader of the Opposition demeaned himself in the election campaign by even raising this matter in his principal, campaign-opening speech. As a result of the way he behaved during the campaign, and the standard of his behaviour in the last Parliament, he was slapped in the mouth by the Australian public and put back into opposition. He is looking for another slap in the mouth from the Australian public, which it will give him for his small-mindedness and his dishonesty.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer: Is he concerned that comments being made in an attempt to talk down the Australian economy by a small political minority for political gain, could cause serious damage to Australia as a whole and to the majority of Australian citizens?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to say that since the election, particularly since the very clear result in the election, which clarified the state of the parties and who governs this place, and with the presentation of the Budget, there has been a substantial turnaround in sentiment, particularly business and investment sentiment, towards Australia. At the meeting of the Metal Trades Industry Association the other night, which I attended with colleagues from both sides of the House, we were told of investments being made which indicated an exceeding of the official expectations in the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: It ill becomes any group to try to talk down its economy or its nation for its political gain. It helps nobody to pull the economy or the country into disrepute when such a fundamental and important transition in the economy is occurring and, of course, at a time when Australia has had a big collapse in its terms of trade and growth in its current account deficit. I can only say that I think the Australian community generally is responding well to the changes which the Government has brought in.
