The spirit of enterprise and initiative which is being shown by Australian business, and the co-operation and restraint being shown by the Australian work force, is a sign of the genuine maturity that we saw in the election campaign when the community rejected the outrageous financial bribe offered by the Opposition and took the sober policies of the Government, which are to continue to see this fundamental transition occur in the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer him to his latest examples of self-congratulation about the state of the economy and of the fault for the state of the Australian economy resting in the hands of those overseas. I ask him whether it is a fact that when his Government came to power the gross foreign debt to gross domestic product ratio in Australia was 21 per cent and that it has soared to 41 per cent under his stewardship?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should have thought that anybody who had been Treasurer of this country and who had left this economy so debilitated would be so embarrassed to ask such a question that he would hardly manage to stand on his feet and put the question across. The fact is that it was a succession of coalition governments that told us, `Don't worry about it. Commodities will rescue us. Commodities are all we need. Just find another mineral deposit and dig it up; the Japanese will come and buy it and you will need to do nothing else. Don't worry about your intellectual product. Don't worry about the intellectual growth within the economy. Let your education system slide. Don't worry about your services sector'. That was the structure that was left to us.

ANSWER.PARA: The growth in the current account deficit, as illustrated by that 6 per cent of gross domestic product in 1981-82-in other words, when the rot started to set in-was when the big buildup of debt started. When commodities let us down in 1986, it showed the bankruptcy of 30 years of coalition government. That is why members of the Opposition are so on the nose with Australian business. That is why they are so on the nose with the financial markets around the world. They kept the economy closed, protected and regulated. They managed an over-valued exchange rate and they smothered financial markets. Now they are running around with a grab bag fiscal policy which they know would only bankrupt their country. That is why the Opposition does not cut any ice in the financial markets of the rest of the world. That is why in the major business councils of this country it has no support and that is why it is sitting in opposition without a policy, without structure, without leadership and without any guts. Until the Opposition decides that it has to join the rest of us in responsible policy rather than trying to make cheap, synthetic and transparent points of the kind made by implication in this question, then, and only then, will it start to look like an alternative government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of the attack, at the recent Australia-Japan trade conference, on the standard of Australian tourism facilities, to the effect that the Australian tourism industry would have to pull its socks up or hand over some facilities to the Japanese, particularly duty free souvenir shops and accommodation facilities? Will the Minister inform the House of the Government's response to this criticism, which even some Australian entrepreneurs admit has some validity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Capricornia for his question. I did see that report of statements made at the Australia-Japan trade conference in Perth yesterday. Unfortunately, some of those comments would quite obviously be correct. I think the Commonwealth has done its job in attracting tourists to Australia. It then becomes the responsibility of hoteliers, developers and State tourist commissioners to make sure that the Japanese are made to feel happy. It is true that there are certain hotel properties in Australia which do not supply baths in the rooms, which, of course, does not please the Japanese. There is a shortage of Japanese language signs in some places in Australia, notably airports-something about which I have been talking to State governments for some years but without too much success. I can assure members of this House that there will be a great increase in the number of Japanese language signs evident in the Australian Capital Territory in the very near future.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also true that shopping hours are not necessarily suitable to Japanese tastes. It is fair to say that in the last month I have appointed a committee of very responsible people, headed by Mr Bevan Bradbury, the former Chief Executive of Coles Myer Ltd, to hold an inquiry into the exact situation of shopping hours in Australia. As I understand it, we may be on the brink of a breakthrough in terms of the extension of shopping hours in Australia.

Quite obviously, Australia's success in attracting Japanese tourists is the envy of the world. It is very obvious that we will have one million Japanese tourists by the end of this century. In August 1987 we doubled the number of Japanese tourists to Australia in August 1986, so obviously we are doing something right. But that does not necessarily mean that our product is perfect; it is not. Unless everybody associated with this industry takes the opportunity to provide the facilities to keep Japanese coming here, the industry will go off the boil. Given the nature of entrepreneurs in Australia, particularly hoteliers, I am pretty sure we will do something about it.

Of course, the other shortage is in our capacity to have Japanese speaking people in hotels. One night this week I stayed in Melbourne at one of the leading hotels in Australia and I was very disappointed to find a Japanese customer unable to have his conversation understood by the young lady at the counter who was serving him. Although she was serving him with great graciousness, she certainly had no knowledge of the Japanese language. I rang the hotel the next day to complain about that and I think it will make some efforts to make sure that there are Japanese speaking people on the counter at all times, as well there should be. We are certainly on the threshold of an enormous advantage over the rest of the world in attracting Japanese tourists. If we do not grasp the opportunity while it is there, it will be a great loss not only to this country but also to those entrepreneurs and hoteliers who at this stage are not doing exactly what they should.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Prime Minister. Since the proposed bans by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) against Fiji, announced by Mr Crean, are directly contrary to the Government's decision not to impose economic sanctions against Fiji, will the Acting Prime Minister advise the House whether Mr Crean has been contacted and told that the bans must not be put into effect? If so, what was Mr Crean's answer? If he has not been contacted, how does the Government justify inaction on such a serious threat to Australia's foreign policy and to Australia's trade with Fiji?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have spoken to Simon Crean about this matter on two occasions in the last few days. Of course, I have expressed the concern of the Government should the Australian Council of Trade Unions proceed with bans, as it has proposed. However, it has been pointed out that the actions of the self-declared Government in Fiji against the trade union movement in Fiji have been extremely provocative. Should those actions which have been taken in Fiji be withdrawn, the proposed sanctions of the ACTU would then be reconsidered.
—Who's running the country?

—Well, wait a minute. The honourable member asked me whether I had spoken to Mr Crean. I am telling him what Mr Crean said. I have not told him what I said. The Leader of the Opposition should not be such a gormless fellow. That is a problem a lot of those on the other side of the House have. There is a pregnant pause while they look for the dictionary.

ANSWER.PARA: We have registered our concern very firmly. Our opposition to those sanctions has been expressed on a number of occasions, and will continue to be expressed. I will continue to make very strong representations to the trade union movement to withdraw the sanctions. The Minister for Industrial Relations has also been associated with this matter.

I conclude by saying that, if it is a simple matter to get rid of an industrial dispute by some fiat or declaration of determined intent on the part of a government, perhaps the Leader of the Opposition and his colleagues can explain why there was such a deplorable record of industrial disputation in this country during the period when they were in government. That level has been greatly reduced by a much more sensible approach to the trade union movement in seeking co-operation in a range of areas and, in particular in problem areas like this, seeking to persuade them and to apply productive pressure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—In an article in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald, `Hold on to your pants and wait for New York, says MP', Mr Milton Cockburn has made a number of misrepresentations concerning me. He said that when in the party room the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) announced that the Australian stock market had fallen 400 points, I rushed for the door. This is simply untrue. Moreover, it implies that I left the party room because I was concerned with my investments in the Australian share market. This is equally untrue. In fact, I left because I thought the news to be important and wished to find out more. No item of business involving my portfolio area was listed on the party room agenda. My Australian shareholdings are, and have been for some considerable time, negligible. My total investments in the Australian share market, held either personally or by companies of which I am a director, amounted to 2,100 shares in Debex Ltd, valued as at 16 October at $1.30 each, and 3,000 shares in Gold and Copper Exploration valued at the same date at 28c each, with a total worth at that time of approximately $3,570. No changes have been made in those investments since last Friday, nor have I, or any company of which I am a director, made any other investments in the Australian share market since last Friday.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Cockburn also said that I am a director of a number of investment companies. In the context, the implication is that these are important investment companies with significant holdings in the Australian share market. He did not raise either of these matters with me when he spoke with me yesterday and has clumsily misrepresented what appears in my statement of members' interests in which I disclosed my directorships in companies which I described explicitly as trustee companies or as family holding companies. That is precisely what they are. Moreover, these companies do not hold shares in the Australian share market, save for one which holds the shares in Gold and Copper Exploration to which I have referred.

Mr Cockburn said that after leaving the party room I was recalled later to it. This is literally correct. However, in the context, the implication which suggests itself is that I was engaged in checking on my investments in the Australian market. I was not; I was recalled from my own room where I was working. Mr Cockburn also described me as a prominent investor in the stock market. In the context, the clear implication is that I am a prominent investor in the Australian stock market. As I have made clear, my investments in the Australian share market are negligible. Furthermore, I have never described myself as, nor would I ever describe myself as, a prominent investor in any stock market.
As my statement of interests discloses, I hold investments in some overseas shares. It is no doubt in respect of these investments that Mr Cockburn alleges that I said:
. . . when the new Register of Members' Interests was tabled soon we would find things were not as bad for him as they might have appeared when the last Register was tabled.

I did not say or suggest that things were in any way bad for me. The conversation with Mr Cockburn was of a jocular nature. My reference to changes in holdings and that he should wait for the new statement of members interests was described by Mr Cockburn himself as `a tease'. The overwhelming, and in my view, defamatory implication underlying this series of gross and unprofessional misrepresentations is that I put my personal affairs before my parliamentary work. As I have made clear, this is entirely untrue.
