PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.

Your petitioners therefore request the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to: Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlay destructive experimentations on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron,Mr Cobb,Mr Cross,Mr Free,Mr Gayler,Mr Katter,Mr Lee,Mr Millar,Mr Moore and Mr Sciacca.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of food irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Kent,Mr Milton,Mr Reith and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Burr,Mr Ruddock and Dr Woods.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern:
About the evil caused by the fact that x-rated videos with their depiction of unnatural sex and often horrible violence, are allowed to circulate around Australia from Canberra.
And your petitioners, therefore humbly pray that such circulation be prevented.
The laws regarding obscenity in the media should also be revived and enforced.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Free,Mr Ruddock and Mr Uren.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available, it will not tackle tax and social security fraud in the most cost-efficient and effective manner.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cobb,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Sharp and Mr Webster.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Lyne Electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian Legislation ever, and that on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-effective manner tax and social security fraud.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject Labor's ID card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government has no mandate to introduce its flawed and costly ID card proposal and that the card won't stop tax and welfare fraud and will invade the private lives of Australians.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject Labor's ID card proposal as the Australian public haven't given the Government a mandate to introduce it.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory Identity Card should be reconsidered and rejected because the proposal:
(a) is not a cost effective method of reducing tax evasion and Social Security fraud, and to the contrary, in the form proposed, will facilitate such evasion and fraud;
(b) will constitute an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy by the aggregation of a wide variety of personal information of a private matter;
(c) will cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on the tax payer;
(d) cannot be guaranteed against misuse for purposes other than for which the introduction is stated to be intended.
And your petitioners humbly pray that the problems which Identity Cards are intended to reduce should be attacked by other, more effective methods.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cobb,Mr Hicks,Mr Hunt and Mr Reith.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Downer and Dr Woods.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

Any proposals to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs gravely concern ex-servicemen, ex-servicewomen and their families because they renege on clear and unequivocal commitments from various Commonwealth Governments to properly care for Australia's veterans.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Ensure that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continues to exist as a separate and distinct Department of State servicing the needs of veterans and their families.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the proposed introduction of compulsory identification cards should not be considered any further, and in the event of it coming again before parliament it should be rejected because:
We do not accept the concept of and ID card as necessary to control social security fraud or tax evasion.

It would be an unwarranted infringement of individual privacy and our democratic society, in particular because it being required to work, operate a bank account, enter hospital or enter into any transaction.
It would cause a further large and costly growth in the bureaucracy and burden on tax payers.
It cannot be guaranteed that the aggregated private information would not be misused for other purposes.
The people of Australia should be fully informed and consulted in a referendum before legislation for any such change with such wide-ranging effect is considered, and
We call upon the Government to cease immediately any endeavour to introduce this invasion upon our lives.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cobb and Mr Sharp.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
That we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr MacKellar and Mr Porter.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The Humble Petition of certain Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The Government by persisting with the Australia Card Bill has wilfully rejected the advice and recommendations of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia's ``Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card'' which unequivocally rejected the Government's proposal in these words:

``The majority believes the creation of a new bureaucracy of 2000 public servants within the HIC [Health Insurance Commission], with the sole task of identifying every man, woman and child in Australia, is a wasteful exercise which will not address the problems of tax evasion and social security fraud but will provide the mechanism by which the very fabric of our society will be irreversibly altered, opening the way for the greatest attack on the privacy of individuals as the `Identity Bureau' identifies, monitors, and updates information on every person in Australia.'' (Report, 4.55, page 148)

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government now withdraw the Bill as being contrary to the Common Law and traditional freedoms we have hitherto enjoyed in Australia, and should the Bill be nevertheless re-introduced, that the Members of the House without regard for party should unanimously reject the Australia Card Bill as being contrary to our personal liberties and the national interest.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Prosser and Mr Saunderson.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: We, the undersigned are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1.-its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2.-its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3.-its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4.-in that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their business and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefit Tax Legislation forthwith.
Your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
The Federal Government has done nothing to ease concerns that it will support Telecom's plans to introduce timed charges for local calls; and
Call upon the Government to undertake that such plans will not be implemented.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
Make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
Close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X-rated videos, (and ER) and END the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia Connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X-rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and its availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography pedlars are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Because anyone can have these tapes in their possession for private use.
Because the Government does not intervene in that.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Disabled Students
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that we, the undersigned support the need for Government Funding to enable the continuation of the Naranga Work Education Centre and the Nepean Education and Vocation Centre, both of which cater for students with disabilities and are based at the Frankston College of T.A.F.E.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned do respectfully showeth that pornographic material relating to children is deleterious to the health and welfare of children and society as a whole.
We respectfully urge the Government to ban all child pornography from entering or from being produced in Australia.
And your petitioners in duty-bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the United States Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change in any way the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card.

We consider that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.
We therefore ask the House to take action to prevent the implementation of this legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Social Security Offices
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth (closure of social security offices at Corrimal, Warrawong & Dapto)
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will (keep said offices open with full services as at present 21 August 1987)
And your petitioners as duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to show restraint with equity.

In particular, the decision to defer the November pension adjustments has resulted in a loss of $25.62 for a single pensioner and $21.36 for each married pensioner. The prospect of a further deferral of the May adjustment will result in the loss of another $35.10 for a single pensioner and $29.10 for each married pensioner.

When you are scrimping to make ends meet, as is the case with many pensioners, you can't afford such a cut in living standards. Pensioners are looking for a new deal from politicians-more of the same is not good enough!
Your petitioners request an immediate return to payment of May and November C.P.I. increases, and as is duty bound will ever pray the Government grant this request now.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectively sheweth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action nor permit any action to be taken to make any change without the approval of the Australian people by referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wealth Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully:

Condemn the Hawke Labor Government's high tax policies and state our total opposition to the introduction of any new taxes including a wealth tax on the net wealth of individual Australians and Australian business.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Not introduce an investment destroying wealth tax into the House of Representatives.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Industrial Relations Bill will increase industrial disputation, bankrupt companies, and give the union movement total and absolute power over the Australian community.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject Labor's Industrial Relations Bill to save Australia from the actions of militant unions and give our economy a chance of recovering.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Murray electorate respectfully showeth that:
The August 1st changes to Medicare Benefit rebates are unfair to patients, such as those with chronic disabilities requiring consultant physician or after hours consultations.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Amend the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act to restore the original rebates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The vulnerability of the Australian economy because of the sheer size of our foreign debt burden and the seemingly intractable deficit in the current account of the balance of payments.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The editorial in today's Australian newspaper is just another indication of the growing numbers of people who are joining the Opposition in its criticism of the Government's risky economic strategy. Honourable members will know that, since I took the position of Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I have been stressing the need for this Government to force the pace of adjustment of Australian economic policies. Indeed, I will show honourable members, through a reading of the editorial in today's Australian, just how it fits with what honourable members will recall having been said in this Parliament. I will quote only elements of the editorial:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the sheer size of our foreign debt burden and the seemingly intractable deficit in the current account of the balance of payments make Australia one of the most vulnerable economies in the Western world.
After talking about how vulnerable we are it goes on to say:
But the fact remains the pace of adjustment has been too slow and, it now appears, dangerously so.
It continues:

The Government's own economic forecasts suggest only a modest improvement in the current account of the balance of payments this financial year. For this it has rewarded itself with lower interest rates as the Reserve Bank prints more money, raising the risk that the current account could even deteriorate.

These are precisely the points that the Opposition has been making. We in Australia are vulnerable because the Government will not force the pace of adjustment. The key question is: Why is Australia one of the most vulnerable countries in the Western world? Why after four years has the Government failed to put Australia's economic house in order? This Government's deficits-the disastrous Keating deficits-swallowed Australia's domestic savings and forced us as a nation to borrow overseas and run up a huge foreign debt. In other words, with these early Budgets and the large deficit, the rot was already setting in before the decline in our terms of trade in 1985. I mention that because the decline in our terms of trade was not, as the Government has argued, the cause of our external problems; it simply exacerbated an already serious situation.

The failure of the Government to bite the bullet on government expenditure-that is, to reduce public sector demand-is one of the major reasons why Australia is, as the Australian puts it today and as we have been saying, `one of the most vulnerable economies in the Western world'. The other major reason, of course, is wages policy. Year in and year out the Government's wages policy delivers nominal wage increases well in excess of productivity. It is all very well for the Government-in particular, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-to say that some adjustment to fiscal and wages policy is taking place. That is hardly the point. The point is that the Government should abandon its high risk, slow adjustment economic strategy, especially in view of the increased danger of the economy being subject to adverse shocks from overseas. This is the current economic debate.

If one were to listen to the Treasurer day after day one might think that the debate is about what the previous Government under Malcolm Fraser did, what it was like in those days and what this Government has done. Honourable members opposite do not address the contemporary issue and that is why more and more people are endorsing our call for a forcing of the pace of adjustment. This is the issue raised by members of the Opposition; it is the issue raised by the colleague of those opposite, Senator Peter Walsh, the Minister for Finance. It has been raised by the editorial in the Australian. And those honourable members opposite who listened to AM this morning on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation would have heard the issue raised by Allan Wood of Syntec International. There have been others; one could go on. A groundswell of opinion has been coming in to endorse what we have been saying.

But yesterday the Treasurer demonstrated that he has completely missed the point of the current economic debate. He rambled on. We heard him again at Question Time today. He either rambles on in an incoherent manner or he seeks to dump it on people personally. He cannot or will not address the economic issue of the day. He is completely missing the point about the current economic debate. He rambles on about the past performances of governments. That is on the record for everyone to see. He reaffirmed his right to comment on the United States economy. Of course he has a right to comment on the United States economy. But let him do it from a position of credibility. This applies also to his comments about the United Kingdom.

I would like to get to the substance of the matter. The Treasurer is very critical of other countries' abilities to adjust their economic policy. They should, he claims, take a leaf from Australia's book. The clear implication of the Treasurer's remarks is that the disruption on the world's stock markets is due in part to the failure of other governments' policies, the failure of the international monetary system and the management of exchange rates. Of course, the Australian Government is not to be blamed for any adverse impact of a disruption to world trade and the Australian economy! Well, the fact is that the Australian Government can be criticised for not adopting a faster pace of adjustment on fiscal and wages policy to ensure that we can weather any storm in the world economy. As we stated at the time of the Budget, the Government has been following an incredibly risky, indeed irresponsible, policy. It failed to reduce the vulnerability of the Australian economy. Instead, it presided over, for example, a quadrupling of our net foreign debt.

Furthermore, how does Australia's economic situation-that is, Australia's vulnerability-measure up against that of the United States? I could do a comparison with Argentina. Senator Walsh asks us so to do. That is obvious. But I have chosen the country the Treasurer seeks to lecture, the United States of America. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development forecasts the United States current account deficit as a percentage of gross domestic product at 3.3 per cent, compared with 4.6 per cent for Australia for 1987. In 1986, the gross external debt for the United States as a percentage of gross domestic product, as I mentioned at Question Time, amounted to nearly 13 per cent. In Australia it was around 40 per cent-some difference. Furthermore, the Treasurer's criticism of wages policy in the United States appears well wide of the mark. It is difficult to sustain the criticism of the alleged inflexibility of the relatively decentralised wages policy in the United States while claiming that Australia has had apparent success with its centralised system. The fact is that the United States wages policy has delivered an annual average rate of wage and price inflation of about 3.3 per cent over the 1983-86 period. In contrast, in Australia wages and prices have grown at an annual average rate in the neighbourhood of 7 per cent. Based on data published by the International Monetary Fund, average hourly earnings in manufacturing in the United States grew at 10 per cent from 1983 to 1986 while over the same period average weekly earnings in Australia grew by 25 per cent.

We can go on. On the prices front, consumer prices in the United States grew by 10 per cent, compared with 21 per cent in Australia. There is comparison after comparison. We can look at the criticism made of the United Kingdom. It was interesting to hear the Treasurer focus on the monetary aggregates in the United Kingdom. In Australia the rate of growth of monetary aggregates has accelerated, by and large, for the past six months or so. For the 12 months to July 1987, M3 grew by 13.6 per cent, while broad money supply rose by over 11 per cent. Indeed, the recent acceleration in monetary aggregates in Australia, coupled with a projected growth of 6.5 per cent in average weekly earnings, casts doubt on the Government's forecast of an increase in prices of only 6 per cent during 1987-88.

The point, therefore, is: what will the Government do now, and what will the Government do for the future, to make Australia less vulnerable to changes in the world economy? What is the Government doing with its fiscal policy? Is there just a continuation of the same complacency shown in the last Budget, which was a nibble here and a nibble there, leading to a cut of 1.2 per cent in outlays in real terms, or will the Government really start to wind back public sector expenditure? Yesterday the Treasurer asked what the Opposition could cut. As we have said, we could consider first Senator Walsh's nominated list of projects. But of course, his demand is that the Government do that first. On top of that, we could add in many of the expenditure cuts outlined during our last election campaign. We outlined savings from Medicare, the supporting parent's benefit, changes in the unemployment benefit and the abolition of commissions and quangos and so on. That is what we would do. We would cut government outlays, as we have said, by several percentage points of gross domestic product to fund tax cuts.

But let us hear again what this Government is going to do. We can depend on getting obfuscation and abuse from this Government and this Treasurer, and we will hear it again from the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Holding), this inadequate man who supports the current Treasurer, when he responds today. They want to dump it on a previous government, which is not relevant today, and say how good they are. Then, if it appears that someone has greater ability than the present incumbent, they will seek to use some form of jargon. They will never tell the Australian people what they are going to do to prise us out of the difficulties they have got us into. Where is their expenditure cutting program? How will they release resources from the public sector for use in the private sector? The Treasurer does not have an answer, so it is not surprising that he is not in the House to participate in this debate. The Government is quite prepared to continue with business as usual with a huge government sector. So much for cutting government expenditure.

The same applies to the Government's wages policy. Earlier this year the Government negotiated an increase in average weekly earnings of 6.5 per cent for the third year in a row. Now it is telling us it will not support the Australian Council of Trade Unions today, and it has submitted to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that what was being profferred ought to be postponed because of the current circumstances. What will the Government tell us next week, or later when the case comes up? The question can yet again be asked: What is the Government doing? How is it going to respond to the current situation in which Australia is one of the most vulnerable economies in the Western world? Will it just continue, as I say, with business as usual, where wage increases and to a large extent inflation are politically negotiated variables set with barely passing reference to our position in the world economy? The Government has the opportunity at least to start to put Australia's wage-price situation in order at the current national wage case. That case has been deferred, and correctly so. On top of that deferral, the Government will have another opportunity when the national wage case is heard next year to set up a wages policy for 1988-89.

The fact is that this Government reeks of complacency. It has brought down a complacent Budget for 1987-88, it negotiated a complacent wages package earlier this year and it has been complacent about the recent growth in monetary aggregates. Now, as the debate on the pace of adjustment takes off in the face of the possibility of shocks to the world economy, the Government's attitude is `She'll be right', or, as the Treasurer says, `Don't waste my time. I have no time to talk to you; I have no time to talk to the Australian people. I will talk to the money market and the mates who look after me on my pig killing holidays or who put me up in their apartments while I watch the America's Cup'. It would be interesting to know whether the old travelling allowance was picked up then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on.

—The honourable member should not show so much concern on his face. These guys opposite dump it on people on this side day after day, and have done so for years. The first time we give it back to them, they squeal. They are the most gutless bunch of hypocrites I have seen in this place. They squeal that it is the system that is wrong and that it is the Opposition that is crook. They cannot defend their own inadequacies and they cannot proffer what they are going to do on the economic front. We are saying to the Government: `Debate the pace of adjustment; tell us the changes you are going to make on fiscal policy and on wages policy'. But the Government runs away from that all the time. The same old song will come today from the inadequate Minister Assisting the Treasurer-`Don't waste my time'.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, the Government has peddled the lie that it has fixed macroeconomic policy. The problem is that now, nobody believes it. It says it will set out on microeconomic issues, but it has deferred that. It cannot explain privatisation even to its own Party. The labour market is crying out for reform. There is a crying need for deregulation, and also a need to adjust macro- economic policies. It is not good enough for the Government to say it has fixed it; it has not. As the Australian newspaper says, the Government has put us in a most vulnerable position. Instead of playing with the issue it should proffer its policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOLDING
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —It ill becomes any member of the Opposition to come into this House and accuse the Government, to use the words of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), of never telling the Australian people what it is going to do. That is what he said. Less than four months ago the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was locked into the leadership of the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who was promising the Australian people massive tax cuts on the one hand while, on the other hand, promising massive cuts in the revenue. But he said to the Australian people, `Don't ask us what cuts we are going to make; don't ask us where we are going to make them, whether they will be in education, social welfare or defence, because we would not want to upset you'. The Opposition got its answer from the Australian people then, and it was the answer it deserved to get. The people were not going to be conned once again by the Opposition's phoney fistful of dollars economic bait.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened since then? There has been a certain amount of shuffling on the other side. The once Leader of the Opposition has become the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, and I will say this for the honourable gentleman: he has desperately tried to achieve some level of learning in terms of economic reality. He has picked up a couple of new buzz words-he is pretty excited about them-and they are `the pace of adjustment'. I say to the Deputy Leader that he cannot learn it all at once. Just imagine his excitement this morning when he picked up the Australian newspaper and, goodness me, it too had heard about the pace of adjustment. So with excitement, and indeed some trepidation, he came into the House to tell us that the real accusation against the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is that he is not forcing the pace of adjustment.

What does the Deputy Leader of the Opposition have to say about this? What is the presumption in his argument? The terms of his matter of public importance refer to the current account deficit. As the Treasurer has said in Parliament today, and as he said when he introduced the Budget and subsequent to that, the current account deficit is too high. There is no argument about that. Indeed, the Treasurer himself confirmed that today, so there is no argument between the honourable gentlemen opposite and us that the current account deficit is too high. What the argument is about is how it is reduced. That is not just a matter of putting together a glib phrase such as `increasing the pace of adjustment'; it is about producing a total economic strategy, a total economic philosophy.

I say this for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition: he realised the weaknesses in the policies put by his former Leader. Within a few weeks of being given the responsibilities of shadow Treasurer he indicated his concern to take the policies of the Opposition in another direction, and well he might. I commend him for that because there was a level of reality in it. His problem was that the Leader of the Opposition has since confirmed the same old philosophy, the same old economic jargon.

When all of this jargon is stripped away, what the Opposition said yesterday and what the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) is saying today is that we have a debt problem and we must fix it. There is no argument about that but implicit in the criticism of the honourable gentleman opposite is that what the Opposition proposes is somehow or other an alternative and better solution.

The first point that has to be made is that over the past two years the Australian economy has been adjusting rapidly and consistently to our terms of trade collapse. Through the process of the accord we have unwound wage indexation and put in its place a two-tier system which better equates reward with productivity and performance. We have done this in a climate of business and union co-operation and in the context of further declines in industry disputation. In the year ahead we expect to achieve a further fall in real unit labor costs following successive declines in each of the years since the Government's election in 1983. The most important point is that we have achieved these policy and labour costs without acrimony or bitterness but with co-operation.

In 1987-88 we will not only continue to secure competitive wage outcomes but also make major inroads into those restrictive work and management practices which have for far too long held Australia back. This prospect and the results already achieved to date were positively acknowledged as recently as two days ago, in the presence of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, by both the outgoing President and the new President of the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia, in Canberra. That was referred to by the Treasurer in the House today. There was a very strong endorsement of that aspect of our wages policy from industry. It is all very well for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to say today, `Let us go back to the days when we had confrontation at almost every level of our industrial life'. It was partly that confrontation which got Australia into the mess it was in when we came to government.

The other weapon in our adjustment armoury has been fiscal policy. Under a Labor government the level of Commonwealth spending has been cut significantly. It is just as well that the Leader of the Opposition is not present because he and other honourable gentlemen opposite have to be reminded-admittedly, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition had other responsibilities at that time-that when the Leader of the Opposition left office he left Australia with a deficit of nearly $10 billion. He left us in an economic mess. In 1983-84 spending amounted to 29.3 per cent of our gross domestic product (GDP). In this Budget that figure has been slashed to 26.8 per cent and the Budget has been balanced. This Government has consistently brought down the deficit since its election. In 1983-84 it was 4.1 per cent of GDP; in 1984-85 it was 3.1 per cent of GDP; in 1985-86 it was 2.4 per cent of GDP; in 1986-87 it was one per cent of GDP and in the year ahead it will be zero.

In terms of total public sector borrowing, we have cut the public sector's requirement for domestic and national savings from the Leader of the Opposition's 8 per cent of GDP to 2.4 per cent for 1987-88. These budgetary changes and this level of discipline over the States amounts to the most radical shift in fiscal policy of any Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country. That fact has been widely and freely acknowledged in Australia and by international financial analysts and other governments. It is merely churlish and childish of the Opposition to deny this economic reality.

As a result of these successes on the wages and budgetary fronts, and because of a general improved outlook for our trade performance, monetary conditions in Australia have eased by a significant amount over the past 12 months. Ninety-day bank bills have fallen by nearly 7 per cent in the past year, prime lending rates have fallen substantially and, much to the despair of the Opposition, home loan rates have eased as well. However, the Government acknowledges quite freely that the overwhelming challenge facing Australia is to reduce our dependence on debt by trading out of our current account deficit. We, as a government, have been honest and open about this matter since commodity prices fell disastrously during 1985-86.

We have said time and time again that living standards cannot go up but must come down if our export earnings are being driven down. It was on the basis of our frankness and our direct record in confronting these problems-they were put fairly and honestly to the Australian people-that we were re-elected only three months ago. In the period since the election we have consolidated the policy shifts on which we have campaigned. There is a consistency of approach and an advocation for doing what is right which separates this Government from virtually all honourable members opposite. Most markedly, it is that difference in approach which I think characterises the approach of the Opposition and the Government. The Opposition was defeated in the last election because it did not have a coherent economic policy. It made a series of promises which the average Australian realised, as did every economic analyst, could not be made to work. If there had been any attempt to implement these promises our deficits would have gone through the roof. That is the reality and the Opposition cannot escape that fact.

It is all very well to use buzz words and to talk about forcing the pace of change but the reality is that we were entitled to hear from the honourable gentleman opposite a coherent, alternative, economic strategy and we have not heard it. We will not hear it because the honourable gentleman is still working on it and he is still trying to get his Leader to change his mind. We wish him well in his endeavours to unlock his Party from the hopeless fiscal and economic policies that were produced at the last election. When he succeeds we may hear from him something that sounds like a serious alternative economic strategy. But as long as he is locked into the kind of economic nonsense mouthed by the Leader of the Opposition he, the Treasurer and I know that the honourable gentleman is forced to grab the latest piece of economic jargon that comes out of his advisers to try to argue that this Government is failing, that it is not facing its responsibilities, and to suggest that somehow or other, buried within his head-not in his Leader's head-there is some kind of economic strategy which he will ultimately get out. We hope this will happen because when that occurs we will be in a position to have a serious economic debate and, hopefully, some alternative strategies can be put not merely before the Parliament but before the Australian people. But before that happens the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer have to move their Party to a position in which it is able to tell us what it would do if it were in government. Opposition members cannot say, `Oh well, it is really up to the Minister for Finance; we will rest behind him. After he has told you what he knows we will tell you what we know'.

I am sorry for the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong, because that is simply not good enough. We believe that he is trying to get it right, but we believe that he has real problems in moving both the Leader of the Opposition and some of the right wing economic gurus who back him. It is not an easy task. I want the honourable member to know that we feel for him. I want him to know that we know that he is doing his best. But we are entitled to say to the people of Australia that his best is not good enough when it simply amounts to walking into the Parliament, puffing and panting and using all his rhetorical skills to tell us that what it is all about is forcing the pace of adjustment. He thinks he is lucky because there is an editorial in the Australian which states that that is a good idea. But that is not an alternative economic strategy. The Opposition did not have one before the last election and it does not have one now. This matter of public importance is just one further example of the economic bankruptcy of members of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad commentary on the Hawke Government and its performance as an economic manager that it takes something like a 40 per cent fall in our currency or the largest stock market crash in history to get its attention and to get it to start to think about whether this country is vulnerable in current economic circumstances. Indeed, even yesterday in the House, in the midst of the crash, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was trying to perpetuate the illusion that there was nothing wrong; that everything was turning around; that he had the right policies in place; that he did not need to adjust his policies; that he did not need to change his forecasts. But surely, almost anybody anywhere else in the world could have told him that the chances of a world recession are now a lot greater than they were just a few days ago. However, he was not going to waste his time dealing with those who questioned his judgment. He just turned around and walked out of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts should be clear. This country is particularly vulnerable in current circumstances. The Government has not addressed our fundamental economic problems. What policy changes it has made latterly-and admittedly now more in the right direction-have been far too little, far too late. I suggest that the Government should spend more time taking some of the tough decisions that are required in current circumstances than in wandering around this country and the rest of the world trying to create the impression that it has taken most of those tough decisions.

In looking at our present vulnerability, we see that the key element is the size of our international debts. Our debts have reached banana republic proportions; we are well down the Argentinean road. And of course, that is compounded by the fact that our balance of payments is still both structurally and cyclically weak. This makes it very difficult for us to service even those levels of international debt. It already takes more than $1 in every $3 of our export earnings just to pay the interest and meet the contractual principal repayments on those debts.

If one looks at the structure of our balance of payments, one sees some very disturbing features. We are still very much a commodity exporting country. We have never been able to reap fully our potential as an exporter of manufactures or, more recently, as an exporter of services. Moreover, our exports are concentrated very heavily on just a couple of markets-most importantly, Japan and the United States of America, two countries that are very close to an international trade war as a result of the protectionist sentiment that has arisen in the United States.

Similarly, if we look at the import side we see a very heavy dependence on the importation of capital equipment which makes it very difficult for us to capitalise on competitive opportunities that could flow from a fall in the exchange rate by way of import substitution. By looking at the data that the Australian Statistician has released in recent days, we see that the J-curve has recently stalled. For the last five or six months this `saviour' of the Government has stalled; the curve has flattened out and will not do the job that the Government is counting on it to do. As a result of our current account deficit, we are now heavily dependent on capital inflow and the sustained confidence of international financial markets. To maintain that confidence is not easy because many of those financial markets look at our currency as an exotic or speculative currency and they are quite happy to move in and out with great vigour on occasions.

Apart from those balance of payments factors, there are a host of other structural factors which have made our life very difficult and which prevent us responding to external shocks in the way that we should. We have a tax system that imposes excessive taxation burdens on individuals and corporations. It saps initiatives and incentive. We also have a very rigid and inflexible labour market, despite all the Government's rhetoric to the contrary. It is a labour market that does not allow us to respond in a realistic way to the challenge of international competitiveness. Finally, we still have an attitude to protection and industry policy that is still far too inward looking and infantile in its orientation.

Of course, the Government has recently started to pay lip service to some of these things, suggesting that it will make some of the changes of a micro nature that are required to get our house in order, as well as suggesting that its macro policies are broadly in the right direction. But at the macro level the Government's strategy is just like it was before. It is entirely dependent on growth; it is of little more use than a grab for growth. Its whole strategy depends very heavily on a sizable pick-up in growth. The Government needs growth for the taxation revenue that it fed into its last Budget which it hopes will end up balanced. Of course, that is an illusion. It also needs growth to bring the productivity gains that are required to offset some of those excessive wage deals that it has done to satisfy its political constituency. And, the Government needs growth to sustain the confidence of foreigners in our economy and to sustain that crucial capital inflow.

The simple fact is that the Government has not taken the decisions it should have taken and therefore will not get the growth it thinks it will get. Disturbingly, it seems that it has learned virtually nothing from the past, including its past attempts to chase growth. Honourable members might remember what happened in 1983 and 1984, which was the last time the Government got hooked on growth. Just as growth was not sustainable then, it is not attainable now. Indeed, many of our current difficulties have arisen primarily because of some of the very soft decisions taken in the economic policy area in 1983, 1984 and 1985. Do honourable members remember the nonsense that this Government used to peddle around this country about consensus? Do honourable members recall how the accord would control inflation so that the Government could stimulate growth by expansionary monetary and fiscal policies? Do they remember the situation around the middle of 1984, leading up to the election, when the Treasurer eased monetary policy quite significantly by forcing the Reserve Bank of Australia to push down interest rates? I would suggest that the Government has learned virtually nothing from those experiences. It got its just deserts then. Our exchange rate collapsed on three occasions in 1985 and 1986 as financial markets voted with their feet. And it is about to get its desserts again. The Government has learnt nothing as the current economic environment is, in many respects, a repeat of 1984-85. Again it is awash with revenue. Again it sees growth picking up. And, already, it has started to reward itself by pushing down interest rates and paying excessive wage increases.

Interestingly, the Treasurer has two responses to economic shocks such as we are experiencing. Either he blames somebody else or he sits quietly by in the desperate hope that it will all go away. Just look at the list of excuses that he has used in recent days. He has referred to the fall in our terms of trade-as if that is something new; it has been falling for about 25 or 30 years. He has referred to the fact that the States are still spending, not him; or that President Reagan has not got his house in order; or that the Fraser Government did one thing or another, or whatever. He is a past master at this game of passing the parcel. Have honourable members ever seen him when he stands up in the House? As soon as he turns around to talk to his mates they all duck because they think the parcel is about to come their way.

Alternatively, he sits back and hopes the problem will just go away. He wants a quiet life. He would like to be able to go to ground in the next several months. Why? It is because he wants an easy passage to the position of chief executive. He does not want to antagonise any more of his mates. Indeed, he has to win some new mates if he is to get there. So deals get done, but the essential decisions do not get taken. It is just like the last Budget with all its nonsense and rhetoric about fiscal discipline, balance, expenditure restraint, tax reform, retiring debt and so on. Those are all illusions. None of it stands up to close examination.

Even yesterday in the midst of a stock market crisis we had the almost unbelievable spectacle of a Treasurer who seemed completely oblivious to what was going on around him. For he came into this House and defended another increase of 1.5 per cent in the first tier in the current wage case. He did so even though it will contribute to a wage increase this year that is nearly double that of our trading partners. This is not economic rationality. He surely must have done a deal with one of his Australian Council of Trade Union mates.

Our balance of payments is still in fundamental deficit. Our debt is still growing alarmingly. It will not stabilise, even on the most optimistic assumptions, until the early 1990s and, realistically, probably not until the early 2000s. The truth is that the Government has not taken the necessary economic decisions. Unfortunately the necessary policy adjustments are about as slow in coming as one of the Treasurer's tax returns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of an amazing set of circumstances, today on the front page of the Australian Financial Review, one of the most prestigious newspapers in this country in terms of economic discussion, is a story about how the leaders of the G7 group, as they are known, the major economic powers of the world, have reaffirmed their commitment to stable exchange rates in light of what has happened in the world economy in the last 24 to 48 hours. I urge honourable members opposite to have a good look at this article by Mr Stephen Hughes. It talks about Mr James Baker's reaction. It talks about the reaction of the German Finance Minister, Mr Stoltenberg, and the reaction of the President of the Bundesbank. It talks about the reaction of the Governor of the Bank of Japan.

SPEECH.PARA: On the very day that we see a united, confirmed world economic response to what has happened, members of this pathetic Opposition stand up in this place and go on with the usual drivel they have gone on with for the last 4 1/2 years. Only now they have got themselves a professor to do it as well. They try to blame this Government for what has happened, saying, `What has happened in the last 24 to 48 hours, although it is not really the Labor Government's fault, sort of is its fault and we will blame it'. They are attempting to play on people's ignorance and fear. They have no ground for doing either. They will come well and truly unstuck by the end of this week if they continue with this sort of economic drivel.

The Minister Assisting the Treasurer, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), has already gone into the record of what this Government has done in world terms very quickly to adjust this country to the problems we face in terms of our foreign debt and of the new economic world order. He has mentioned the reduction of government spending from 5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) to zero. It is important to note that that 5 per cent was a Liberal-National Party legacy. The Minister Assisting the Treasurer has also mentioned the 10 per cent reduction in real unit labour costs that has been achieved by the Labor Government and the labour movement in the last 4 1/2 years. Suffice it to say what the Minister Assisting the Treasurer has said here today: this country is responding better than any other country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development to the changed circumstances, under more difficult conditions than any which face other OECD countries. The Labor Government is achieving macroeconomic and micro- economic flexibility with our new emphasis on employment retraining, work skills and so forth. In light of all that, honourable members opposite have had nothing to say today about what their policy response would be.

In Question Time today Opposition members talked about debt having risen, in relative terms, as a percentage of gross domestic product. That is very good. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been telling them that for 12 months. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), forgot to mention a couple of things today. He forgot to mention that current account deficits are cumulative and that we inherited an institutional and structural imbalance from the previous Government. They were problems from 1975 to 1983. He forgot to mention the fact that the problem with a cumulative current account deficit, like any other debt, is that it feeds off itself.

The shadow Treasurer forgot to mention where the problem started. He forgot to mention that 25 to 30 per cent of our net external debt of $81 billion is devaluation-related. The decline in the value of our currency has boosted the dollar figure of our overseas debt. He forgot to mention that this transition has occurred at a time when our terms of trade have declined by 16 per cent in real terms, as opposed to the position of many other nations in the OECD. The Treasurer mentioned today the fact that West Germany's terms of trade have risen by 30 per cent. The shadow Treasurer forgot to mention that. He forgot to mention that if we had the same terms of trade today as we had in 1985-86 our foreign debt would be considerably worse.

The Opposition is attempting to change tack. This was highlighted in the Financial Review on Friday, 11 September, in an interview with the shadow Treasurer. Opposition members are now attacking the Government, not on the fundamentals-they have lost that argument; they know we are right-but about the pace of change in Australian economic policy. They are going back to the old, cliche-riddled policies they had in the leadup to the 1984 election. They had no real policy options, just cliches.

Let us put a few questions to the Opposition this afternoon and let us demand a response. The Government is here in the House every day when the Parliament is sitting for its key Ministers to be questioned. The Opposition has not yet found a basic problem in what we are doing. Yet it comes into this place and talks about the pace of change, without any substance or concrete policy. What is the Opposition's alternative policy? Is it a further reduction in real wages; if so, by how much and how is the Opposition going to achieve it in the present institutional framework of Australian industrial relations? The Opposition's last attempt in 1980-81 was not bad. There was a 39 per cent blowout in wage increases in the metal industry alone.

Is the Opposition going to attempt to implement the big baseball bat industrial relations policy again and destroy the consensus which is now achieving, for the first time, work practice changes which are so badly needed in this country and which were built in the private sector over 30 years-for the vast majority of which time the Opposition was in government? Is the Opposition's response to cut the deficit or to cut government outlays further? If so, by how much and where? The honourable member for Kooyong, it has to be remembered, made his name with the pensioners in this country for opposing the assets test. What is his response to government outlays such as the provision of pensions for everybody? Is he going to scrap the assets test? Let us hear a response from the shadow Treasurer-something concrete. He is condemned by his own words in the article in the Financial Review on 11 September. He said:
But I would not want to be in a situation as Treasurer where I would be seeking to implement a sudden turnaround-it would be too disruptive.

So at the same time as the honourable member is criticising us for the pace of change he says that he does not want to be too disruptive. It has to be remembered that during the election campaign his Leader spelt out that the reduction in the deficit this year under the Opposition would have been a mere $270m, to phase in its tax cuts. Opposition members talk about the pace of change! They talk about the pace of change with their own Liberal Party tax policy. What a joke! While we are talking about changing basic institutional and economic foundations in this country, and are doing so to the applause of the rest of the OECD countries, the great pace of change the shadow Treasurer is talking about is to bring out his new Liberal Party tax policy. When is he going to do it? By mid-1988, and announce it soon after. We are here grappling with the world's economic problems, the likes of which no government in the history of this country has ever had to face, and the honourable member for Kooyong cannot even change his own Party's policy before mid-1988. How hypocritical can one get?

If the honourable member wants to talk about further cuts in government outlays, if the Opposition were to be elected to government and somehow magically produced a $2 billion surplus, let us note that a mere 0.7 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product would be given back from the public call on borrowings and savings to the private sector. We would go from a position of about 2.5 per cent of gross domestic product in the net public sector borrowing requirement, nearly all of which is for the States in prospect for 1987-88, back to 1.8 per cent. So what? What would that achieve, apart from massive social, economic and industrial dislocation in this country. The truth is that members opposite, the new right wing ideologues, do not want to acknowledge that Reaganism in the United States has failed. America has caught a cold and has sneezed and the rest of us are in danger of ill health. Those opposite do not want to acknowledge that. In that case, I suggest that they read Robert Hadler's article in today's Australian in which he says:
While the Australian Government has taken great strides to reduce its twin deficit problems, the United States administration stubbornly refuses to face up to its own economic problems.
I remind those opposite of that article and urge them to look at it to see who is right and who is wrong.
