DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Bill is the first in a package of four Bills that will give effect to the Government's decision to introduce a petroleum resource rent tax on profits from certain off-shore petroleum projects. The proposed tax regime was announced in detail in June 1984, after extensive consultation with the industry and the States. These Bills are now being reintroduced in the same form in which they were before the Senate when Parliament was dissolved for the election and the Bills consequently lapsed.

Petroleum resources are, in their most basic sense, community property and the Government believes that the community as a whole should share in the potentially high returns from the exploitation of these scarce, non-renewable resources. At the same time it is recognised that participants in petroleum projects who do not earn high profits in relation to the amount invested and the risk involved, particularly when oil prices decline, should be able to operate secure in the knowledge that excise and royalties which are based on production will not apply. The Government believes that a resource rent tax related to achieved profits is a more efficient and equitable secondary taxation regime than the excise and royalty system that it is to replace. I emphasise that the proposed tax replaces the existing system-it is not in addition to it.

In contrast to production-based secondary tax regimes, the petroleum resource rent tax will be payable only in respect of projects earning a high rate of return on outlays. Particularly in light of the current volatility of world oil prices, the resource rent tax system thus offers considerable benefits to the petroleum industry. It strikes a reasonable balance between the objectives of satisfying the right of the community as a whole to share in the benefits of profitable offshore petroleum projects, and of providing the participants with adequate returns for the risks they accept in undertaking offshore exploration and development activities. The Bill incorporates amendments made after Government consideration of representations made by the petroleum industry. The provisions of the Bill, nevertheless, follow closely the proposal as announced in June 1984, while accommodating the retention lease system in relation to offshore petroleum exploration. I now turn to outline the more significant features of the tax.
General Application

The tax is to apply to a person's taxable profits from the recovery of petroleum in off-shore areas where the Commonwealth's Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 applies, other than in areas covered by production licences granted on or before 1 July 1984 and the permit areas from which those production licences were drawn. The tax will therefore not apply to the North West Shelf permit areas or Esso Australia Ltd's and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd's Bass Strait permit area. Excise and royalty arrangements will continue to apply in those areas.

As the petroleum resource rent tax is profit-based, rather than production-based, it will apply only where there is an excess of project-related receipts for a financial year over both project-related expenditure for the year and undeducted expenditure of previous years brought forward at a compound rate. This compounding of expenditure ensures that the investment represented by the expenditure obtains an appropriate rate of return free of secondary tax. The rate of compounding for expenditure that remains undeducted at the end of a financial year will be determined according to when it was expended. Expenditure-generally exploration expenditure-more than five years before the coming into force of the first production licence in a permit area will attract compounding at a rate equal to the gross domestic product deflator rate, currently around 8 per cent. More recent expenditure in respect of the project will be carried forward at a rate equal to the prevailing long term bond rate increased by 15 percentage points. Currently this produces a rate of about 28 per cent.

In broad terms, a petroleum project incorporates the production licence area, and such treatment and other facilities and operations outside that area as are integral to the production and initial on-site storage of marketable petroleum commodities such as stabilised crude oil, condensate and liquefied petroleum gas. As a practical matter, two or more projects will be treated as a single project for tax purposes where the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, having regard to relevant factors, considers that they should be so treated and issues a certificate to that effect. The boundaries of a petroleum project will not extend beyond the point at which a marketable petroleum commodity is initially stored after production-that is, the project boundaries will not extend to `downstream activities' such as refineries and facilities for the transport of marketable products from initial storage.
Assessable Receipts

Liability for petroleum resource rent tax is to be assessed on the accruals basis that generally applies in determining income tax liability. Assessable receipts from the project will, therefore, be taken into account in the financial year in which they are receivable. Assessable project receipts will include amounts receivable from the sale of petroleum or of a marketable petroleum commodity. In the event that a marketable petroleum commodity is not sold after the point of initial on-site storage, the market value-or a fair and reasonable value-of the commodity will be treated as an assessable receipt of the project. The need to attribute a value could arise, for example, in the case of an integrated producer which both extracts crude oil and refines it.
Deductible Expenditure

Expenditure of either a capital or a revenue nature which is directly related to a petroleum project will be deductible in the year in which it is incurred against any assessable receipts for the year. Any excess of deductible expenditure, other than closing-down expenditure, over assessable receipts at the end of a year, will be compounded forward for deduction against receipts in future years. Deductible expenditure comprises exploration expenditure, general project expenditure and closing-down expenditure, subject to the exclusion of certain specific items of expenditure. Exploration expenditure consists, broadly, of expenditure-other than excluded expenditure-in an exploration permit area that is directly related to exploration for petroleum and will include expenditure on the recovery of petroleum and the production of a marketable commodity prior to the coming into force of a production licence. Exploration expenditure includes related expenditure on storage and processing facilities and on employee amenities. Exploration expenditure will be deductible against assessable receipts of any project established within the exploration permit area.

Where there are two or more projects in a permit area, exploration expenditure deductible in a particular year is to be off set against the project that relates to the production licence which first came into force, then against subsequent projects producing assessable receipts in that year. Special rules apply where a production licence from one permit area is combined with a production licence from another permit area to form a single project.

I mentioned earlier that the provisions of this Bill take into account the retention lease system introduced in 1985. Retention leases are of considerable benefit to the industry. They allow title to be held over a promising discovery for a number of years without insisting on any major ongoing exploration or development program in the area. To prevent potentially significant revenue losses arising from compounding of deductible amounts, exploration expenditure related to a retention lease area will be able to be offset only against projects in that area. Exploration expenditure in the rest of the permit area will not be deductible against a retention lease project. That expenditure, if incurred more than five years before the coming into force of a production licence in the retention lease area, will attract compounding at the gross domestic product deflator rate.

General project expenditure comprises expenditure in a production licence area, or combined production licence areas, on the establishment of a project, on recovering and producing a marketable petroleum commodity and on storing that commodity adjacent to the production site. It includes relevant expenditure on storage and processing facilities and employee amenities.

Closing-down expenditure is made up of expenditure in closing down a petroleum project and specifically includes expenditure on environmental restoration of a project site. If, at the end of a project's life, there are insufficient assessable receipts for a year against which to offset closing-down expenditure for the year, a tax credit of 40 per cent of the excess expenditure is provided. Of course, closing-down credits in respect of a project will not be permitted to exceed the petroleum resource rent tax previously paid in respect of the project.

Certain expenditure is specifically excluded from petroleum resource rent tax deductibility. Examples are interest payments and payments made under a cash bidding system. As petroleum resource rent tax is to be a deductible expense for income tax purposes, income tax payments are not to be deductible for resource rent tax purposes. Fringe benefits tax payments are also excluded.
Instalments

The practical operation of the Bill will require the payment of petroleum resource rent tax by instalments in any year in which a person's assessable receipts from a project exceed the deductible expenditure, including any compounded expenditure of previous years. Three instalments of tax will be payable, determined on the basis of assessable receipts and deductible expenditure in the instalment period and an appropriate proportion of compounded expenditure from previous years. The liability for tax assessed at the year's end will be reduced by earlier paid instalments for the year.

The Bill also contains the usual machinery provisions of a tax law-dealing with such things as collection and recovery procedures-and provides objection and appeal rights for taxpayers dissatisfied with decisions under the proposed petroleum resource rent tax regime. Full details of the provisions of the Bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum that has been circulated to honourable members.

The Bill in its present form deals with projects that might straddle both a petroleum resource rent tax area and an area under Commonwealth or State jurisdiction and subject to excise and/or royalties. It does this by apportioning a quantity of petroleum from a project to be subject to petroleum resource rent tax. This issue raises a number of complex questions-some requiring resolution in Commonwealth-State discussions. Nevertheless, it is the Government's intention that, for reasons of both administration and industry certainty, the petroleum resource rent tax should apply to the total project where it extends beyond the resource rent tax area. The Government intends to initiate discussions with the States on the question of treatment of projects which straddle resource rent tax areas and State excise/royalty areas. Once these questions have been resolved, any necessary amendments will be introduced.

On the basis of current world oil prices, it is unlikely that any petroleum resource rent tax revenue will be received before the 1988-89 financial year. Due to the continuing fluctuations in world oil prices and the uncertainties inherent in predicting success in off-shore petroleum exploration and subsequent production, the amount of revenue likely to be obtained in any year cannot be projected.
I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT TAX (INTEREST ON UNDERPAYMENTS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will formally impose the interest charge payable under section 65 of the proposed Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987, the Bill for which I have just introduced. Honourable members will be aware that under section 55 of the Australian Constitution laws imposing taxation may deal only with the imposition of taxation and may not contain any extraneous matters. Because interest payable under section 65 of the Assessment Act might technically be regarded as a tax, this Bill is designed to ensure that constitutional requirements are met. Its provisions are also explained in the memorandum that has been circulated. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RESOURCE RENT TAX (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill now be read a second time.

The new profit based taxing regime for off-shore petroleum projects is, in respect of those projects, to replace the existing production based excise and royalty arrangements. This Bill will amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Act 1967 to effect that replacement. The Bill will also amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to provide income tax deductibility for petroleum resource rent tax paid other than by way of instalments. Conversely, refunds and certain credits of petroleum resource rent tax are to be made subject to income tax.

Decisions under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 will assume greater importance for the Commonwealth with the introduction of a petroleum resource rent tax. That Act is therefore being amended by this Bill to provide for decisions relating to the development of petroleum pools straddling production licence areas, including pools which straddle the outer boundary of the territorial sea, to be taken jointly by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the relevant State or Northern Territory Minister.

The scope of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 is also being extended by the Bill, so that offences against that Act will cover schemes for the fraudulent evasion of petroleum resource rent tax in the same way as they deal with other taxes of the Commonwealth. Details of this Bill are also set out in the explanatory memorandum that has been circulated. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Dr BLEWETT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Hawke Labor Government was elected in 1983 with a firm commitment to the availability of adequate and affordable housing for all Australians. In 1984 we introduced the new Housing Assistance Bill which honoured our commitment to revamp public housing policy and assistance in Australia. This was an important piece of social legislation. Affordable and secure housing is essential for the well-being of all Australians.

The 1984 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, authorised by the Housing Assistance Act, was negotiated by Federal and State governments in 1983-84 to operate for 10 years from 1 July 1984. It included a number of initiatives, one of which was that the Agreement be evaluated triennially.

At the Housing Ministers Conference in April 1986 Federal and State housing Ministers agreed to a timetable and a procedure for the first triennial evaluation of the agreement. At that meeting Ministers agreed that a steering committee of Commonwealth and State officials would be established to oversee the evaluation in accordance with the agreed terms of reference.

The terms of reference stated that the first triennial evaluation would examine the effectiveness and efficiency of rental and home purchase assistance programs, against the principles set out in the agreement. Ministers also agreed that non-government organisations be invited to provide submissions on the operation of the agreement. The triennial evaluation concluded that public housing programs under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement are generally efficient, effective and well targeted. The evaluation also concluded that the objectives and principles introduced in the 1984 agreement remain valid, but that in particular areas of the provision of home purchase and rental assistance, minor amendments could further improve effectiveness and efficiency.

Two changes are to be made to the Housing Assistance Act through this Bill. The first is to provide for the continuation of the Government's commitment to provide a guarantee of a high level of base funding for the next triennium. Funding to the States and the Northern Territory for housing will be guaranteed at a base level of $700m for 1988-89 and 1989-90. This is $200m more than the record base funding provided in the first triennium and 3 1/2 times the base level provided for in the previous Government's 1981 agreement. The current year's funding is to be made available through Appropriation Act (No. 2) 1987-88.

The financial impact of this Bill is therefore a cost to the Commonwealth of $700m in 1988-89 and 1989-90. As part of the $700m guaranteed for 1988-89 and 1989-90 the local government and community housing program will receive $11m and the crisis accommodation program will receive $14m.

The Government will also allow all States to nominate up to 100 per cent of the loan component of their State government borrowing programs for public housing in 1987-88. These funds are available at the highly concessional interest rate of 4.5 per cent, repayable over 53 years. This funding, which is provided in a year of very considerable Budget restraint, reflects the high priority accorded by the Federal Government to the alleviation of housing related poverty.

The second change to the Housing Assistance Act arising out of the evaluation of the agreement relates to section 11 of that Act which deals with the Minister's authority to reallocate specific housing assistance grants from one State to another. This section is to be amended to allow the Federal Minister responsible for administering the agreement to redirect funds to other States or for the funds to be retained by the Commonwealth. This could occur in the event of a State failing to comply with the provisions of the agreement relating to specific purpose programs or the guidelines for those programs. This change is being introduced to ensure that States adhere to the agreed procedures for consultation in respect of Aboriginal housing and other special purpose programs and that in these programs, which are fully funded by the Federal Government, Federal priorities are implemented.

Following the outcome of the triennial evaluation, amendments were also made to the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, and I propose to outline briefly these changes for the information of honourable members. I table the amended agreement. The amendments in this agreement have been negotiated and agreed with the State and Northern Territory housing Ministers. The agreement has been tightened up in the area of State matching contributions to ensure that States meet their financial responsibilities for public housing.

The agreement will also be amended to ensure that all State matching contributions for home purchase assistance, and Loan Council nominated funds used for home purchase assistance, will be channelled through the home purchase assistance account. This will ensure that all funds provided to the States under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and Loan Council arrangements continue to be used for the purposes of the agreement.

The agreement will permit surpluses generated from home purchase assistance operations to be used for general rental assistance. It will also specify that not less than 50 per cent of total funds are to be directed to public rental assistance in recognition of the need to increase the supply of affordable rental housing. The approved use of funds will also be widened. This amendment will permit funds provided under the agreement to be used for more innovative purposes such as joint ventures, secondary mortgage market trusts and rental housing trusts. This move will encourage States to enter into innovative financial arrangements and attract private sector finance into public housing provision.

Home purchase assistance provisions will also be amended to require that reviews of income of recipients be conducted annually or at intervals agreed to by the Minister. This will ensure that subsidies are not provided to those who are not in need and will maximise the amount of funds available for further loans. If income is not reviewed annually, loan repayments are to be adjusted annually in accordance with the consumer price index or other agreed index.

The sales policy for public rental housing will be refined to ensure that rental stock is not depleted and that sales will cover the costs of providing replacement dwellings. This policy will provide that public rental housing constructed or purchased within the previous five years cannot be sold to an individual purchaser at less than replacement cost. This Government will also ensure that young single people are not excluded by a particular State from access to public housing.

These changes to public housing arrangements will ensure that the 1984 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement remains effective in assisting many thousands of Australian households each year to obtain adequate housing at a price they can afford. In addition to our public housing efforts, this Government has made significant achievement in other areas of housing assistance. The first home owners scheme has been widely heralded as the most effective scheme ever to assist home buyers obtain their first home. The eligibility limits were increased in March this year, with extra assistance going to families. Since its inception, this scheme has helped over 255,000 first home buyers into their own home. It continues to be the most effective home purchase assistance program ever introduced by a Federal government.

This Government has not ignored the private rental market. The recent decision on negative gearing will flow through into increased rental supply and put a brake on rent increases. We will also provide direct assistance through the new family allowance package. Low income families renting privately who are receiving the family allowance supplement, parents on unemployment benefit and pensioners will now receive up to $15 a week rent assistance. It is the first time that any Federal government has provided rent assistance to working families on low incomes. This is a significant breakthrough.

This Government's sound economic policies will continue to place downward pressure on home loan interest rates. The Budget has been followed by an immediate drop in housing loan interest rates. Rates have now come down by a full percentage point over the last three months.

Another initiative co-ordinated by the Federal Government was that from 1 July 1987 the funding arrangements for public housing in the Australian Capital Territory would be aligned with the States and the Northern Territory under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. This decision is welcomed because it will ensure consistency and equity of treatment between residents in the Australian Capital Territory and those living elsewhere in Australia.

The Government recognises that the massive housing problems facing low income earners cannot be overcome in one or two years. This is why the agreement is placed in a 10-year framework. We have entered into a long term commitment to those in housing need. The improvements made to the arrangements following the first evaluation will enhance significantly the effectiveness of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement over the remaining seven years. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: UPGRADE OF JINDALEE FACILITIES AT ALICE SPRINGS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, and by reason of the urgent nature of the work, it is expedient that the following proposed work be carried out without having been referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works: Upgrade of the Jindalee facilities at Alice Springs.

The proposed work, I believe, is an essential element of the project to develop a network of over-the-horizon radars. The upgrade of the existing Jindalee facilities is to enable the experimental radar to be used as a test-bed for scientific, engineering and operational development. From this test-bed a network of radars will be developed to provide a basic element of a national system for air defence and air space control. The network of radars will provide this country with broad area surveillance of our sea and air approaches and will provide long range detection of aircraft and surface ships.

The Jindalee radar facilities are dispersed at remote locations within the Northern Territory. The transmitter site is some 160 kilometres north-east of Alice Springs in the Harts Range area. The receiver site is in the Mount Everard area, 45 kilometres north-west of Alice Springs. A beacon located at HMAS Coonawarra in Darwin provides the reference information for the radar system.

For the benefit of those honourable members who were not present when the House first considered this proposal, I will now outline details of the proposed works. At the Mount Everard receiver site there will be alterations to the receiver building to accommodate additional personnel and equipment, a new administration and amenities complex, a new general engineering workshop, a new guard house, carports for defence vehicles, a new electronic security surveillance system, a new power supply, an upgrading of existing engineering services including roads, security fencing, water, drainage, fire and electrical systems, and provision of landscaping.

At the Harts Range transmitter site there will be alterations to the transmitter control building, a new workshop and store, five new 4-bedroom houses, a refurbishment of two transportable houses for transient personnel, two new transportables for kitchen and dining facilities, civil works for an antenna extension, upgrading of engineering services and the provision of landscaping.

In Alice Springs there will be provision for seven 3-bedroom and two 4-bedroom houses, and provision of four 2-bedroom townhouses. At the Darwin beacon site there will be an upgrade of the power supply and structural modifications to improve cyclone resistance.

The estimated cost of the upgrading works is $8.2m at April 1987 prices. It is now necessary to proceed urgently with the works. Examination by the Joint Committee on Public Works is, therefore, not recommended for two major reasons: firstly, the time it would now take the Committee to report. I state, by way of explanation of this point, that, on 2 April 1987, the House resolved to refer the proposal to the Committee for examination. The hearing was scheduled for 20-22 July, but the reference lapsed with the dissolution of the Parliament on 5 June. The normal procedure for a reference that has lapsed is to refer it again to the new Committee upon the resumption of Parliament.

When previously referred it was anticipated the Committee would table its report in August 1987, and, subject to favourable recommendations, contracts would be called when the expediency motion was passed, with construction commencing in October 1987, the facilities upgrade being completed by October 1988 and the new housing being completed by mid-1989. With the lapsing of the reference the program has already slipped. If the proposal were to be now referred to the Committee it would be unlikely a report would be tabled until late December and tenders would not be invited until February 1988, with construction commencing in April 1988. The potential delay of six months would delay the availability of the upgraded facilities and consequently the introduction of the over-the-horizon radar network capability.

The second reason for the urgency of these works is that from 1 January 1987 the Department of Defence has been arranging contracts for equipment upgrade and systems acquisition packages to redevelop the radar. Some 300 packages are programmed for implementation in a four-year period ending in 1990. The bulk of these tasks have already been contracted at a cost of over $22m.

The programming of these tasks was based on the facilities upgrade being completed at the transmitter site by the end of August 1988 and at the receiver site by October 1988. Delays to the construction timetable will delay these contracts. The penalty cost to the Commonwealth of extending these contracts has been estimated at some $330,000 for each month's delay.

If the House supports this motion my Department intends immediately to call tenders so that construction can commence as soon as possible. The facilities upgrade should be completed in 12 months time with the housing completed in 1989. Design of this project was undertaken by my Department with some contract support. Construction will be contracted to private enterprise. After considering those explanations I trust that the House will agree that there is urgency with this proposal. I am convinced of those facts, so I commend to the House this motion that it is expedient to carry out the work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Joint Committee on Public Works I wish to refer to the exemption of the Jindalee project. It is regrettable that the referral to the Committee lapsed with the dissolution of Parliament in June. The Department of Defence has now advised that deferral of commencement of the work from October 1987 to April 1988 would result in a cost of $330,000 per month, and the Committee agrees that this would result in sev- ere financial penalties for the Commonwealth. However, the Committee is extremely concerned that the Department of Defence entered into contracts for equipment and systems long before a public hearing was scheduled under the original referral. At that time Defence could not have known whether the Public Works Committee would recommend that the project proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Public Works Committee is to fulfil its role of scrutinising public works then its decisions should not be pre-empted in this manner. On behalf of the Committee I would like the Government to note its concern in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again we have a proposal before the House which seeks to short-circuit the established system, as the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has rightly pointed out, giving a bit of a shaft to his own side. Again a motion has come before this House which seeks urgency status for a major piece of defence equipment. We will not oppose this motion today. But at the same time I must state plainly that I do not think the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) ever had any intention of referring this matter to the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works. He kept blaming the election which the Government itself called, and which is a stupid excuse anyway. He also blamed many other things. I have some sympathy with the view that perhaps some of these highly complicated and complex projects should go somewhere else. But, for God's sake, the Minister should stop coming in here and blaming everything else, such as elections and running out of time and all the rest of it. If the Government wants to change the system it should change the system and stop coming in here making excuses every time. The Government is going around the Public Works Committee. If there is a reason to change the system the Government should do it.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason we will not oppose this motion is that we believe that the Jindalee project has enormous potential to enhance the security of this country. The reason we place such great importance on that project is that some of the other agencies that are supposed to be responsible for the security of this country are falling apart. I am very pleased to see the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) in the chamber because if there is one thing that is falling apart at the moment it is the defence forces of this country. Without putting too fine a point on it, the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) is just about knackered. There is an enormous shortage of pilots. They are leaving day by day. Our operational squadrons are almost grounded because of lack of pilots and other personnel. Two hundred and fifty pilots left in the last two years. The RAAF has managed to supply only 150 through its normal training procedure. So we have been 100 short for the last two years. So we agree that it is a matter of urgency to get a decent surveillance system in the north of this country. We have recently had the spectacle of the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member to keep closely to the motion before the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will not be very lengthy but I put it to you that it is a very serious matter. Amann is part of our Coast- watch service. Coastwatch is part of our northern surveillance system. Jindalee has been designed to be a major contributor-and this is gradually coming into effect; it was started in 1984-to the northern surveillance and security of this country. I think it is entirely legitimate to give passing reference to the fiasco of the Amann contract when talking about the northern surveillance of this country.
—The honourable member has given passing reference.

—Having made reference to the fiasco of the Amann contract which has so recently been debated, let me also talk about the control and co-ordination of our northern surveillance because Jindalee, when it comes on stream, as it will in the next few years, is an essential part of that surveillance. What I am saying to the Government is this: Are we going to allow the northern surveillance and security of this country to remain under the haphazard control which is presently exercised over it? That is a fundamental problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Will the Government continue to allow the Department of Transport and Communications to be involved? Will the Government leave the matter in the hands of the Australian Federal Police, which is so damned busy that it does not have time properly to devote any energies to this function? The Australian Federal Police does not have the equipment and I suspect that many of its officers do not have the interest or the experience to run and co-ordinate such a project. Or will the Government initiate a study so that the northern surveillance problems of this country can be put in the hands of a professional force, the sort of force that one would look to to do the job both in times of war or emergency as well as in peace? If an organisation is going to do the job in wartime it should also do it in peacetime. I suggest to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) that he initiate an immediate study into how Jindalee will be incorporated into our northern surveillance in respect of the other agencies, whether we are talking about Amann, Coastwatch, Navy, Army or Air Force patrols, merchant shipping, graziers, health, immigration and the Australian Customs Service. We cannot leave this surveillance in the unholy mess that it is in now. That is why we will support this proposal-to get Jindalee up and running as soon as possible so that we get an added dimension of security into our northern surveillance.

One of the problems with Jindalee is that it will not be the be-all and end-all of northern surveillance. It is still an unproven system. It is showing signs of great effectiveness; it still has a long way to go. But it can only be really effective if it is co-ordinated with airborne early warning radar. That seems to be acknowledged by anyone who has had anything to do with our northern surveillance, including the Government. I find it interesting that in 1985 the Minister talked about the acquisition of these other agencies which would be called upon to assist the Jindalee system. I ask the Minister: Where at the moment are the proposals that were asked for in December 1985 to assist and supplement the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar? The fact is that Jindalee is a very generalised security system. It can tell us in which general area a ship or aircraft might be. It cannot tell us the altitude of an aircraft, for a start, and it can only tell us that something is there if it is moving. So if a submarine, for example, were stationary on the surface the Jindalee would not be able to tell us that it was there.

Jindalee has developed an extraordinary capacity and has confounded some of the cynics. Exercise Pitch Black held recently in the Darwin area surprised many people by showing that Jindalee had come a long way. But we come back to this fundamental point: Are we still going to have as part of our surveillance screen in northern Australia this unco-ordinated mass of agencies that we have now? We have Amann, Army patrols, Navy patrols and the Federal Police, and the Jindalee project will be coming in. Who in the end will control and co-ordinate these things? It is no good having a system such as Jindalee-which shows potential which can be developed and which will be a valuable agency in the surveillance of the northern approaches to Australia-if it is not properly controlled and co-ordinated. I would hate to think that we will have this valuable piece of equipment, which has the potential to do such a lot of work and provide a lot of security for us in northern Australia, only to let it go by default, because if there are two things that require extra attention at the moment they are the northern surveillance problem and the state of our armed forces, as I have no doubt the Minister is very much aware.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish, firstly, to support my colleague the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), and, secondly, to express the fact that we have some sympathy with the concerns raised by the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Public Works. I say to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), that the Opposition's concern, and clearly the concern of the Public Works Committee (PWC) as expressed by its Chairman today, is that declaring works urgent is becoming a bit of a habit. On 24 September the Minister sought a similar declaration of urgency in relation to the construction of survey motor launches for the Royal Australian Navy. On that occasion he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The acquisition of the survey motor launches has been deferred for some years due to financial constraints.
In other words, he said that the plan had been on the drawing board for some time. His next sentence was:
However, their acquisition is now urgent to enable the surveying of coastal waters, particularly around northern Australia.

The Minister did not explain why it was suddenly urgent. I understand the plan had been on the drawing board for three years. His Government had not considered it to be of a sufficiently high priority to allocate funds to it for three years. But suddenly, when the money became available, the Minister came in here and sought a declaration of urgency. In a way, it was similar to the Jindalee case. He had already sought tenders for the construction of the vessels. Those tenders closed in October 1986, and in September 1987 the Minister told us, `Look, the tenders have closed and we understand that the validity of those tenders is about to expire'. So he had to award the tender by the end of September or early this month. So, as the honourable member for McPherson said, we do not believe that the Minister had any intention of submitting that proposal to the Public Works Committee. He put it out to tender without submitting it to the Public Works Committee, although he could have done so during the six months before the last election.

In this case, as the Chairman of the Public Works Committee has said, he put out to tender contracts for part of the Jindalee system before submiting to the Public Works Committee the other half of the project-that is, the building of the facilities in which this Australian Defence Force equipment is to be installed. So again the evidence is that the Minister really had no intention of ever submitting this matter to the Committee once the election was called. He said that it did not matter, that he would just have the works declared urgent. If that is the way he wants to proceed, he ought to explain to the House what the new procedures are. The excuses for declarations of urgency are pretty flimsy. I think the Jindalee case has more substance to it than the previous case. The case for declaring the coastal survey vessels work urgent had no substance to it other than that the Minister had sought tenders, the tenders had closed and if a tender was not awarded, the process would have had to start again and there could have been cost penalties imposed.

As has been stated by my colleague, the Opposition clearly supports the upgrading of the Jindalee facilities because the system is a valuable adjunct to the nation's surveillance and intelligence facilities. The purpose of this project, according to the Minister, is the further development of a network of over-the-horizon radars which will provide a broad area of surveillance of our sea and air approaches, and will provide long range detection of aircraft and surface ships. We are aware that the new system has the potential to improve dramatically our surveillance capacity. The Opposition has on many occasions raised its concern about the current state of our northern coastal surveillance-or should I say lack of surveillance. Certainly the grossly incompetent way the Government has handled the letting of tenders by the Department of Transport and Communications for the aerial surveillance of our northern coast, resulting in the Amann Aviation Pty Ltd fiasco, has raised our concern not only about the Government's administrative competence, or incompetence, but also about the extent and standard of surveillance currently being undertaken. This matter remains a vital issue for Australia for defence purposes, for the control of illegal imports, for the control of illegal immigration and, of course, for the control of the illegal importation of drugs. In addition, we want to maintain an adequate surveillance system to ensure that we exclude from this country exotic diseases which we do not now have.

We therefore appreciate the concern of the Government that the initial reference to the Public Works Committee has been interrupted by the election and that a reference to the Committee now would delay the availability of this much-needed work, and it is also claimed that a delay would result in penalty costs of around $330,000 for each month. Nevertheless, we do raise some concerns and we think they are the sorts of concerns that would have been considered by the Public Works Committee had it been given the opportunity. Perhaps at the conclusion of this debate the Minister will be able to allay the concerns we have.

Following the Amann fiasco, it is clear that the Government is making a ham-fisted attempt to continue with surveillance under the auspices of the Australian Federal Police. If that is so, how will that surveillance be co-ordinated with this new Defence Force facility, which, as I have said, will provide the country with broad area surveillance of our sea and air approaches and will provide long range detection of aircraft and surface ships? In order to ensure that we have the most effective and efficient coastal surveillance, we need to make sure that in the event of the overlapping of the roles of each organisation involved-that is, the Department of Transport and Communications under the auspices of the Australian Federal Police, and those involved in this new Defence Force project-there is no duplication, and we need to make sure that the information obtained is actioned by the appropriate authority, be it the Department of Defence, the Federal Police, the Australian Customs Service, or the Department of Community Services and Health and so on. We would welcome the Minister's response, or indeed the response of the Acting Minister for Defence and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), to that concern which, as I say, the PWC would have looked into had it been given a chance.

Finally, I reiterate that we support the upgrading of our nation's surveillance and intelligence facilities, and whilst we agree with the concern expressed by the Chairman of the PWC in the circumstances of this case, we will not stand in the way of a declaration of urgency and we welcome the fact that the work will be contracted to the private sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and Acting Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government appreciates the fact that the Opposition does not oppose this declaration of urgency, and understands the circumstances involved. I give the Opposition a guarantee from the Government that it was not trying to get around the processes of the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works. Having just been a backbencher and having been involved in the work of parliamentary committees, I can assure the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) that I would never attempt to get around the work of committees such as the Public Works Committee. This matter was referred to the Public Works Committee on 2 April and it was just a factor of the election. We are not trying to blame anyone. It is a fact that this matter was referred to the Committee on 2 April. The Committee did not have time to consider it and I apologise to the Chairman of the Committee for there not being sufficient time to enable the Committee to examine it. But I understand that, as a courtesy, my Department will be briefing the Public Works Committee in the morning and will go through the project in some detail.

SPEECH.PARA: I also appreciate the support from the Opposition given to the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar system project. It is one of the most exciting systems I am involved in in the defence science and technology area of my portfolio. The work that has been done in this area by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) is world class and it is to be congratulated. I often think of the DSTO as the secret weapon in our defence bureaucracy because so much of the work that is being done in our laboratory is world class and deserves a lot of praise. Foremost is the over-the-horizon radar system. This radar system will be an integral part of northern surveillance.

I take the point that has been raised by speakers for the Opposition about the need to integrate our defence role with the work of the Australian Customs Service and the police. This work will obviously have a primary role in the defence and intelligence area. At the moment discussions are proceeding about ways that Jindalee can help in civilian areas, the Customs area and the police area. It is a very exciting project and honourable members should be aware of the way it will operate. Currently we are attempting to develop a network of radars. As I have said, they are absolutely first class. The basic network of radars around the top of Australia will be the essential element in the national system of air defence and airspace control. Primarily, Jindalee will be established for intelligence and surveillance but discussions are under way on how it can assist in civilian areas.

Before I conclude, I want to take up one point that was made by my colleague the Chairman of the Committee. Why was a contract let prior to the work being examined by the Committee? Basically these works are only a very small element of the overall upgraded facility; they will cost only $8.2m out of $57.5m. It was necessary to renew an existing major maintenance contract which expired at the end of 1986. This contract, along with others involving software which had very long gestation periods, was let to enable the project to become fully operational by 1990. I appreciate the support and the comments from the Opposition. I think we can look forward to a very exciting project, one of which Australia, and particularly my organisation, the DSTO, can be very proud.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a message from the Senate acquainting the House of the appointment of the following senators to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters: Senators Beahan, Coulter, Harradine, Schacht and Short. I also inform the House of the following nomination of honourable members to be members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters: Mr Lee, Ms Jakobsen and Mr Punch have been nominated by the Government Whip; Mr Shack has been nominated by the Opposition Whip; and Mr Blunt has been nominated by the National Party of Australia Whip.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was interrupted, I was talking about petrol prices. It was said to me during the interval that I had underestimated the price of petrol in Canberra. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), is again in the chamber; I am sorry that she is always present when I speak on this subject. I have been told that the petrol price in Canberra is about the same as it normally is in Tasmania. I repeat that in Tasmania at the moment there is a petrol price war so the price is down to about 52c a litre in Hobart. I usually get the daily paper-the Hobart Mercury-which I read from cover to cover to find out all the news and to keep in tune with what is happening in Franklin, Tasmania.
—How long does that take you to read, two minutes?

—It does not take me long. To read the Canberra Times would take less time. The Hobart Mercury, which is a very good paper, had the headline `Petrusma cautious on petrol price war'. Mr Petrusma is a member of the Legislative Council-I never run other politicians down unless they are present when I speak-and is quite a decent fellow. There was an inquiry into the price of petrol in Tasmania and it went over the same old thing again. Canberra also has such an inquiry at the moment which I imagine was initiated by the honourable member for Canberra. The poor old Canberra people will be told why the price of petrol in Canberra is a lot dearer than it is in Sydney and that it is much dearer than in Melbourne. It is the same old thing and it goes on and on. The article in the Mercury stated:

SPEECH.PARA: While Hobart motorists are cashing in on the benefits of the petrol price war, they will be no better off than when it started once the dust settles, it was claimed yesterday.

That is exactly what I said last night. There will be a price war for a little while and then all of a sudden prices will settle down, the poor dealers will lose a few dollars and the poor motorists, with their raised hopes of getting something cheap, will have them dashed again. The article continued:

Mr Hank Petrusma (MLC, Hobart) raised the issue of petrol prices as a matter of urgency in the Legislative Council, saying that the chaotic situation which had developed recently had destabilised the whole retail petrol industry questioning its continued viability.
Criticising the higher wholesale petrol prices Tasmania has to pay . . .

Mr Petrusma should know. I made the point this morning that the Prices Surveillance Authority fixes a maximum wholesale price for petrol in every capital city, including Canberra and Hobart, and the figure does not vary very much. Actually, it is about the same; it is about 51.2c a litre. As the oil companies say, market forces then come into play. In a heavily populated area such as Sydney or Melbourne where they can get rid of a bit of petrol-the word dumping is used-they drop the price. So the maximum wholesale price is a fictitious price and that is the reason why I continually criticise the Prices Surveillance Authority. It fixes a maximum wholesale price. It is set up by the Government, by the taxpayers of Australia, to be a watchdog, to look at the margins and the retail and wholesale prices in Australia but it does not do its job. That is the reason why at the last election I supported getting rid of the Prices Surveillance Authority and setting up some other authority, or having some mechanism, whereby everybody in Australia would get a fair and respectable go. We have inquiries-one is now being conducted in Canberra-which go on and on but what happens when the dust settles down again? The people of Canberra will be paying a much higher price for petrol than people in Melbourne and Sydney pay. That is enough about the marketing side of petrol.

Let me get back to what the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Legislation Amendment Bill is all about. Speakers have had a wide-ranging debate on this Bill, Mr Deputy Speaker, so I am not taking advantage of your noble looks and good nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been watching the debate, though.

—I realise that. I said that I supported some of the things that the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) said today. Regrettably, we need exploration in Australia; we need oil companies because they provide employment and we need the structure of their industry to supply petrol to dealers, et cetera. We definitely need exploration and that is the critical point: there has been a decline in exploration. I compliment the shadow Minister for science and energy, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), who did a very good job today. He spoke for 30 minutes and detailed the problems associated with exploration in this country. When the Fraser Government introduced import parity pricing many people, including me, questioned it because all of a sudden the price of petrol went from being low to being very high. Everybody started talking about the increased costs of transportation, the increased cost of goods and many other things. We had to do it, but we put a few question marks on it. We said that this was for future exploration, for looking for alternatives and for making certain that we would be self-sufficient in the long term. At the time we said that we thought we would be self-sufficient by 1990-three years off. But we will not be self-sufficient by that date; we are still only about 70 per cent self-sufficient. I supported that step because I thought that it would mean we would not have to depend on some Arab countries and other countries throughout the world for our supply of petrol. The supply of oil is always volatile. I have just been handed an article which is headed `The Coming Oil Drought' by Peter Gill. That is interesting. There is an oil drought and we must be aware of it. I am stressing the point that by the year 1990 we thought that we would be self-sufficient in oil. We all subscribed to import parity pricing because of that. We all tolerated that tremendous increase in the price of petrol and liquefied petroleum gas because of that. But we will not be self-sufficient, therefore the Government must have a good look at its policies.

SPEECH.PARA: I keep harking back to comments made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Year after year in opposition he kept saying that import parity pricing was taxation by stealth at the petrol pump. During that wonderful campaign when the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) came to power, he kept telling us that his Government would reduce the price of petrol by 3c a litre. But he could not do that. He could not do it because the Government needed that revenue. It needed it then and it still needs it now. That is the reason why the price of petrol has gone up by an average of 13c a litre since this Government came into power. Government members cannot deny that. That is why they go crook at me. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) said that I had not done anything about the price of petrol. At least I have tried, year after year, to draw attention to the problems of this industry. I have often said that it is complex, difficult and hard to unravel. Several years ago I made a suggestion. We have the Prices Surveillance Authority and we have had other inquiries ad infinitum to try to resolve this problem but we never seem to be able to clear it up. Yet backbenchers such as I, who have been here for a long time, get involved in all the activities pertaining to this House. We get involved in committees. Some get involved in the more fashionable committees. They think that they are great--

TALK.START.PARA: —What are we talking about?

—I will come back to the point in a moment. The Minister should not worry about me; I always come back to the point. I suggested that we could have set up a committee in this Parliament-a bipartisan committee-to look into the pricing of petrol in this country. We could have resolved the problem. We could have satisfied the people of Canberra that they were not paying too much for their petrol. There has been a hue and cry that they should have paid far less, as they did for their home heating oil and so on. We could have looked into all this in a bipartisan way. We could have had two or three members from the Government benches and two or three from the Opposition--
—You should have been the chairman. You are the most knowledgeable man on petrol in the world, not just in Australia.
—I know that. The honourable member does not have to tell me that. He is a very good member too.
—I am trying to tell those other fellows.

—I only wish this debate was being broadcast today. That sort of publicity would help me in Tasmania. The honourable member for Denison had better be aware of that because everyone in Tasmania knows me and I have not started on him yet. One day I will. The Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding) was in Tasmania the other day and had a very good reception--
—We will carve him up.

—Yes, we will carve him up. Had the Government adopted my suggestion we may have been able to resolve this problem. We could have participated in trying to overcome some of the problems that regrettably have occurred within this industry. We may have been able to save some of the poor retailers, the people who are heavily involved, from some of the problems associated with this industry. This is a complex industry. We need exploration and we need oil companies. But at least we should direct our attention to trying to overcome some of the marketing problems involved and make certain that the people of Australia, who are paying so much in taxation for exploration and for petrol, are getting their money's worth. By doing that we will make it better for everyone concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who has just resumed his seat, has made some very interesting observations about the petroleum industry. However, I think we ought to place on record that it was the Fraser Government that introduced import parity pricing. I wish to make sure that this is clear. One of the reasons why import parity pricing was put to this Parliament, and finally accepted by the Government and the Parliament, was that we needed to ensure that Australian petroleum explorers would be encouraged to find new reserves and, if they found them, were able to market them at a reasonable, competitive price. That meant that in some way we had to put up the price of imported products. If we had not done that and if we had changed overnight there was not only the problem for the explorer but also the problem for the hundreds of people who were involved in the oil industry generally. I think particularly of those people who are part of the industry which processes the crude oil to the point of it becoming fuel.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Franklin also made comments about the increases that have taken place in the price of fuel. He castigated the Hawke Government. In his contribution he did not bother to say that there had been something like nine reductions in the price of fuel in the last four years. But regrettably these reductions were not passed on by the industry. When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) first came to power he said that he would bring down the price of fuel and he did. But we have been caught up with import parity pricing introduced by the previous Government and we are caught up with the demands and costs carried by the industry itself.

I wish to place one set of statistics on the record. When the Fraser Government came to power the wholesale price of fuel-this goes back to 1975-was 13c a litre. When the Fraser Government left power in 1983 the price had risen to 38c-a 25c a litre increase. I heard the honourable member for Franklin say earlier that the wholesale price of fuel in the capital cities is now around 50c a litre. In some seven to eight years under the Fraser Government we had a 25c a litre increase and in the last five years under the Hawke Government we have had an increase of 12c. I really think that we are trying to keep the price down and we have done well.

I will now come back to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Legislation Amendment Bill. As the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) explained in his second reading speech, this Bill proposes a number of amendments which will improve the administration of petroleum exploration and development activities in Australian off-shore waters. I believe that it is important that administrative decisions can be made without unnecessary hold up. One of the amendments in this Bill will give the Commonwealth Minister power to decide a matter if there is prolonged disagreement on it. I know that there is a joint agreement with Western Australia. I understand that the Minister has said that Western Australia should not be given a privileged position, that it ought to be in the same sort of position as other States-and I know you have a special interest in this, Mr Deputy Speaker. Whilst there has to be consultation and co-operation and whilst the joint authority should be used to the maximum, if there is prolonged disagreement someone has to make a decision. I think that as we have many other joint authorities involving the States and the Commonwealth, the buck has to stop somewhere. In this instance the buck must stop with the Commonwealth. It is in the national interest that the Commonwealth bears the decision finally and bears the buck.

There are also other amendments which will streamline the decision-making process and this is surely necessary. A few years ago there was a review which found there were anomalies. There were hang-ups or hold-ups within the decision-making process, particularly as they related to the awarding of exploration permits. There were other anomalies that really created some difficulties when it came to the declaration of locations and the size of locations in certain circumstances. These circumstances were such that they could actually frustrate the development of an oil discovery. The Minister clearly explained those circumstances when he made his second reading speech. We know that industry everywhere is looking to cut the unnecessary red tape, to remove those problems and those barriers in the decision-making process, to remove the inappropriate bureaucratic rules that can make life in the market-place so often unnecessarily difficult. This legislation is going down that track, to resolve those anomalies. I am pleased that the Opposition is supporting the proposals in principle.

I readily support the proposition; I think that there are too many rules in the market-place. There is too much paper warfare. There are too many reports to be made to government at every level. There are too many records to be kept. We need constantly to review the requirements that we place on business. The Hawke Government has taken the initiative. It has given the lead. In my own State of Queensland there has been a promise to review the quasi-autonomous non-government organisations. There are almost a thousand of them. Some meet only a couple of times a year. They gather up reports and information from all the elements within the market-place, be it the rural sector or the commercial sector. These rules and regulations virtually control the life or quality of life of commercial enterprise. They control almost every aspect of industrial life. So we have to review them constantly.

If the rules and regulations are in the interests of product safety, in the national interest or in the interests of creating competition and ensuring that competition prevails, I have no argument with them but where they are unnecessary or over-costly we need to review them. There is a need for governments at every level-local, State and Federal-constantly to wind down this `rules mania', as it can be described. There is a need for departments to rethink the delegated powers they have accumulated. They keep bringing down regulation after regulation. Somehow we have to put a stop to what is taking place. There is almost a rush by every department wanting to bring down more rules. It has to be a two-way street. Therein lies the importance of this Bill.

Whilst governments must listen to industry and must loosen up in the system, so must industry rethink its own rules. I refer to the petroleum industry. We certainly need some explanations. I agree with the honourable member for Franklin and the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) that we need to have a hard look again at the petroleum industry as it affects the retailers, in other words, the service station proprietors, and the consumers. We need to get some explanations about the cost structures that prevail within our community. To come back to my local area, central Queensland is supposed to charge only 1c more for petrol than the capital city of Brisbane. That is the margin. Yet prices can vary by as much as 10c a litre. During price wars in Brisbane the price can be as low as 40c a litre. In Rockhampton it can be as high as 59c a litre. A week later in Rockhampton can be selling petrol at 46c a litre.

Whilst that takes place all the time, in country areas, my rural areas, the price can still be as high as 64c a litre. We question why. If the oil companies can sell to independents and jobbers at a price 10c below the normal wholesale price day in and day out, week in week out, throughout the year, why can there not be an across the board drop? When one talks to the companies they say that the reason they bring down the price sometimes is that there is an oversupply. I do not believe that is true. These wars happen at any time. There are price escalations at any time.

It boggles my mind to think of what the oil companies must make. They increased the price of fuel in Sydney overnight by 10c a litre. I wonder what that meant for the oil companies' coffers. Yet whilst these wars take place at any time, the independents are out there buying at a cut rate year in year out, all the year round, and the oil companies' selected sites are selling at cut rate prices. These are usually independents, where the jobbers have a say, or they are sites owned by the companies. Again the price can be as much as 10c a litre cheaper than the normal market price in capital and provincial cities and sometimes 15c or 16c a litre cheaper than the price in some country areas.

The free enterprise service stations however, the ones in the cities and not owned by oil companies, constantly get squeezed and screwed by the companies which force them sometimes to operate on a margin of less than 2c a litre. I have done some work on it. I have talked with the proprietors. There is no way they can operate on much less than 6c a litre, that is, meeting the cost of money, paying wages, and paying the lease back to the oil companies.

The retailers are caught up in another serious situation. They have to pay cash up front for every litre of fuel they get from the oil companies. If they buy 200,000 litres a month, as some of them can-I know that some of them buy only 50,000 litres, but many of the big sites buy 200,000 litres a month-they have to pay cash when the fuel is delivered. But not so for the jobbers, the independents. These fellows are given 60 days credit, and they are getting away with it. I know that many of them make a lot of money on the short term money market, especially when then can buy at 10c a litre less.

The fellow leasing the service station is worse off still. There is supposed to be a law that those who have their own service stations are allowed to buy at least 50 per cent of their fuel requirements from an alternative supplier. So a Shell service station can buy half from Ampol. But, whilst the rule in law says that is so, the rule in practice prevents it. The oil company which owns and leases the site says, `You buy what you like but don't put it through our bowsers, don't store it in our tanks'. It is a stupid rule that ought to be changed. I go back to this point: if the companies want deregulation, if they want a loosening up of the market to take away the bureaucratic inhibitions that prevail, let them also come back to fairness, to equality, as to the rules they lock their suppliers into.

In this country, oil companies control everything the proprietor does, whether it be in regard to the fuel he buys, the quantity he buys, the rebate he gets or the price he sells it at. Yet we are supposed to be talking about free enterprise. Despite the fact that proprietors lease the premises, the site, they have to buy through that company and have their fuel transported by that company.

In central Queensland recently a proprietor told me-this case involves the Shell Co. of Australia Ltd; I do not mind naming the company-that he has to pay 6c a litre to get his fuel transported just under 250 kilometres to his petrol station. He also said that if he could deliver it himself he could bring down the transport cost to a little over 1c a litre and that he would be prepared to pass that saving on to the consumer. I asked him why he did not do so. He said that he did not do so because the oil company, Shell, did not let him. The oil company has locked him in to a monopoly situation. Not only must he buy its fuel, but also it must be transported at the company's price. Yet companies talk about competition and free enterprise. It is baloney. It does not really exist.

The time has come to stop the rip off of people in rural towns and the huge mark-up these companies have. They rip off rural consumers because no competition prevails. Rural consumers pay 64.9c for fuel a little under 250 kilometres from a major provincial city, half the distance from the capital city of Brisbane where, I reiterate, the additional transport cost is supposed to be 1c a litre. Yet for half the distance they are charged 6c a litre.

I said before that there is a need for a two-way street. That has to be the approach to the rules which certainly inhibit those in the market-place, those at the retailing level. I welcome these amendments, which are going to help the petroleum explorers, but the same explorers in the wholesaling and refining industry have a responsibility to get their own house in order. They have created havoc within the petroleum retail industry. Some time back we had about 2,500 service stations. We are now down to about 1,500. The estimates given to me by the motor traders industry association, which the service stations belong to, are that before long we will have a cut of about a third in the number of proprietors. They will be cut back to around 1,000.

Some time back the service station industry in Queensland was employing 12,000 people. I am now told that it employs about 5,000. Where once seven or eight people would work at a service station, in so many instances today it is a husband and wife operation, working many hours. In some cases, as one fellow said, people are working 19 or 20 hours a day. They have to do that because the mark-up has been brought down to 2c and 3c a litre. Why? Because the oil companies are playing a game whereby their selected stations, their selected jobbers and independents are getting special deals. There have been instances where the oil company owned site will drop the price overnight by 6c or 7c, and the war is on. What do the other oil companies do? They say to the proprietor `We will give you a 3c rebate but you will carry the other 3c', regardless of overheads and the cost of money. (Quorum formed)

As I was saying before the quorum was pulled on me, there are many service stations throughout the State of Queensland, and I suggest throughout Australia, that are at risk because of the rules and policies which have been put in place by the oil companies. Although they have come to the Government and said that they want to change the rules and want to loosen them up in order to free up the market-place, this must be a two-way street. They have to do the same for the consumers and also those in the retailing industry. There are people at risk, people who have invested tens of thousands of dollars, in some cases hundreds of thousands of dollars, who face losing that investment because of the policies, rules and tactics of the oil companies in which a false price war is created.

I ask the question, which must be answered: If the oil companies can cut the price of fuel by 10c a litre and sell to independents and jobbers on a regular basis throughout the year, why can they not make a reduction across the board so that every Australian consumer benefits? Let them come back to fair play. Let them set in place rules that are in the interests of private enterprise. Instead, the moment a person builds up a business, the oil companies increase the lease periods or when the expiry date arrives take away the leases. There must be a two-way street and rules that suit the total industry and also the nation. The oil industry stands condemned because of some of the tactics and policies it has used in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Queensland Government?

—The Queensland Government can be condemned on every level in this field, but at least it is trying to bring in a consumer price that is fair to everybody. There have been negotiations with the Queensland Government and the Motor Traders Association to try to set down a fair margin. I believe that that margin is about 6c a litre, but some operators are trying to work on 2c a litre. It is simply impossible. Although I support the amendments to the Act, I say to the oil companies that it is time that they also played the game. That will happen only when they start considering their responsibilities to the retailers who make the industry viable and who keep the oil companies alive. Without the retailers, the oil companies would not sell one litre of fuel.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House has just heard the usual rantings and ravings from the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) about the high cost of fuel, but he failed to say that since his own Labor Government has been in office it has increased the excise taxes on fuel from 6c to 20c a litre. That is a disgrace, and that is the area on which he should be concentrating his rhetoric. I would also remind him and his colleagues that Queensland is the only State that does not impose any State taxes on fuel. The Queensland Government makes every effort not to tax the fuel users, as this Labor Government does.

SPEECH.PARA: It is well known that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) brought in the concept of using the petrol bowser as a tax, and he, as Treasurer, has done nothing but adopt that course since he has been in government. Over 60 per cent of the price of every litre of fuel the motorist buys goes to the Commonwealth in taxation in some form or another. Yet the Federal Government is now seeking to introduce yet another tax on petroleum-because that is what it is, an indirect tax. Cash bidding for leases involves an amount of money which this Government is asking the private oil exploration companies to put up in tender form. So far, this Government has collected about $30m in indirect taxation from the companies in order to do this. Yet Australia today is facing a crisis in its economy. Oil is one of the major ingredients of our economy. We have seen falls in the price of the shares of oil companies which are involved in exploration for this essential raw product, a product that we need to remain self-sufficient. For example, the price of shares in Santos Ltd, one of the major Australian exploration companies, has dropped $1.30 down to $5. Ampol Petroleum Ltd is an original Australian company that was set up to look for, refine and retail petroleum in this nation, and its price has fallen by $1.10. Those companies are in a much weakened position in raising capital and going out and looking for new product.

This Government has put this country in an horrendous trade position. In Question Time Ministers mentioned the situation in the United States of America. If one does one's figures, as the Treasurer should, one will see that, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was trying to explain to him today, proportionally the United States is in no worse position than Australia is in terms of trade. Our trade imbalance is running per year at the rate at which the United States figure is running per month; in percentage terms the position is exactly the same. We are in the horrendous position that, having found crude oil in Australia some 25 to 30 years ago, we are now starting to run out of that resource. If Australia has to import large quantities of crude again, we will be paying out between $2 billion and $4 billion in import costs. In view of our present balance of payments position, such a prospect will make our financial position even more horrendous. Yet the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and the Government are seeking today to reintroduce yet another tax on this industry, an industry which is so important to us all.
