I remind the House that I have a number of oil provinces in my electorate. Unfortunately, Maranoa does not front the sea, so I am not involved in off-shore exploration. However, I represent the Cooper Basin, which is a very large area of about the size of Victoria in the western part of my electorate, where the Jackson oil field is situated. That is the only on-shore oil field paying royalties. Indeed, it is the only on-shore oil field producing sufficient oil to be in the royalty regime but it pays royalties to both Federal and State governments. I am not keen on such companies paying any direct taxes. Enough is being raked out of companies these days, with tax at 49c in the dollar, for them to pay their fair share of tax at company level without burdening them with taxes up front and taxes on inputs.

Another area is Roma, where the first discovery of oil in Australia was made. That is probably a larger gas producing area. Unfortunately, the explorers have not found too much crude. They have found quite a deal of concentrate and gas, which is converted and sent mainly to Sydney and Melbourne, to the bigger industrial areas, for use. Moonie, which was the first commercial oil field in Australia, is within sight of where I live. So I have had a long-standing interest in this industry, and that is why I continue to take such an interest.

I believe this industry has been totally overtaxed. The regime that was put in place by a previous government was very wrong. I have said so for many years. We still have a resource rent tax on oil that is bringing in roughly $1.2 billion-an upfront tax on the industry which ought to be abolished, and I will not be satisfied until it is abolished. It is a total distortion of our taxing and business regime to continue to tax this industry up front. It should not be done that way. The same applies to the excessive tax placed on coal. It should be abolished as well.

I support the announcements of the Government and the new Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) in wishing to deregulate the industry. I disagree with the honourable member for Capricornia, who raves and rants about prices. There is nothing like a bit of competition to bring down the price of anything. The less regulation and government control on the industry, the better. The oil industry is like the communications industry and some other industries, such as the wheat industry, in which I am a grower-they are totally controlled by government regulation. The oil industry cannot ship oil without a pricing arrangement and neither can the refineries operate. There is very little free movement of the product around Australia. It has to go where it is directed. There is a whole regime of pricing arrangements. Deregulation should take place now that the dollar has been floated and, therefore, there is not the opportunity, as there was previously, for international companies to transfer profits overseas at an advantage to them-which they were doing in pretty big licks, although a lot of that has stopped. Our dollar is supposedly free floating, although it is not quite as free a float as we would like to see it. The Reserve Bank of Australia made a profit last year of $2.5 billion in trying to float the dollar. In other words, it is a fairly firm float. It sits on top of the Reserve Bank, but at least it is freer than it was.

The other thing that is of great concern to us is the drop in the world price of oil. This is coming down because of the slump in oil shares. Oil dropped US39c yesterday; it is now down to $US19.83c per barrel. Unfortunately, the Middle East is now the main hot spot in the world, and that is one of the reasons for the fall in share prices. If the Americans and the Iranians, in other words, the Russians, who are backing Iran, start to blow battleships out of the water-at the moment they are really just zapping the odd oil derrick-we will see a rapid increase in the price of fuel and in the price of any oil which we import. We continue to import oil because we do not produce the heavy crudes. We will find that that will severely affect our trade balance once again, and force the deficit up.

These are the main parameters and the main reasons why I believe we should not be supporting these Bills, which seek to put this cash bidding regime in place. When companies are looking for oil, the first thing that governments do is offer an exploration licence. The companies have permits to explore. The geologists told us for many years that there was no oil in Australia, but the Government actually encouraged oil companies to come here. It used to pay them a dollar for dollar subsidy-a 100 per cent subsidy-to find the first oil reserves in Australia. Now we see the complete opposite. Governments are now greedy for the taxes involved and are ripping the taxes out of anybody who wishes to produce anything up front in this country. We see the greed of the Government in wishing to tax this industry yet again under this legislation.

I believe we should continue to encourage companies to come from all around the world to look for this product. We should not be charging them for the privilege; most other countries do not, although some do. This sort of bidding does take place, for instance, in respect of the off-shore leases in Alaska. Companies there pay some horrendous prices for particular oil province leases, but they are very rich leases. In Australia a company initially has to put up a bid, with the risk of not knowing what is there. Having found a product, it then has to get another licence from the Government in order to produce. I do not see why governments should be involved in this sort of taxing arrangement at all. A similar thing is being suggested with FM-frequency modulation-radio. There is not much correlation with the oil industry, but the same sort of thinking is running through the minds of the departmental officers or those in the Government and the Cabinet who have put these things up. They wish to start indirectly taxing radio operators by charging them an up front tender fee to get the licence.

I would have thought that the ideal in our system would be to encourage business to establish, to get it up and running and making a substantial profit, and then tax it. In that way we would not be in the situation we are in today, where we are wasting all our money and trying to collect more and more tax. Government expenditure is continuing to rise we are continuing to socialise ourselves and we are going down the gurgler, as happened yesterday, at a fast pace. This is the sort of economic exercise that we do not wish to be associated with.

Under this legislation, companies have to report back to governments on their statistics. But the oil companies have always had to do this. They log the holes with electric logging equipment, and in order to find out what is down them they take cores at every 200 or 300 feet. The cores are drilled out of rock, and are boxed up and usually sent to the State departments. They are kept there and this information is used for further exploration work. This practice will continue. Although this Bill says that it has to happen, it has been happening. There is a charge of a flat $300 for the repatriation of a transfer, so there is more red tape involved. That is really all it amounts to. These companies will have to employ two or three extra people to fill out the forms and to continue to abide by the regulations which this Bill lays down. We on this side of the House believe that the Government should be getting out of these sorts of areas.

The other thing we wonder about is what the Australian Democrats might do. They are fairly hypocritical in some of their actions in the way they vote in the Senate. This Bill has to get through. The Democrats were against the cash bidding and proposed the two-year sunset clause in 1985 for the area in the Ashmore and Cartier fields. They now appear to be supporting the Government-they must be, otherwise the Government would not be going to the trouble of putting the Bill through-and will allow this new tax to go through the Senate.

Another matter that should be of interest to the Government is an article in the latest Bulletin, of 27 October, headed `The Coming Oil Drought-Painful energy decisions ahead for government', written by journalist Peter Gill. I will read from a couple of sections and then ask the Minister at the table, the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), whether they may be incorporated in Hansard. This article, in the Business and Investment section of this notable Australian journal, states:

Australia is running out of oil. The country's premier oil province, Bass Strait, is simply drying up. It is a geological fact yet to be fully addressed in any co-ordinated fashion by the federal government and a phenomenon hardly appreciated by the general public.

I suppose that is understandable because the general public would not really know and understand that 80 per cent of our oil production comes from Bass Strait. It is by far and away the biggest oil field in Australia and we depend practically totally on that oil field for our oil needs. The workers do an excellent job off-shore there. Esso Australia Ltd and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd have put an enormous amount of money into this facility to allow us to become self-sufficient in our oil needs. The workers do an excellent job off-shore there. Esso Australia Ltd and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd have put an enormous amount of money into this facility to allow us to become self-sufficient in our oil needs. We actually export up to $2 billion worth of oil, although we continue to import the heavy crudes that are needed because we do not produce them in this country. The article goes on to state:

Crude oil self-sufficiency will dive from the present level of about 90 per cent to less than half that amount and Australia will be left facing the inherent danger of being dependent on foreign oil, the most likely source of which being the volatile Middle East.
I mentioned that fact in my opening remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Heaven forbid.

—Yes, heaven forbid. If the rockets start flying there and sinking the oil tankers, we can imagine to what level the price of oil will go. Previously, when we have run out of oil, Indonesia and the Middle East have been our main sources and I imagine that is where we would go back to because they have fields that supply the light crude oil that the refineries in Australia are set up to handle and that they need to refine it into the diesel and petrol that we basically use in this country in order to produce our raw exports, the wool and wheat et cetera, that are so badly needed if we are to maintain our standard of living.

SPEECH.PARA: Central to the explorers' argument is that this measure represents secondary taxation on top of the normal company taxation, which I have already mentioned. This Government is not happy enough to be taxing the companies at 49c in the dollar, which is about half. Then there is the capital gains tax. If one buys and sells a piece of capital, the capital gains tax applies. This will affect the oil industry and the sale of these leases. Every time a company makes a sale transaction, practically half-I am not saying exactly half-of any profit made will be paid in capital gains tax. That is over and above the company tax, and the personal tax that is paid on the wages earned. Now we have the resource rent tax proposed in this Bill. The article goes on to state:
. . . secondary taxation . . . is an impediment to exploration, particularly in a country where the prospectivity for oil is low compared to the rest of the world.

That is very true because we are one of the last major countries of the world to find oil. Now that we have found it, we continue to look for it. The companies that operate in my electorate, for instance, in the Cooper Basin and the Channel Country, have enormous problems. They are faced with looking for this product in the far outback of Queensland. Of course, they have to spend inordinate amounts of money to find it. Then, of course, no sooner do they find it than governments, both Federal and State, start taxing them for the privilege of having gone to all that trouble and having found a product that we all really need. In this legislation they are being asked to pay tax. But, worse than that, before they even get to the stage of looking for the product, this iniquitous type of cash bidding is to be put into place.

We have heard all about the wealth tax that the screaming lefties in the Australian Labor Party are on about. But, of all the taxes that the industry has to face, this has to be the worst. Of course, it is the multinationals, the so-called wealthy people that the left is so concerned about, who have the money and who will put it up front to get these leases. Australian companies will find it very difficult to fill up their envelopes with enough cash to be able to buy one of these leases. I have much pleasure in opposing this Bill. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to have the material that I mentioned earlier incorporated in Hansard.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL(No. 2) 1987MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 September, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill cognately with the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be proposing amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987 which we are debating cognately this evening. Two of those amendments deal with the Government's attempts to alter the existing procedures whereby the current income tax scales are presented to Parliament on an annual basis. The Government seeks to institute those income taxation rates, including the Medicare levy, as a standing order. The Bill proposes that they will be reintroduced to Parliament only when those rate scales change. The Opposition disagrees with that.

SPEECH.PARA: First, the Opposition is moving amendments to clauses 4, 5 and 6 of the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) and clause 11 of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, to bring both pieces of legislation back to the traditional basis of annual imposition Bills. Secondly, we wish to move an amendment to clause 8 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). Clause 8 proposes the insertion of a new section, section 46e, in the Income Tax Assessment Act to counter certain schemes involving the payment of dividends out of profits arising from the revaluation of assets. Similar proposals were originally announced in earlier legislation brought before the House on 4 June 1987. That Bill was passed over due to the election. It is proposed in the current Bill that the same date, 4 June, still apply for the application of the new section 46e. Nevertheless, a careful reading reveals that the proposals put forward in the legislation before us are not the same as those detailed in the earlier Bill. We will, therefore, be seeking to avoid the retrospective nature of these changes by moving forward the effectiveness of this part of the legislation to 23 September 1987, the date on which this legislation was introduced to the Parliament.

I will leave a detailed discussion of this amendment to the committee stage of this debate so that I may concentrate on the broader aspects of these three Bills, one of which is an attempt to deny the annual review of tax scales by the Parliament. It may be argued that the Government is simply proposing to put the legislation for income tax on the same basis as most other tax law, that is, subject to standing legislation. Nevertheless, we consider that because income tax represents well over 60 per cent of the total receipts of the Commonwealth Government and that a large proportion of that is embodied in the legislation before us, there is a case for treating this legislation on a different basis. The life blood of government is, after all, supplied through these sorts of Bills. The Opposition would be failing in its duty to uphold the supremacy of Parliament to allow such an enormously important means of debating government policy just to disappear.

The Executive, that is, the Government, is answerable, after all, to the Parliament. It is the responsibility of Parliament to conduct a thorough debate to make the Australian community cognisant of the ongoing policies of the incumbent executive. We are not prepared to allow that executive arm of government to ride roughshod over the Parliament. The Government wants to deprive the people of Australia of a continuing opportunity for their chosen representatives to debate the very essentials of government.

There is much in these tax Bills that needs airing. The Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) seeks formally to impose the tax payable on the basis of the new rate scales announced in the September 1985 tax reform package. However, to call that package one of tax reform certainly seems a deep misrepresentation. I thought tax reform was all about achieving efficiency, simplicity and equity. If this is simplicity and equity, the Australian taxpayer must be wondering whether the definitions in the dictionary have been changed.

Let us examine a few aspects of the Government's so-called reforms. The company tax rate has been increased from 46c in the dollar to 49c. In the second reading speech on the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) the Government argues that this helps to defray the cost of the new imputation system. However, more accurately, the Government has used the opportunity to set the corporate rate at the same level as the top marginal personal income tax rate. But where is the forethought in raising the corporate tax rate? If anything, a 49c top personal income tax rate is itself too high. We should be bringing that down rather than raising the company rate to match it.

Some commentators argue that our effective corporate tax rate is much in line with those in other countries such as the United States, where there is a rate of 34 per cent because of the large concessions provided through such devices as the depreciation allowance. However, when it comes to business, as well as politics, perceptions play a major role. A foreign investor, or even just the homegrown variety, will look at the United States rate, the Hong Kong rate, the Singaporean rate and then the Australian rate. Forty-nine cents in the dollar does not look all that attractive. At a time when Australia is facing an enormous adjustment task to cope with a foreign debt of $83 billion-Labor's well-known debt-this Government raises the corporate tax rate.

I recognise that in the Budget there is an undertaking to institute a review of corporate taxation. One hears from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in forums outside that this will bring about a reduction in the corporate rate and, of course, the cessation of various concessions that apply to business at the moment. I assume that when that rate is brought down it will be a real competitive rate on the international playing field of taxation, so that investment in this country will become more attractive. I recognise that it is not just the rate of taxation that is denying the opportunity for investment to be made more attractive. I think the three fundamental areas are: high rates of taxation, the uncertainty over labour costs, and high interest rates. But the tax factor is there. Of course, when that tax rate does come down I assume that the personal rate will be coming down as well, because it hardly seems likely that we would structure a significantly reduced corporate rate and allow tax avoidance through the ability of individual taxpayers to incorporate.

This therefore poses the question: Why on earth, with all the opportunities that were missed in the Budget, did the Government increase the tax rate to 49c and undertake a review in the Budget while recognising that it will be substantially reducing that rate? Sure it brings the Government more revenue, but it denies that incentive factor to people who would have been looking for opportunities to invest in Australia. It is just another lost opportunity. The Government talks about tax reform and tax relief while in fact it lifts a rate rather than giving such relief. I recognise that relief is coming, but, again, it is a classic example of not thinking through the consequences of the action to lift the corporate rate to 49c and then shortly thereafter, at the end of the review, to reduce it. So much for certainty in tax rates under this Government. As I said, at a time when Australia is facing an enormous adjustment task to cope with a foreign debt of $83 billion the Government raises the corporate tax rate. No wonder Senator Peter Walsh talks about the road to Argentina. The Government missed a golden opportunity in the September Budget to quicken the pace of economic adjustment and to set in place the policies to facilitate business investment. Instead, as I have indicated, the Government raised the corporate tax rate. Obviously little forethought has been put into this policy. This is a tired government thrashing around in the dark, unable to do the job correctly.

Let us look at one of the other Bills being debated today. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is full of revisions to Labor's previous legislation. The Government brings in legislation, dumps more constraints and taxes on people, finds that the legislation is not working well enough and brings back more legislation to tighten and tighten further. The Bill is full of alterations to hastily prepared and obviously ill-considered legislation. Honourable members may care to note that the largest number of those revisions apply to the capital gains tax legislation. What a sorry state this tax legislation is in, and what a complicated burden the Government has placed on taxpayers. My office receives dozens of phone calls seeking clarification of and guidance on the capital gains tax laws. Those callers are not getting any satisfactory answers from the Treasury or the Australian Taxation Office. That is because not even the experts there are sure what to make of the Government's legislation. Because of the capital gains tax, uncertainties and, to use the dreaded phraseology that we have heard from the Government so often, `unintended consequences'-and thus injustices-abound.

It is enough for the Government to dump this capital gains tax on the Australian community and to come in here time and again talking about how it is hitting the wealthy. Honourable members opposite know they are not tackling those who have been paper shuffling and who have been able to amass significant sums of money. But their capital gains tax is striking at that body of people in the community who work extraordinarily hard and, let us say it frankly, who look for a decent return at the end of the day as a consequence of their exertions when they want to sell their businesses and get hit with a capital gains tax at a rate far above the rates struck elsewhere. The Government might be able to argue for the imposition of taxes to hit those who have made wealth beyond belief. I do not believe in a wealth tax, although honourable members opposite might. But a tax such as the capital gains tax, which honourable members opposite repeat so frequently is aimed at the wealthy, in fact strikes at the abundance of small business people in this community and denies again another incentive for further investment. But this holds pride of place in the Government's legislation.

I indicated that, with the capital gains tax uncertainties, the so-called unintended consequences and injustices abound. Just last week the Taxation Institute of Australia highlighted that one of the most serious deficiencies of the legislation is the inadequate provision for dealing with the roll-over of business assets. For example, a businessman intending to upgrade existing factory premises and move to new expanded premises will pay capital gains tax on the disposal of the old premises with no roll-over relief. There is no doubt that what is required in this nation is investment in business, investment in capital stock and investment in plant and equipment. But incentives necessary to bring that about are not contained in this sort of legislation.

The Treasurer forecast in the Budget an increase in investment in plant and equipment of only 3 per cent. He has since been careering around the world saying, `It could be significantly higher than that; it could reach 7 per cent or even 10 per cent', but he has been unable to substantiate that while the Budget says only 3 per cent. It is investment in plant and equipment that is the real engine for growth. It is what we are on about when we talk about forcing the pace of adjustment and moving resources from the public sector to give room to the private sector to bring about investment so that the economy can grow in a real fashion. But taxes such as these just deny that possibility. The example that I gave just a moment ago-that of a businessman wishing to upgrade his premises or move to new expanded premises and having to pay capital gains tax on the disposal of the old premises with no roll-over relief-moved the Tax Institute to say, and I agree with it, that the deficiency constitutes `a serious disincentive to business investment'.

There are a large number of revisions of the existing laws in the Bills before us, but the problem I have just mentioned is not properly addressed in them. We will obviously be seeing more legislation just like this in the House in coming years. Of course, the mess that has been made with the capital gains tax raises yet another spectre. I fear the day when the Government introduces-and I touched on this a moment ago-a wealth tax. I understand that all honourable members opposite, as socialists, believe in the redistribution of wealth. I also understand their desire to deny to the community, made up mainly of middle income Australians who strive to improve their lot, that they attach themselves any longer to the socialist philosophy. I also recognise that within the Australian Labor Party there are some who are holding true to the old principle and are concerned about the sort of wealth they see portrayed before them. I have some distaste also for some of the gross demonstrations of consumption that have occurred in this community, but at the same time I could not agree with a wealth tax. Yet I fear that the day is coming soon when the proposals of the Left, endorsed by the Centre Left, will be introduced into this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about an inquiry?

—I will deal with an inquiry in a moment, because I do understand that the Socialist Left is hankering for the opportunity to look into this. It is arguing daily for the establishment of a committee to review the distribution of wealth in this country. Why have a committee? Only a small number of individuals in this country have great wealth; the great bulk of Australians who are very comfortably well off, by world standards, make up the next group; and then there is a very large and significant number whom certainly we would call poor. No committee will cure their ills. I would have thought that the Left would know that as well. I believe the underlying motivation for such a committee is that it would provide a forum from which the Left could push for a wealth tax. The Left will argue that this new tax is the only way to redistribute income and help the needy. But what it will do is place disincentives on those much needed wealth creators in the community. I accept that much of the money that has gone through the stock exchange or has gone into takeovers has not created any real wealth-it has just changed ownership and substantially increased the alleged wealth of the people concerned-but the barriers that the Left would put down in the pursuit of a few people would be barriers to the real wealth creators, those who are really creating and doing in this country, who are the driving motivation for the sort of system that the majority of us on this side of the House warmly endorse.

SPEECH.PARA: We need not to place those disincentives in the face of our much needed wealth creators, but to focus on creating more wealth, which will inevitably benefit the whole community, rather than sniping at those who do create the wealth. The reason for so many poor people in this country is the high level of unemployment. If the Government really wants to help the poor, there is an absolute need, yet again, to quicken the pace of economic adjustment so that the level of unemployment can fall. A wealth tax will not solve any problems; it will only exacerbate the existing ones.

I am not so sure that the Hawke-Keating duo will allow the Labor Party to put forward a wealth tax. Just imagine how the old pork barrel Barrie Unsworth in New South Wales or John Cain in Victoria would squeal at such a thought in an election year. But that lies a little down the track. Just imagine what a mess the Government would make of such a tax when we look at the debacle of the investment-depressing capital gains tax or, for that matter, the foreign tax credits system. The Government talks a lot about trying to restore incentives which enable Australian firms to compete effectively in export markets, but instead it introduced the foreign tax credits system, which restricts the ability of Australian companies to expand overseas. This is because after paying tax in the foreign country of operation, the company is now subject to the high Australian corporate rate when bringing profits back home. Some incentive to return the profits to Australia! No wonder the Treasurer has initiated a review into business taxation. It is sorely needed.

Before I finish I want to highlight one other specific aspect of the changes in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). Clause 15 of the Bill seeks to replace the existing sections 108 and 109 of the Income Tax Assessment Act to remove certain technical deficiencies which have become apparent in the legislation's application. Sections 108 and 109 are designed to prevent the avoidance of tax by private companies and their shareholders through the use of disguised dividend distributions. In the case of section 108, this is done by enabling amounts to be deemed to be dividends where private companies make loans to their shareholders which are disguised dividend distributions, thereby avoiding tax at the shareholder level. Section 109 deals with the case where private companies pay excessive remuneration or retirement allowances to their shareholders and directors, and indeed their relatives, thus seeking to avoid taxation at the company level.

A basic deficiency in the provisions has been, as I understand it, that, except for the limited circumstances covered by section 109, they do not extend to payments made to associates of shareholders so that in such cases even though the shareholders may directly benefit, the provisions would not operate to deem the amounts involved to be dividends. Therefore, new legislation is being introduced to cover the instances where loans and reimbursements are made to associates of shareholders. I commend those amendments, and I see the worth and the logic of that element of the legislation and the Government's seeking to move on yet another tax avoidance scheme.

However, I do want to draw attention to the fact that there is some concern that the revisions to section 108, in particular, could result in a deal of uncertainty in the minds of those who are making what could be considered legitimate intercorporate loans-and there will be some of those-because the decision on what constitutes a legitimate or illegitimate use of loans is made at the discretion of the Commissioner of Taxation. I know that the tax Act is riddled with discretions, and of course many worthwhile arguments can be put forward as to why it is that the Tax Commissioner should have a discretion; therefore, putting the provisions in the new section under the discretion of the Commissioner is non-controversial. It occurs right throughout the tax legislation. Many would argue that there are too many instances of that, but often the case can be made for the discretion to be present. But the open-ended nature of the discretion in this case would appear to me, as would a number of others in the tax Act, to create uncertainty, and it may well hinder business investment. Therefore, I do ask that once the Bill is enacted, the Government request the Commissioner to draw up extensive guidelines as to what he expects will be covered by section 108.

I conclude by returning to the question of reinstating this legislation on an annual rather than on a standing basis. Obviously, from what I have said, there is much that can be criticised in, and raised in criticism of, the Government's taxation and general economic policies. It is the prerogative of the Parliament to review such vital policies annually. The Government must realise that there is no substitute for genuine economic debate, and taxation policy forms an integral component of economic policy. Of course, it forms more than an integral component of the Government's revenue raising, of the Government's budgetary policies. Instead of cutting expenditure, the Government has looked to get close to an alleged balanced Budget by seeking more and more revenue.

The heightened central element of taxation in Australia today under this big spending, high taxing Government, bears upon all that is happening in the economic sphere and it is present in the minds of many Australians. Forming the integral component of economic policy, as it does, the Government must surely realise that the high level of taxes and charges imposed on the Australian community really cannot be sustained. Because the Government has relied too much on tax collections instead of taking the hard decisions on expenditure reductions, the rate of adjustment is too slow. Every opportunity should be taken to recognise this deficiency, and the Government ought not be allowed to hide away its inadequacies by making these Bills standing legislation and therefore removing them from annual debate. As a consequence, the Opposition will be moving the amendment that I foreshadowed earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill represent yet another step by the Hawke Labor Government towards its goal of a fair and equitable taxation system. Despite the comments that were made by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), I believe that goal is represented by these Bills. The system which the Government is pursuing is one in which tax avoidance and evasion will not be tolerated; it is a system in which every income earning Australian pays his fair share of tax, no more and no less. This Government has already achieved a great deal in this area and it did so because it had the courage and determination to introduce such things as a capital gains tax, a fringe benefits tax and a whole range of other measures to stop the rorts that have been in existence in the Australian tax system for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also been able to deliver income tax cuts to every Australian. Most income tax paying Australians are pay as you earn taxpayers who have been shouldering the tax burden of this country for far too long. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong, made a number of points about this Government's commitment to tax reform. He said that the phrase `tax reform package' used to describe the measures the Government introduced after the National Taxation Summit was not a very true representation of what actually took place. I remind the honourable gentleman that following the tax debate, following consideration of the taxation package and following the decision of this Government to look at the whole question of tax reform, this Government was courageous in approaching the need to do something about the rorts in the system that had operated for so long.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has a short memory. When the Liberal-National Party Government was defeated in March 1983 it went out of office leaving the top marginal tax rate at 60c in the dollar. He now bemoans the fact that this Government, in two successive steps, was able to reduce that rate to 49c in the dollar. He did not mention in his contribution today that this Government was able not only to institute tax reform measures in the whole range of marginal tax rates but also to increase the threshold at which tax had to be paid. We introduced a range of measures and reduced the number of steps in marginal tax rates so that our tax system is much fairer and more equitable. It is one which everyone can understand.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition also touched on corporate tax rates. He was kind enough to acknowledge that the Government has signalled its intention to carry out a review of that issue. He also signalled his hope that this could also lead to further reductions in personal income tax. Of course, everyone would like to see those sorts of variations put in place if it meant that everyone was paying his fair share of taxation. On the other hand, if people for some reason are getting away with various lurks and perks, they are the ones who have to be picked up through corporate reviews or whatever the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has indicated he will take into consideration.

The honourable member for Kooyong also made some remarks about a reasonable investment environment. I pose the question to him: What, in his view, is a reasonable investment environment? Is he forgetting to talk about the interest rate regime that presently operates in this country? We acknowledge that prime lending rates were 21 or 22 per cent, but they have now gone down. All interest rates have trended downwards because of the sound economic policies that this Government has been able to put in place. When one couples that with taxation reviews, taxation package changes and the introduction of a range of other taxation initiatives which have cleaned up the tax system, I put it to the honourable member for Kooyong that the environment for investment has been developed.

However, what concerns me is some of the nonsense spoken about why the investment environment in Australia has not matched the investment environment of overseas countries. For example, it disturbs me, as a member who represents a steel making and coal mining region of Australia, that a number of significant national companies are not investing purely in Australia and perhaps diversifying their manufacturing base or looking at other areas in manufacturing that they could get into. Rather, they are prepared to invest overseas. I say to those companies that perhaps they should look again at the environment that has been created by this Government and reconsider the position that they have adopted to date. I am sure they would find that there are a number of opportunities in the investment environment created by the taxation measures to which we have referred in the Bills before us today, the interest rate regimes that have been put in place and the macroeconomic, and now microeconomic, policy that is being developed by this Government.

As was mentioned in the second reading speech by the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), the taxation Bills we are considering today will amend income tax laws to give effect to a number of early announcements that were made by the Treasurer and a number of Budget initiatives. I will quickly refer to some of those matters. For example, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill will introduce anti-avoidance provisions to combat dividend stripping operations that seek to exploit benefits provided under the imputation system. The honourable member for Kooyong, in his contribution, failed to mention imputation when he was talking about the effect that taxation regimes have on the business community and the investment environment. He failed to recognise or mention the important contribution that the imputation system will make for those companies, particularly the small business and the small investors on whom he was concentrating so much.

The Bill will specifically amend the Act to ensure that the intercorporate dividend rebate is limited or denied in cases where a dividend stripping operation gives rise to a capital gain or loss. It will also deny the intercorporate dividend rebate in respect of dividends paid out of profits arising on the revaluation of an asset as part of a scheme to avoid tax on disposal of the asset concerned. Even the honourable member for Kooyong must recognise the benefits in cracking down on the rorts that exist in the taxation Acts, as they presently stand, through these measures. I would have thought that in his contribution at least-I hope honourable members on the other side who will speak in this debate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they?

—That is a good question-where are they? There is not one in the House. I would have thought that they would be prepared to address these sorts of basic issues. This Bill will amend the Act to deny franking credits to companies and franking rebates to individuals and certain trustees under the imputation system of company taxation where a dividend is paid in the course of a dividend stripping scheme. We are endeavouring to crack down on the tax avoidance industry and I believe these measures will go towards doing that. Provisions in the Bill will also overcome the technical deficiencies in sections 108 and 109 of the Act that have prevented their proper application-namely, to prevent avoidance of tax by private companies and their shareholders by disguising dividends as non-taxable loans or advances and as tax deductible remuneration. I would have thought that every member of this House would support those basic measures.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.
(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that people from this side of the House are prepared to come in and support their Government's initiatives in fighting tax avoidance and tax evasion through these Bills. This stands in stark contrast to the situation when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) delivered his miserable effort this afternoon. Not one member of the Liberal or National parties was in the background to hear him speak. The only Liberal who was present was acting as the Deputy Speaker. I think that is absolutely disgraceful.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was saying before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, the Bills before us tonight are related to the Government's continuing attack on the tax avoidance industry. These Bills also propose some amendments to the capital gains tax area. As I have said previously, capital gains tax is a very brave effort by this Government to attack an area of tax avoidance which had previously gone undetected. The changes being proposed in this legislation tonight refer to a couple of very important areas. The first is in relation to the treatment of assets owned by a taxpayer who ceases to be a resident of Australia. The changes are intended, amongst other things, to remove any deterrent to Australian residents wishing to gain work experience overseas or to foreign experts considering a temporary assignment in Australia. Tax on capital gains will not apply in certain circumstances in these cases. Secondly, this Bill ensures that, for the purposes of determining exactly what a capital gain is, the cost base of an interest or units in a trust will not be reduced where the trustee distributes income freed from tax by deductions allowed for certain income-producing buildings. That is very important.

There are a number of very important initiatives which this legislation seeks to address. Amendments in clauses 12 and 38 will ensure that employer-provided contributions to superannuation funds under an agreement ratified by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or a State tribunal will not render employees for whose benefit they are provided ineligible for deductions under section 82aat of the Income Tax Assessment Act for their own contributions to qualifying superannuation funds. That is a very significant amendment. It is even more significant in view of what has happened in the world stock markets simply because many superannuation funds which have invested in the stock markets are suffering some losses. Of course, employee contributions may at some stage be affected by those crashes on the stock exchange and it is hoped that through amendments to legislation, such as that proposed in these Bills, the harshness of what may happen can in some way be softened.

The payment of income under the Commonwealth's assistance for isolated children scheme and the veterans children education scheme to or in respect of students who are 16 years of age or more is also to be made subject to tax under this Bill. This is in line with the Government's moves to make these sorts of schemes more consistent with the mainstream provisions of the Austudy scheme. On many occasions Opposition members have come into this place to berate Austudy. It is the Government's intention, through the introduction of a revamped Austudy scheme and allowances for keeping people at school rather than taking unemployment benefits, to go a long way towards retraining and providing opportunities for young Australians to get a better education and take a more important place in the work force. I believe that these measures which have been introduced are part and parcel of rationalising our entire taxation regime as far as training allowances are concerned. The beneficiary rebates to recipients of Austudy will also be extended to recipients of these two schemes and this is a very worthwhile part of this legislation.

This Bill will also give effect to the 1987-88 Budget proposal to vary the 1987-88 maximum rebates of tax and the income levels above which the rebates shade out for taxpayers in receipt of unemployment, sickness or special benefits and certain Commonwealth education allowances. For example, the rebate for married taxpayers will increase from $280 to $430 and the rebate for others will increase from $190 to $280. I believe that these sorts of initiatives do not get enough publicity, nor are they the ones that are seized upon as evidence of this Government's commitment to helping those most in need. Quite frankly, I am sick to death of reading indifferent articles or hearing people berate the Australian Labor Party and this Government for supposedly walking away from their traditional base and not servicing the needs of their traditional constituents. That is absolute nonsense.

Through the taxation measures that we have introduced and through these sorts of measures, such as increased rebates for married taxpayers and rebates for people on special or sickness benefits, we are improving the lot of those people in society. That is what the Australian Labor Party stands for. It does not stand for handouts to the rich. It does not stand for not asking people in the community to pay their fair share of taxation. Through the courageous efforts of this Government, and through the introduction of a variety of taxation changes and varying the mix of our taxation raising abilities, we have been able to see that people are, for the first time, paying their fair share of tax. Therefore, we are able to redistribute money to those people who are in greatest need.

This Bill also specifies the basis for calculating the 1987-88 provisional tax payable-by applying those rates of tax and Medicare levy to 1986-87 taxable incomes. They will be increased by 11 per cent. There is some concern amongst those people on fixed incomes who are picked up by provisional tax caused by not knowing the increases likely to be passed to them. This legislation picks that up. As the Minister stated in his second reading speech, there is also an amendment to the gift provisions of the current law to allow deductions for gifts to the Lionel Murphy Foundation and to the Australian-Hellenic Memorial Trust Fund. Certainly on this side of the House there are no objections to that sort of allowance being made in this legislation.

The last provision of this Bill to which I wish to refer demonstrates beyond doubt that this Government is committed to pursuing those who attempt to rip off our tax system. As honourable members would be aware, it was the case in the past that where a tax debt relating to an assessment was the subject of an objection or an appeal it might have been several years after the date on which the tax became due and payable before the objection and appeal process was finalised. In these cases the limitation period would commence on the due date for payment and could, therefore, expire at a time before the objection and appeal process was completed. The Hawke Labor Government inserted a modifying section into the administration Act to ensure that this does not happen in the future. A technical argument has now been advanced to the effect that our intention has not been achieved by the new section. This Bill will amend the section to make our intention perfectly clear. It also signals to those attempting to defraud the system of $250m that they will not be permitted to do so on a legal technicality.

I believe that all of these provisions, which are part and parcel of the Government's continued attack on the tax avoidance industry, will contribute to that income redistribution process which is so important, which this Government believes in and which this great Party stands for. I hope that, despite what the honourable member for Kooyong had to say in his very shallow contribution to this debate this afternoon, there are those on the other side who can see the need for this sort of legislation, which endeavours to collect a fair share of tax from those people in the community who in the past just have not been prepared to contribute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are having a cognate debate this evening on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987, the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill 1987. I wish to address my remarks to the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, which is a Bill to amend the Medicare Levy Act 1986. The main proposal in the legislation seeks to raise the Medicare levy from 1.145 per cent to 1.25 per cent. This is in substantial contradiction to promises made by the Government. When Medicare was introduced we were told not only that the levy would remain at one per cent but also that it would be fully self-supporting. Both claims were patently untrue. In the Sydney Morning Herald on 21 February 1986 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when responding to an Opposition call to re- affirm an election promise that the levy would not be increased during the Government's present term, was reported as saying, `I affirm the Government has no plans to change the Medicare arrangements'. We are now seeing an increase in the levy which will substantially increase the cost to taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: To avoid further embarrassing annual debate on the disaster that is Medicare the Government proposes to amend the legislation so that only changes to the levy need be debated in this Parliament. As with the indexation of excise and other matters, the Government is at pains to avoid the scrutiny of this Parliament. This is another attempt to do so. Consequently, as has already been announced by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), we have circulated amendments which will be dealt with in committee to ensure that the status quo is retained and that the Government is required to reaffirm the levy each year. The Opposition does not believe that the Parliament should be denied this annual scrutiny. Medicare represents the best possible example of the divergence in philosophy between the Australian Labor Party and the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever used it?

—Of course I have used it. Do not ask silly questions. There is a major divergence in philosophy. One has only to read the speech in September 1983 by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), and some of his other remarks, particularly those about the rights of the community over the individual and the fact that freedom and privacy are a bourgeois right, to understand that. Let us get something straight. Both sides believe in assisting the needy in the community. That is not the point at issue. Both sides recognise that all Australians are entitled to high quality, affordable health care. The divergence occurs in the arena of how best to deliver that high quality health care. Labor politicians believe that the Government can best deliver the actual service. The coalition parties believe that the private sector is best equipped and better motivated to do the task. And that is most important. International evidence is on the coalition's side.
—Rubbish!

—The Minister says, `Rubbish!'. He should go to Russia some time. Let me tell him what it is like in Yugoslavia. I have a close friend whose father was told that he was going to be left to die because he was a bit too old to be put in the system. There is always another side to that type of regime. My close friend was able to fly over there with American dollars and his father is still living 10 years later. He was going to be left to die. Let us get straight which regime is preferred. We say that the private sector would deliver the service best. If one has the money to assist the needy why must one then build and staff a hospital? Why not just assist the needy to go to hospital? The Prime Minister goes fishing and plays golf with private businessmen. He goes fishing occasionally with those who provide the property. He goes fishing with those who run certain businesses and who are too smart to own the property. They say things that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), would not understand, although if the Minister went back to the Richmond City Council he might find someone there to give him some advice.
—It was not as graft-ridden as the Carnarvon Council.
—The Minister has had plenty of time to talk about the Carnarvon Council but he does not. He has got the Nicholson report; I have got nothing.

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The Minister will cease interjecting. Those on the back bench will cease interjecting. The honourable member for O'Connor will not respond if anybody interjects, nor will he shout across the table.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. I am here to treat this matter very seriously. It is a serious matter. I am not inviting the type of remark that has been made but I will not be bullied by the member for the Richmond Council.
—The Chair will make sure that no member is bullied.

—I thank you for your protection, Madam Speaker. I am talking about the divergence in philosophy. The most efficient in our business sector recognise that if one is in the business of providing a service one does not necessarily buy the building from which one delivers the service. They have woken up that there are specialists in every area and they rely on the specialists. They are the most successful businesses in our country. Recently, I read that one of the major businesses which have been taken over was very quick to sell the fixed assets of the company which it said were not in its line of business.

SPEECH.PARA: Under Malcolm Fraser the system was designed to look after the needy. The Government is constantly throwing the figure of two million uninsured people at us, implying that they were all too poor to buy a health insurance policy. Of course they were not. Maybe some did but generally the poor were accommodated and other people decided to take the risk because they were healthy. It is one of the Goebbels-type arguments that have been put up in this place time and time again that because 1.9 million people did not have a health insurance policy they were all too poor to afford it. I knew some of those people. They were wealthy and believed that they could carry their own insurance. That is a practice that occurs in many parts of the private sector as well. Now that we have a system for everyone the needy are neglected.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all pay.

—We are all paying, including the needy, but the needy are neglected. This Government believes that it can measure expenditure by excellence. The needy are now neglected because of a lack of services. We have 100,000 people waiting to get into hospital. One has almost to give three months notice to get sick.
—Where?

—All around the place, and in New South Wales in particular. The comments of Mr Anderson are not true, because I have been around talking to the people and it is about time we started a group of people called Patients in Waiting. Labor members talk about elective surgery as though that is something one can have if one feels like it, a bit like cosmetic surgery. Elective surgery includes treatment for cataracts and hip joint replacements. I spent four months in an orthopaedic ward and I saw people come in who could not walk. They came out of the ward able to walk purely and simply because they had had hip joint replacements. If that is what is considered elective surgery, if that is what one has to wait three or four years for under this wonderful Medicare scheme which is supposed to help the needy, then I say that there is something wrong with it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look quickly at the escalating cost. Back in 1970-71 government expenditure was $1,080m and private expenditure $855m, totalling $1,935m which represented 5.65 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). In 1975-76, after the disastrous Medibank experiment, that had jumped to $4,052m for the Government, $1,508m for the private sector; $5,560m in total, or 7.45 per cent of GDP. Taking the figures last available for public and private sectors, the total was $16,108m or 7.5 per cent of GDP. That figure of 7.5 per cent relates to a massively growing GDP in this country. Unfortunately, it grew on account of the borrowings by this Government and not by genuine growth in the commercial sector. But that is less than is being spent in many other countries. At present the United States of America spends 8.6 per cent of GDP, West Germany 9.4 per cent. This year total Federal expenditure alone for 1987-88 is estimated at $8,212.9m, which is up $713.6m on that for last year, an increase of 9.5 per cent. That represents 10.4 per cent of total Commonwealth outlays. Health has again got ahead of the interest charges. Interest charges came fifth in one-line items in the last Fraser Budget; last year they came second at almost $8,200m. They have dropped to $7,900m and health expenditure is marginally ahead of the interest bill. I wonder whether that is the Government's order of priorities, but that is what it has achieved.

The Medicare levy is now 1.25 per cent, which means that the taxes paid by Australians on account of that levy, according to the Budget estimate, amount to $2,065m, an increase of $350m this year, or an increase of 20.4 per cent. It now represents 2.6 per cent of total Commonwealth revenues. This is the Medicare levy which Labor members call `free medicine', but it certainly is not. The cost per capita for Australians back in 1970-71 in nominal terms was $152.36 which in 1986-87 values was $719. In 1984-85 the figure had jumped in nominal terms to $1,029.27 and in 1986-87 values was $1,191.20. Every Australian man, woman and child is now contributing $23 a week for Labor's free medicine, and people have to give three months notice to get sick or they have to pay more.

The Minister for Community Services and Health has told us all sorts of wonderful things. Today I reread his second reading speech. In that speech in 1983 he told Australians that something had to be done. The cost of a bed would escalate to $130 a day if we did not have this wonderful thing called Medicare. Today one cannot get a hospital bed under $250 a day, so the system was not too effective in that regard. When Labor introduced Medicare the insurance cost was $9.60 a week for a typical Australian family. That figure is now over $16. As I have said, the levy is raising $2,065m, and that is what we were promised would be the total cost of the system. But if one goes to Budget Paper No. 1 and looks at the cost of medical services and benefits and of hospital services and benefits, which I presume is the cost of Medicare, one finds a figure of $5,212.5m-over double, or 230 per cent more than the actual levy. One can see that because clearly the levy is not $23 a week, which is the actual cost of health delivery in Australia.

Prior to the election in 1983 when the health funds predicted this, the Minister for Community Services and Health scoffed at them in his second reading speech, but they have been proved to be correct. But now the Government has a tiger by its tail. The costs are escalating at a speed that the Government cannot control. As the figure is up to 1.25 per cent, the troops are getting angry. The solution of course is to reduce further the services, put caps on the rebates, find excuses, blame the profession, blame the hospitals, blame the foreigners, blame anybody. That is what the Government is doing; it is going through the schedules and cutting back services.

Let me deal with ophthalmology. Cataract removal has been substantially reduced. The rebate for item 6848, lens extraction, has been reduced from $650 to $450, and that figure of $200 must now be paid by the patient. The rebate for item 6852, lens insertion, has gone down from $345 to $250. They are the maximums that can be paid out under Medicare or under certain private insurance. That is being left to the patient. There is a reason for that in that there is some wonderful new technology around. If that technology is available, a lot of operations can be carried out in the day and a professional can profit quite well.

But what happens to those who cannot afford this service? I give the Government a warning while it continues down this road. Some incentive must be left for innovation. If that does not happen, people will not proceed to make the services cheaper, and there will be no gains for the Government or the provider of the services. There must be some common-sense approach, split it down the middle perhaps, but as soon as the technology arrives do not hit everybody because people will miss out. I add in passing that day surgery is another area in which the Government is now totally confused. This can represent substantial savings to patients and to the health provider, the Government in this case. The Government must make up its mind about it; it is procrastinating, it is pulling back, it is agreeing. There are huge opportunities and, although the Minister has made some positive noises, he has not done enough. The ultimate must lie in achievement.

It is being said that a few doctors are not playing according to the rules in the removal of keratoses. The origins of skin cancer can be taken off via a freezing process and this process could quite properly be done in consultation. Apparently some were abusing that arrangement, but why throw the baby out with the bath water? Does the Government know that it also excluded venereal warts at exactly the same time the Health Department declared them a notifiable disease because they are a major cause of cancer of the cervix? The Minister for Community Services and Health has said in this place that the Government is spending a great deal of money on surveying that problem.

What is more, in the area of health, because the Government has changed the rules, a medical specialist in this area no longer goes to the northern town of Geraldton in my electorate, but the Government has just announced a survey of 5,000 people to ascertain the effects of skin cancer. Surely with the resources the Government has at its disposal it should have discovered that before it threw out the baby with the bath water-in other words, before it threw out items 3330 to 3338, plus 3342 and 3346. That was stupid and ridiculous. In the other place today the Opposition asked a question of the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health, Senator Ryan, and apparently the Government is thinking of fixing this matter. This is a pretty private thing. A lot of people would like to consult their own doctor. Obviously this is ridiculous. We had the example of the program shown on Sixty Minutes of a kid who is dying. The specialist professor said that if he had detected his skin cancer early enough-which he attributed to too much sun-he could have saved his life. It might be that even that other service, for keratoses, would be better back on the schedule, as it might save lives. You had better start chasing the very few doctors who have apparently cheated on the system. Throwing the baby out with the bath water might be a very expensive process. It shows that you do not understand this. It is like your understanding of the share market. You let the computers control the whole system.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is in America. Cut it out.
—Yes, and it is happening over here. If the computer tells you that you are spending too much money on something, your solution is `Cut it out'.
—Order! The honourable member should speak through the Chair and not to the honourable member.

—Madam Speaker, you are quite right, and I thank you for your advice. This is the sort of situation we have. It is not a solution to have the sorts of proposals that we have heard. But the Government says it is all the fault of the system. It has a tiger by the tail. Instead of going out into the community and trying to identify the need and the genuinely needy and, yes, raising taxes for that purpose and assisting those people, the Government has decided that it wants all the business. Well, it has got all the business, but now it cannot afford it. The people with money are getting the good services because they still have private cover. They can get into a private bed tomorrow because there are 9,000 vacant beds. Yet the Government has had to spend another $25m of taxpayers' money to try to improve its darling of a public hospital system. That has not worked, and it is time that the Government realised it. It must be a proper government and arrange systems that redirect money to people in need. It must not try to get into the business of running the system. It should buy the people who do that most efficiently. It must not kid itself that because it is the Government it is here to help them. That does not work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been very disappointed by the Opposition's contribution tonight. As was mentioned earlier by my colleague the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), we have witnessed the sad situation of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), a member and former leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, who really pulled that party through in 1983 against all the odds-if you like, the hero of 1983-speaking in this House on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and cognate Bills, with not one member of the Opposition being present during part of his contribution. Again, when the shadow Minister spoke, not one backbencher was there to support him. I am really surprised, particularly given the rhetoric during the contribution offered by both honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address some of the issues raised by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) concerning the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. The honourable member suggested that this is one of the best illustrations of the divergence between the Opposition and the Government. I am afraid that, when in government, one is required to have a policy and to implement that policy. That policy is publicly available and known by all members of the community. It would be fair to say that the Opposition has a Clayton's policy. It does not tell us what it is and we cannot pin it down or track it down. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition did not mention what the Opposition's policy was or what the Opposition would be doing as far as health is concerned, nor did the honourable member for O'Connor. All we heard was this carping criticism of the Government.

Let us go through a few of the things he said. He referred to the system under Malcolm Fraser-this was the system that he extolled to the people of Australia but under that system two million people were uninsured. The honourable member said that Government members were very wrong in believing that those two million people were all poor and could not afford insurance. I can accept that proposition, that not every one of those two million people was too poor and could not afford it. But let me say that the overwhelming majority of them could not afford it. They were priced out of the health system. Their health needs suffered. Surely, in this day and age, the one thing that we ought to be able to guarantee to every citizen of Australia is that they will not be priced out of the health system and that they will be able to have medical attention, irrespective of their circumstances, whenever they require it, and that they should not put off seeing doctors or put off operations merely because of their financial circumstances. That is the difference between the Opposition and the Government. We in the Government are determined to make sure that we have a health system that is accessible to all Australians, whether they are new Australians or old Australians, whether they are wealthy or poor. There has to be a health system that people can access.

The honourable member for O'Connor talked a lot about wanting to divert health to the private sector, to the more efficient side, as he called it. I do not understand what he means. Does he mean that we should close down some public hospitals? I find it very ironic that from time to time we get two different points of view from the Opposition. For example, earlier today the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) was saying what a tragedy it is that there is no maternity section in the Mount Druitt Hospital, the hospital of which formerly I was a deputy chairman. I agree with him. I think it is a tragedy. But here we have one shadow Minister who purports to come from near the western suburbs or identifies with that area, so he says, and he says that we really should have this facility in a public hospital. Then we have the honourable member for O'Connor telling the people of Australia that we do not need public hospitals, they should be private hospitals. But the one thing that neither of them will tell us is that under Fraser, under this beautiful system that the honourable member for O'Connor extols, where two million people were uninsured and there was every incentive to go to a private hospital, the occupancy rate in private hospitals was exactly the same as it is now. We are asked to accept that the Liberal Government under Mr Fraser-the Leader of the Opposition was a key member of his Government and the Deputy Leader was from time to time a Minister in it-had got that system of private hospitals up to maximum efficiency, but what do the figures say? They say that under the present Medicare system the occupancy rate is the same. So it is very misleading to suggest that we can crank up the private hospital system to absorb more.

As has been mentioned, in passing conversation earlier, one of the real problems with the medical system today is that so many doctors have a vested interest in private hospitals, in a couple of ways. Firstly, and quite boldly, they are part-owners of those hospitals. They receive a financial reward as the owners of those institutions, and they make a profit in terms of diverting patients there. Secondly-and I regret that this occurs all too often-patients, not knowing their rights, get told: `If you want to have an operation, I can do it tomorrow in a private hospital, but you will have to wait to have it done in a public hospital'. The patients go away thinking: `Isn't this terrible? This public hospital system is really not meeting the needs of the people'. That specialist does not tell the patient that he has an extensive operating list at the private hospital, that he could, if he wanted, increase his operating list in a public hospital, but chooses not to. He does not say, `It is your right to insist on having that operation done in a public hospital'.

My wife and I were faced with that very dilemma when my son needed an operation. We said to the doctor, `We understand what you are saying, but no, we want the security of knowing that the operation is going to be performed in that public hospital'. And it was performed in the public hospital. This is the other element that doctors, and specialists in particular, never go into when discussing operations with patients. They never say in an emergency in a private hospital that the patient must be transferred to a public hospital. They never say, `Sorry, we cannot deal with this emergency. We are going to have to send you to the nearest public hospital to recover the situation'. Hopefully, it can be recovered. But in some cases, of course, it is not recovered. I really think that we have a job to do-I accept that there is some fault on the Government side here-to inform the people of Australia just what their rights as patients are. If Mr and Mrs Average have a problem with their car, and get an opinion from a mechanic, they can say, `My God, he is charging too much' or, `I do not agree with that'. They do not hesitate to say, `I am sorry, I am going down the road to seek a second opinion'. But it is a real tragedy that when it comes to doctors, to specialists, they do not say, `I disagree with that', or `Maybe that operation is not necessary', or, `I want a second opinion', or, `I insist on a second opinion'. They ought to be encouraged to do that.

Let me also say this about the Opposition, from what can be gleaned from the contribution by the honourable member for O'Connor: the honourable member for O'Connor and members of the Opposition do not stand with the plight of the general practitioners. They side with the specialists, the people who are making the real money-the real beneficiaries of the current health system, such as the consultant physicians. I regret that. I sympathise with the plight of the GPs when, with changing technology, it is insisted that so much of the work that they could perform has to be performed by specialists. I am really pleased that in my contribution to the Mount Druitt Hospital I was able to liaise with the family medicine program whose aim it was to uplift the skills of GPs and to recognise the very important contribution they make in family medicine, in servicing the majority of patients.

The honourable member for Macarthur raised a very important point about consulting physicians. I think the honourable member for O'Connor referred to eye operations and other operations. Yes, there have been changes in technology. Every member of this House in some endeavour, whether in agriculture, in administration, in banking-you name it-has seen the impact of changing technology. But what the honourable member for O'Connor asks the people of Australia to believe is that, with any change in medicine-any improvement that allows doctors to perform half a dozen operations instead of one or two a day-there should be a work practice demarcation border built in and the doctors should be insulated from any productivity improvements and should continue to receive exactly the same remuneration as they are used to receiving. What an absurd argument!

Madam Speaker, how many times have you had to sit in this House and hear members of the Opposition say, `Look at all these nasty work practices, these demarcation disputes. They are bringing the country down.'? For our part, we have been saying, `Well, we are trying to work through them. We are getting, through processes of consultation, a real understanding of the difficulties in this area and we are getting changes'. But, no, when it comes to medicine, the honourable member for O'Connor wants to put a border around it and say that there should be no improvements whatsoever.

On the issue of physicians, let me say that I sympathise with the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). Any unbiased observer of the health system would say that the task of the Minister-historically, that means any health Minister, whether Liberal or Labor-has been a most difficult one in negotiating with the medical profession. This area is no exception. I reiterate an undertaking given by the Minister during the election campaign, which was that we would review this area. That review is continuing; the discussions are continuing. I say publicly-I do not apologise for this-that I ask the representatives of the specialists to sit down genuinely at the negotiating table and negotiate legitimately and honestly in the patients' interests. This problem has to be resolved. No group in the community-Madam Speaker, you may think I am stealing the Opposition's words here-should be allowed to blackmail the public at large. Certainly, doctors should not be allowed to do this.

On the issue of Medicare, I want to conclude my remarks by saying that there is a divergence in general philosophy. We certainly stand by the principle, and will defend it to the nth degree, that every Australian should have equality of access to medical facilities. Let me also mention one of the things that the Government has done. Members of the Opposition keep talking about waiting lists. I have already covered that in part. But it is also true to say that this Government has given the States $100m to reduce those waiting lists. Let me say this: At the meeting of State health Ministers, which included the Ministers from Tasmania and the Northern Territory-Ministers of the same political persuasion as members opposite-it was unanimously agreed that waiting lists were not the Commonwealth's responsibility. They acknowledged that in fact they are a State responsibility. There are a number of factors-I will not go through them-that contribute to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go on; tell us.

—I am urged to tell. The important point to make is that at that ministerial conference it was unanimously agreed that this was a State problem. I congratulate the Minister for Community Services and Health for stepping in with the money. Obviously, the answer given this week in the New South Wales Parliament by the New South Wales Minister for Health, Mr Anderson, hurt; otherwise, the honourable member for O'Connor would not have mentioned it.
