SPEECH.PARA: I also want to direct a few of my remarks to the contribution made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He talked about the high level of corporate tax and the fact that we have increased it from 43c to 49c in the dollar. I say to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that one of the sad things about his leadership of the Liberal Party of Australia, and indeed the current Leader's deputy leadership of it, is that, when we decided to have a taxation summit meeting, the approach of the Liberal Party was not that taxation was an issue that needed to be addressed in a bipartisan way or that the Opposition would, as much as oppositions can, co-operate with the Government to develop a bipartisan approach. No, not at all; members of the Opposition sat on the sidelines and would not participate. The history of the Opposition has always been that it tends to agree with the good things we do, that is, where we are giving money away, and to complain when we are raising money.

This reform has been the most thorough that any government over the last 35 years has put together. Members on the Opposition side should be ashamed of what they did not do. And they had more opportunities, and a better climate in which to do it, than we have ever had. It is a tribute to this Government and its determination that we have done this in some of the toughest economic times.

There is a very good reason why the Deputy Leader of the Opposition did not mention why one would want to increase the company tax rate from 43 to 49 per cent, which would make it comparable with the top marginal rate of income tax. While ever there is a differential, there is a great incentive to incorporate. A lot of companies are incorporated merely to gain the taxation advantage. So, while ever there is a disparity between the two, that will be the case. With all of the Opposition's rhetoric about cutting down bureaucracy and making government more efficient, surely it can accept that point of view.

Another thing I want to say, which was pointed out by the honourable member for Macarthur in his contribution, is that we have not heard one word from the Opposition about imputation. It is almost as though imputation was never brought in.

TALK.START.PARA: —At 78c in the dollar.

—That is right. This Government had done for private enterprise something that the Opposition had always wanted to do but never had the courage to do. And we did it in the toughest of economic times-not in the halcyon days and with the opportunities that previous governments had, but which they forswore.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition made much of the impact of the capital gains tax. I have talked to a lot of business organisations about the impact of the capital gains tax. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said, `We have this group of people who work really hard to build up the goodwill of the businesses'. I accept that a lot of small business people-in fact, most small business people-work exceptionally hard to earn their money. What he did not say was, `Does goodwill grow at a greater rate than the inflation rate?'. I accept that we can have good entrepreneurs, highly skilled people, who are capable of lifting the goodwill of businesses dramatically, but we are talking about the majority of people who put in long hours over a long time to build up that goodwill. Our capital gains tax is not like that in America where one is taxed on the nominal gain. In Australia one is taxed only on the real gains, that is, the gains less inflation. As far as the smaller small businesses are concerned, part of the goodwill is quarantined; it is not even taxable. If the Opposition wants to, it should develop a table to show me how goodwill increases at 1.2 per cent, 1.5 per cent, 2.2 per cent, or whatever, more than inflation. I suspect that it does not, but I ask the Opposition genuinely and earnestly to look at that. If it thinks it is a problem it should remember that we are taxing only the real gains.

As my time draws to an end, I say to the House that I support, and I will continue to support, the fairness and equity that this Government has tried to put into the taxation system. Certainly, I support the measures contained in these Bills that get at the rorts, get at the schemes and scams that have developed. People are on notice from us that we will continue on this track.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) begs a reply before he leaves the chamber. I will mention a few of the points he made, particularly in relation to tax and the dividend imputation system. I will be talking about imputation later in my speech. The honourable member might ask himself this question: Who was the Treasurer who removed, immediately upon coming to office, the $1,000 tax free ceiling on dividends that was introduced by the former Treasurer, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard)? It was this Treasurer (Mr Keating). The honourable member cannot have it all ways. When we talk about the great advantages of imputation-and I admit them-we also have to look at the history of the previous Government. The honourable member bases his comments on a false premise when he says that imputation was some record creating activity of this Government. In actual fact, it was responsible for removing legislation from the books that gave not identical relief but partial relief to those people who were receiving dividends from double taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member also talked about the bipartisan approach to the National Taxation Summit. I can think of the bipartisan approach as being only that between the Government and the unions. I can remember some things quite clearly about the conference. True, the Government did have a fringe benefits tax in mind, but I can remember the Treasurer saying on one night that a fringe benefits tax applied to the employee, the receiver of the benefit. The next day Cliff Dolan happened to look at what his fringe benefits were and found that they would be too excessive. He said publicly, `No, it won't be a charge on the employee'. The following day, in the course of 24 hours, the Treasurer changed his mind and said that the fringe benefits tax--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, what rot!

—It is not rot; it is the absolute truth, and I can recall it. I also raise the manner in which the Government came to that Summit on the subject of a consumption tax. It had it on the table that there would be a consumption tax, but there was no suggestion at that stage that there would be a capital gains tax. Yet by the time the conference was out, through some secret deal with the unions at a hotel in Canberra, we ended up not with a consumption tax but with a capital gains tax-obviously an offset-and a fringe benefits tax on businesses or corporations, not on the individual receiver of the benefit. I believe that asking somebody to pay the tax on the benefit received by somebody else offended every taxation canon that had ever been introduced under British law or Australian law. No amount of harping by the Government will convince me or the businesses that were taken to the cleaners otherwise. I thought it important to get those two matters on tax cleared up.

SPEECH.PARA: In connection with the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill, the honourable member for Chifley went to great lengths to talk about the vested interests of doctors and specialists in the private hospitals of Australia. There are two hospitals in Mackay: one run by the Catholic Church, the Mater Misericordiae Hospital, and the other a private hospital, the Pioneer Valley Hospital. If anybody tells me that specialists and doctors of the medical profession can somehow have a vested interest in hospitals such as that run by Mater Mothers, I would be quite surprised. Those establishments have in their time provided a medical service which is not available in the public area. I refer here to intensive and palliative care which is a very good service provided by the Mater. Yet they are the ones who have been attacked under the Medicare system which the honourable member for Chifley glorifies.

The subsidy rate has been reduced and the waiting list for vacant hospital beds has increased. That has occurred for one reason, and it does not matter how much money this Government throws at any State government, whether it be $100m or more; if the program is wrong the system will be wrong and the queues will grow. That is what is happening at the moment. Because of the doctor choice arrangement people will be going into the public hospital system-joining the queue-hoping that they do not have to give notice of an illness. On the other hand, the services available, particularly those available in Mackay and, I suggest, anywhere else in Queensland, are as good as, if not better than, those in the public hospital system because they are run as hospitals and they do care. I refute the nonsense given to us by honourable members opposite, particularly when the owners are accused of referring patients to their own hospitals for their own ends.

The honourable member talked about waiting lists but he then went on to say that as a member he was able to tell his doctor or his specialist where he wanted to go. That is the right of every patient, and some people pay dearly for that right. The shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), mentioned that the family cover for hospital treatment has increased from $9.60 prior to the Medicare system being introduced to $16 today. If the honourable member for Chifley is talking about double taxation as far as dividends are concerned, why does he not care for these people who are being doubly taxed, once under the Medicare system, which is compulsory, and again when they pay the extra $16 a week in order to have a choice of doctors? There are many people in that particular category who want their family to have good health care and who are prepared to pay for it.

The Medicare Levy Amendment Bill seeks to increase the levy from 1.15 per cent to 1.25 per cent. It is interesting to note that the Medicare levy will be increased this year by some $350m-that is, from $1,715m to $2,065m, which is an increase of 20.4 per cent. That is a rather massive increase. But in spite of the size of that increase, one has to take into account that it goes nowhere near the payment of the expenses it is supposed to cover. If we look at the expenditure side of health outlays we will notice that there has been an increase of some $713m for this year, or nearly 10 per cent. The provision for medical services and benefits has increased to $3,527m and the provision for hospital services and benefits have increased to $1,685m. So the people of Australia should have in mind that this free Medicare does not stop at 1.25 per cent; it stops right in the middle of the Government's other tax assessment which, as a comparison, must add another 3 or 4 per cent to the cost of what is declared as free medicine in Australia. So it is a nonsense to suggest, as the honourable member for Chifley did, that giving money will solve all problems. It think it is time that this philosophy of the Government ceased. It is the programs that count, and no amount of money will rectify any of the deep-seated problems unless there is a program to go with it.

Another aspect of this legislation concerns taxation. There is a diminution in some rates of tax, particularly at the high levels of income. The tax rates for incomes of between $19,501 and $35,000 have been reduced from 43c and 46c to 40c and the rate for incomes of $35,000 and over has been reduced from 55c to 49c. At the time these changes were made-and I had a feeling that the Treasurer had this in his mind when the election was called for 11 July-there was to be one pay packet in the hands of ordinary Australians that would reflect a decrease in the rate of taxation. How disappointed those people on incomes of less than $19,500-that is a little below average yearly earnings-must have been when they found that there was no decrease at all and when in fact with the Medicare levy they found an increase. These people received no benefit whatsoever. The zero tax threshold was not raised and the rates of tax for these people were similar to what they were prior to the end of June; that is, 24c and 29c respectively.

In addition to personal income tax rates I want to talk about the company rate of tax which goes to 49c. Again I come back to this matter of imputation. I would say that imputation does have some consideration in increasing the rate from say, 46c. But I point out that although some relief in the area of dividends was also offered by the previous Fraser Government it did not feel that it was necessary to increase the company tax rate. As honourable members will appreciate, the tax rate of 49c now applies not only to company tax but also to the fringe benefits tax. Just to compare the figures, company tax collections will go up by 14.3 per cent this year, from $6,714m to $7,675m. At the same time, fringe benefits tax collections are increasing from $535m to $750m, a 40.1 per cent increase. That is a massive increase in collections from people who do not get the benefit of a tax deduction for that tax within their expenditure; they have to account for it otherwise. If we add that as a proportional rate of company tax on to what they already pay, the real rate is not 49c in the dollar but something like 53c in the dollar. I think this is something that the Government has chosen to hide amongst a lot of the other problems that the Budget will entail.

Anyone-the Treasurer or anyone else-who says that the fringe benefits tax has been received and taken on the chin within the business community of Australia ought to look at the figures to see the manner in which some companies have had to dispose of employees. I have seen that actually happen with one of the companies in Mackay. Because of the additional imposition of the fringe benefits tax some of the staff of that company had to be dismissed because it could not bear the price of that particular labour under those circumstances. So the fringe benefits tax has also been a real contributor to the unemployment situation in Australia.

In talking about the rates of taxation, I want to deal with a particular aspect that is not dealt with in this legislation and has not been dealt with in any legislation in the 4 1/2 years of this Government. The members of the Government are quite keen to talk about the rorts and the people who have been tampering with the system and indulging in avoidance or evasion. They say that this piece of legislation or that piece of legislation is meant to improve the situation. Yet one of the rorts within the system is allowed to go unchecked. I refer specifically to section 23 (f) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which states:

The income of a trade union and the income of an association of employers or employees registered under any Act or State Act, or under any law in force in a Territory being part of Australia relating to the settlement of industrial disputes;

That income is exempt from taxation. This is allowed to go on. I remember reading in an article in the Bulletin less than six months ago that the income from interest on investments of 10 unions was calculated to be about $100m. I understand that there are about 350 registered unions in Australia. They are certainly not all as big as the 10 referred to in the article. People talk about the aggregate amount of tax that is lost and complain that employers and businesses of Australia are rorting the system, but they should ask why unions are not treated in a similar way to the businesses for whom their members work.

This is a massive rort that I believe should be corrected. It is a rort that is being practised at the same time as many non-profit organisations around Australia are receiving letters from the Commissioner of Taxation asking why they have not lodged returns or paid tax in regard to the non-exempt part of their income, namely, the interest on investments. That is a double standard. The Act is quite clear in that regard. If the Government suggests that an association of employers stands to gain, I would like to know how many associations of employers around Australia have investments of a similar nature to those of unions and receive interest on them of the kind indicated by the article in the Bulletin.

We hear about amendments to taxation law and the greatest reform in taxation for the last 35 years. I have with me a copy of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which was reprinted as at 31 December 1985. This volume contains 1,522 pages. I do not know how anybody can say that that represents a simplification or an improvement of the Act. Incidentally, that does not include the fringe benefits tax provisions, which are also massive. The legislation that we are now debating is increasing the amount of taxation law by a further 29 pages. The Government must understand that there must be a simpler system for the collection of taxation than the one that it is adopting. Basically, the high rates of tax, particularly company tax rates and other rates, mean that a person earning income in Australia tries to seek any solution he can-preferably an honourable one. To add additional provisions to the Income Tax Assessment Act and to try to stamp out the problems in that way is not the way to go. We need a simpler system. We need a system that provides encouragement and an incentive for people to earn money, instead of falling out of the income-producing area and into the social welfare or some other net. If they do not make efforts to earn money, the Government has to pick up the tab.

I believe that the proposed imputation system is probably an improvement, but there are still some problems. For instance, I understand that unappropriated profits prior to 30 June 1987 on which income tax has been paid on a company basis by the corporations concerned will, on a distribution after 1 July or a distribution in liquidation, become taxable in full despite having been taxed previously by the government of the day. So there will not be any relief on imputation. The Australian Taxation Office will have its hand in the till when a company goes into liquidation.

I also raise a question in regard to capital gains tax. It was indicated to me recently that the transfer of a 30-year crown lease, even to a similar one, is subject to capital gains tax even though improvements by the owner to the old lease might go back quite a few years. Even acquiring a new lease for the same land makes that land and perhaps all the improvements thereon subject to capital gain. Perhaps the Minister at the table, the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs (Mr Holding), would tell me whether that is correct, or whether it is an unintended consequence of the capital gains legislation and the Government would prefer to do something about it by other means.

I could mention quite a few things in regard to this legislation, but I might just mention again provisional tax. I know that provisional tax puts the business taxpayer into basically the same situation as the pay as you earn taxpayer, as businesses have to make quarterly payments, but it does offend me that when the Budget predicts an inflation rate of about 6 per cent, provisional tax will be based on an 11 per cent increase on the previous year's income. One wonders, following the fall of the stock exchange over the last two days and with the quarterly payment coming up, just how business people will react. They have to try to provide a proper estimate of their income for both capital gains and income tax purposes, and under section 221ydb (1) of the Act if there is a 10 per cent error and one's provisional tax assessment has to be revised, there is a 20 per cent penalty. I find that to be quite horrific. The Australian Taxation Office is unwilling to listen always to proper reason, and it is very difficult for an individual to assess in such a volatile market his income for the coming year with an error rate of no more than 10 per cent-and all this while he is being taxed on an 11 per cent increase on his business in the previous year while a 6 per cent inflation rate obtains. There are many things we could talk about--

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep going.

—I cannot. I do believe the Government has to answer questions in many areas, and I particularly ask the Minister to answer the two questions I have raised-my query about leases and capital gains, and why it is that the Government endeavours to keep exempting union income from taxation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought for one moment late in the contribution of the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) that we might finally have reached some agreement in this House. I thought what he said was the same as I was going to say, but I discover now that we are really talking about different things although using the same words. He has highlighted one important aspect by demonstrating that all this taxation legislation should be made more simple. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) is what I call a `here we go again' Bill, because it contains a number of measures that are really designed to close off more loopholes and tidy up avenues for circumventing the legislation which have been found by those who specialise in these things since the introduction of our tax reform package. So when I think in terms of a simplification of the tax legislation, what I am really admitting is that it is almost impossible for draft legislation to cater for all circumstances. We do need the co-operation of the community to ensure that it follows the spirit of our legislation, and the tax avoidance and minimisation industry ought to take notice of this. The Government cannot be expected to keep on closing loopholes while an industry goes on finding new ones.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess I am really saying that I think the Government ought to be looking at dismantling the Income Tax Assessment Act and setting in place a new set of principles-principles which I can assure the House would give the honourable member for Dawson apoplexy. At the moment our tax law is out there on the table. The high fliers are looking through it with a microscope for every potential loophole. I think we ought to be looking at moving powers of specific definition to the Commissioner of Taxation and establishing a set of guidelines for him to follow, and then have the industry come to the Tax Commissioner to find out how he would propose to treat their schemes before they are implemented. In other words, if they are not going to back off and stop this caper of continually finding and exploiting loopholes in every piece of legislation brought into Parliament, perhaps we should make them get permission from the Tax Commissioner before they start. There is a lot to be said for that approach.

In this amending legislation, there are attempts by the Government to be fair about the application of the capital gains tax, and I applaud that. When I look to the other aspects of the legislation, which includes reference to all these loopholes that we are attempting to close, I seriously question whether it is worth following that approach any more. My colleagues the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) and the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) have already focused very well on what I would describe as the pathetic contribution of those on the other side of the House, not only during this debate but continually in Question Time. There is no substance, and no understanding of the principle of fairness and equity. They simply come into the House, rowing the boats of the vested interest groups that they represent: we heard again tonight the call for less tax for those in the best position to pay.

What has to be understood about the tax cuts that are embodied in the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) is that they represent the final stage of what has been a very bitter fight in Australia to get a fairer tax system for all Australians. Our wage and salary earners have been paying income tax rates among the highest in the world, while others have been avoiding their fair share.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—My colleague the honourable member for Charlton, who is in total agreement with what I am saying, will, I am sure, elucidate more on this matter in his contribution. Let it not be forgotten that these tax cuts are being paid for by a clamping down on business lunches and fringe benefits ripoffs, as well as by the money raised from capital gains tax. It cannot be reiterated too often that every dollar that has been raised under these taxes has been directed back to wage and salary earners via tax cuts in their pay packets-something which this Government stands proudly behind.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us in this debate look also at the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill. At the heart of the recent Federal election was the question of the continuation of Medicare. In December 1975, when government in Australia changed hands, the first act of those on the other side of the House was to dismantle Medibank, as it was called in those days, despite an unequivocal promise to the Australian public that it would not be dismantled. That was done to cater for the whims and fancies of the medical practitioners and specialists who ripped the system off, made big dollars out of it, used all the negative gearing provisions and the whole box and dice and now want to return to that private health system which gave them free slather. During the recent election campaign, we had what I regard as a last ditch attempt in Australia to return to those good old days for that group. It is just not on. Medicare is here to stay. This legislation actually increases the income threshold from which people will pay. In other words, more low income people have been excluded from paying the Medicare levy, and that is typical of this Government's approach.

It ought to be said that this approach to families and Medicare is the overall thrust of this tax reform and the Budget undertakings. In looking at the welfare of ordinary Australians and issues such as the health system, I see in my electorate developments such as the Broadmeadows Community Health Centre, with its use of salaried doctors and its provision of fee for service, using the Medicare system. Bulk billing is working beautifully and is widely and well accepted in the community and by the medical practitioners who use the system, and I commend them for it. In central Victoria the Cobaw program is developing in conjunction with the home and community care program to help particularly our elderly people to stay in their homes and be catered for within the local community. This is all being funded under a budget approach that is working and has at its heart the principles of fairness and equity for ordinary people. I will divert to give a personal example. In my home town of Heathcote are a couple of lovely people, Mr and Mrs Nicol. Recently Molly Nicol had an operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is she all right?

—She is okay but she has to go back into hospital for another operation, which is unfortunate. They are a couple of ordinary retired people who have worked hard. Mrs Nicol is getting the best care and attention that our hospital system can provide under Medicare. Yet those on the other side complain about waiting lists and the conditions for consulting physicians when ordinary people who deserve the best care and attention that our system can provide are prepared to wait and also support this system. Mr and Mrs Nicol are very strong supporters of Medicare and want to see it stay.
—And the Labor Party as a result.

—And the Labor Party, the Labor Government, as my colleague interjects. I turn just briefly to the family package because the arrangements that are outlined in the tax amendment Bills are addressing the fundamental principles of redistribution which incorporate very substantial payments for low income families with children.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge the 1,500-odd families in my electorate who will benefit from the family package to ensure that they get their applications in and start planning now for the best way to apply the increases of between $50 and $70 a week which will be given to ordinary families. Families should start planning a budgeting program now to consolidate debts or to start a savings scheme towards bridging the home loan gap. I hope that many women in families will have the opportunity to use a little of the family package money to enrol in a course for personal development, word processing, or in some other area, in, say, a technical and further education college which would gear them up for returning to the work force. Education is a key way of ensuring the longer term future of their families, and that is what we are trying to provide for them.

I again reiterate that all of these provisions have been made possible by the determination of this Government to press ahead with a very major tax reform, a number of components of which are incorporated in these Bills. Despite calls from the Opposition, we will not be backing away from the capital gains tax, we will not be backing away from the fringe benefits tax and we will not be backing away from crackdowns on those who have been using every possible device to minimise their tax. I think that is something to be applauded.

Finally, I will say something about wealth because there has been some debate about it in the community in recent weeks. We really have to look at what is happening in the community that is focusing attention on this matter. Many are using the term `conspicuous consumption'. I can take honourable members to places in my electorate where, only two kilometres apart, are some of the wealthiest and some of the poorest areas of Melbourne. They can see for themselves, in very direct comparison, the conspicuous consumption that now exists in our community.

In 1983, when the prices and incomes accord was established, the Government at the time asked those in the business sector not to take short term profits off the top to use the profits that we were injecting into the system via wage discounting and the approach taken by the Government and trade unions to achieve a resurgence of Australian industry. We pleaded with those people not to cream the profits off the top but to churn the money back into their businesses, to reduce their business debt and to get into productive investment to better place us in the world market so that we could see what was needed. What has happened is that $9 billion of extra profit has been created in this country and very little has turned up yet in either reduced debt or in investment in productive enterprise. It has been creamed off the top and it is reflected in conspicuous consumption. So we have to look at this problem. I believe these are the frustrations that the ordinary person in the community is experiencing. That is why the ordinary person is saying, `What has been going on? Why is all this happening while I am taking the bite? I am pulling in my belt; why aren't they?'. The politics of envy is being created in our community by the people who are not prepared to play the game fairly.

I received some information today which I guess was not surprising, but it is disappointing. I understand that one person who features very highly in the top 200 of the Business Review Weekly is a leading light in the Liberal Party of Australia; in fact, he may even be its new Federal President.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I guess?

—Yes, the honourable member might be able to guess who it is. He is on a quoted salary of hundreds of thousands of dollars. I have it on very good information that his personal tax contribution to the system this year was $950.
—How much?

—A sum of $950. If that is true, those who represent these sorts of people stand condemned in this society as far as I am concerned. Honourable members opposite look a little surprised. Let me tell them that not all the leaks in Australia are against the Government. The fact of life is that these people are around the place all the time bleating that we need to provide incentivation and something to work for. I will tell honourable members what we need to do. The only way we can get them rolling in Australia is to write out a government guaranteed cheque for profit-no sort of entrepreneurial burst, but a government guaranteed cheque for profit. Then they might actually do something about creating something productive. These are the people who continually dud our tax system with takeover write-offs. They race off-shore and borrow foreign capital. The minute the Government gets a bit tough, what do they do? They threaten to take their money overseas and invest it elsewhere. They are real good Aussie made stuff.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view we have reached the point in Australia where we ought to be reforming the tax system or taking a new approach to tax. I do not think that coming into this Parliament month after month with page after page of legislation to close off loopholes is the approach. I think we ought to be looking at a new approach which hands a lot more power of definition and a lot more power of determination to the Commissioner of Taxation. As a member of the Government, I am prepared to wear the responsibility. If the Tax Commissioner turns into a Hitler for the business society, I will wear the responsibility for that. But, by gee, I am not going to stand here and watch certain members of our community continue to sit with their microscopes finding loophole after loophole, working out ways to continually dud the tax system at the expense of the ordinary person and making zillions of dollars doing it.

I was explaining to one of my colleagues at dinner tonight that I had outlined to me last weekend the latest device for getting around bankruptcy and negative gearing. I was given the example of a $6m property investment consisting of three $2m lots tied together. One property is able to be declared bankrupt and immediately becomes a write-off against the whole system. Such activity is taking place out there. It is going on all the time and it is being funded by the ordinary taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not on.

—As the honourable member for Lilley says, it is just not on any longer. I support this legislation, but I do think the honourable member for Dawson was right when he called for a reform of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Although he was using the same words as I have used, I do not think he had quite the same intention. There needs to be a simplification of taxation legislation. We need an approach of putting it all on the table and looking at it before we allow it to be enforced in the community because it is just not working. If we need a wealth inquiry to outline the sorts of things that are going on, so be it. Given that, I am happy to let my contribution rest there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —`I now give this understanding-that for the term of our next Government the Medicare levy will not be increased'. I do not need to remind the House that these are the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his policy speech from the 1984 election. To any normal human being the presence of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill before us tonight would represent a broken promise-No. 31, or is it No. 41--
—One hundred and forty-one.
—Perhaps it is No. 141. But this is not the case with our beloved leader, Mr Forty-Nine Per Cent, whose popularity must have been listed on Wall Street judging by the way it is in free-fall.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us examine this Medicare levy. Let us see whether Australian Labor Party rhetoric matches the facts. What does the levy produce? The answer is about $2 billion of taxpayers' money. Whatever it may be called, the levy is an extra tax from this Hawke-Keating Government with its record taxation levels. The Medicare system is so inefficient and so cost ineffective that the levy, contrary to Labor's initial promises, does not even begin to match the pretence that it will pay for our health care system.

The reality is that in 1986-87 health care cost the Government $5.8 billion over and above the income from the Medicare levy and in 1987-88 it will cost a projected $6.2 billion over and above the income from that levy. Honourable members might think that this is a good reason for increasing the levy and other taxation on the people of Australia in order to pay for their health care. The problem is, of course, that under this Government this has already happened. None of us would begrudge paying extra for an improved health care system, but what have we got? We have an apology for a health care system. We have a Claytons system-the health care one has when one does not have health care.

The delivery of an effective health system is a primary and indeed a major responsibility of government. It is a major challenge to all three spheres of government-Federal, State and local. The very basics of our health system lie in good drains and sewers, clean water supplies, unpolluted air, sensible food and drug laws and sufficient green belts and forests to provide the primary lungs for our cities and towns. Those considerations should lie foremost in the creation by governments and community groups of a positive attitude in individuals towards the maintenance of good health. A health system must never see itself essentially as a wholly or even predominantly remedial or palliative system. Good health must be the norm to strive for and to maintain, and preventative medicine must be the starting point. This does not just mean good environments and immunisation programs; it means the education of everyone in the principles of sustained good health.

The Hawke Labor Government has been in office for 4 1/2 terrible years. During those years there have been Labor governments in four of the six States. Thus, both in its direct Commonwealth policies and in its specific grants and influence through the Commonwealth-State Health Ministers Council, the Hawke Government has had a full opportunity to shape an overall health policy throughout Australia according to its own concepts. It must take full responsibility for the result. It cannot blame anyone else. It has had more than ample time and resources to put its clear imprint on Australia's health programs. The result has been disastrous. Year by year, throughout the Government's whole term in office, both the quality and the quantity of health care have seriously declined. The Minister for Health in my own State of New South Wales tells us that the problems are the Commonwealth's and he disclaims responsibility for the pitiful state of our health care system. We have buck passing here of enormous dimensions.

Let us look at the situation. In 1982-83 the Federal contribution to State health costs was $1,449m. In 1986-87 the contribution totalled $2,770m, an increase of 91 per cent. Perhaps it is just that New South Wales misses out on the Commonwealth moneys. Let us look at New South Wales in particular. In 1982-83 the total outlay for New South Wales was $488m. In 1986-87 it was $1,069m, an increase of 119 per cent. It just so happens, by coincidence of course, that that was the period of the operation of Medicare. Under Medicare, these costs have gone up almost twice. I ask honourable members whether the quality of health care has gone up anything like the same amount. I see that Government members cannot keep a straight face; they are sniggering. The Labor Party does not even have the decency to pretend that it cares about health care quality. It cares only about ideology, socialising medicine, reducing it to its lowest common denominator--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. You would have observed, as I did, that no Government member was sniggering when it was suggested that we were sniggering.
—Order! There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for Lowe.

—The Labor Party cares only about ideology, socialising medicine, reducing it to its lowest common denominator, increasing government control and, of course, increasing the costs. Who cares about the quality of the service? Who cares about the poor? Who cares about the disadvantaged? Not this Labor Party. The poor and disadvantaged under this Labor Party should be grateful even to have any service, or at least that is what the Labor Party implies.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is it that this often pragmatic Government does not exercise its pragmatism in this regard? Why does it maintain its ideology at the expense of the sick? After all, its other policies have gone by the board. I seem to remember some sort of pragmatic policy about uranium mining. I give up; I do not know the answer.

Since Medicare costs have increased almost 100 per cent in terms of health contributions to the States, one would expect that the money would result in a better system, so much better that nobody would pay to be privately insured. Why should they pay for something they can get for free? But no, Australians are voting with their feet. They are marching straight into the private health insurance offices in every State. With the exception of Queensland, more than 50 per cent of the population in each State has taken out private insurance. Why is that if the Government's Medicare system is so good?

Let us go back to May, to those halcyon days before the Prime Minister realised the problems that we poor card subjects were facing. Honourable members will remember that it was months before we became individuals again and could breath the clean fresh air of freedom, rescued from the threat of the identity card. We were in big trouble then, of course. We had not found the Argentinean road; we were just an ordinary banana republic. Those were the days of the so-called mini-Budget. What happened is what happens every time this Government does anything-it took more from our pockets and it gave us less. Firstly, the rebate to privately insured in-patients was reduced from 85 to 75 per cent. Perhaps even more significantly, the maximum gap of $20, which the Government had promised it would retain, was removed.

Not satisfied with that, it also savagely attacked the services. Now, if one has a simple wart or pre-cancerous keratosis, one cannot get it removed by a plastic surgeon or even a general practitioner (GP) specialising in this. This procedure just qualifies as an ordinary GP consult. This may be okay if a person has a face as wrinkled as most of us, but what if a person happens to be an 18-year-old girl? According to the Government, she does not need the best of care, any old care will do and she does not need to worry about a few scars on her face.

It is bad enough if a person gets sick from nine to five, but heaven help him if he gets sick after hours, because this Government has removed the loading paid to doctors to work outside normal hours. I understand that bulk billing was causing a problem and that the system was being misused, but if the system is being misused one fixes the system. One does not create another problem and destroy health care for the needy people who happen to be inconsiderate enough to get sick after hours.

This Government has reduced health services to an embarrassingly low level. It has reduced rebates. For example, if a person has a few skin cancers removed, which is very common in this country, the Australian Medical Association (AMA) fee is $230. The Medicare rebate now, after the May changes, is $138. The gap is $92. Should a person happen to need something major like a coronary artery bypass graft, he had better have a friendly bank manager because he will face an enormous bill at the end of it. The doctor's fee alone, if he follows proposed AMA guidelines, will be $1,680, but the rebate will be only $952. The patient will have to find $728 for the doctor's fee alone. Should a person be lucky enough to find somewhere to get a hip replaced-and frankly, he has more chance of winning a lottery-he will have to find the gap between the proposed AMA fee and the rebate of $538. One must remember that hip replacements usually occur in the age group whose financial needs are greater, the poorer end of the population, the 60-plus group.

Should a woman have that terrible disease, pregnancy, she will get back $307 from a fee of $655, a gap of $348-less than half. And that is assuming that there are no complications. Should a person feel the need, as I am sure some Government members do, to have a frontal lobotomy, a type of brain surgery for the mentally disturbed, the rebate will be $390 of a fee of $880-a gap of $490. The rebate for a cataract removal, another disease of the elderly, is only $337 of a fee of $1,035-a gap of $998. The rebate is only 32.5 per cent of the proposed fee. Oh for those glorious days when the maximum gap was $20! Under this Government one cannot fully insure oneself to cover the costs of being sick. It is unacceptable to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). Never mind the hardship.

What are these changes going to cost? They will save $116m each year, according to our Minister for Community Services and Health. Let me explain what those savings are. We are talking about $116m extra in taxation, paid not by the whole population-that would be bad enough-but by those who can least afford it, the sick. Sure, it is covered by health insurance, but who pays for the health insurance premiums? One pays more and gets less. There is no doubt that we pay more, but do we get less?

Let us look at the level of care offered. I have already pointed out that one dares not get sick after hours, but if one does get sick at least one can be assured of the very best care; or can one? Not under this Government which does not, for example, believe in the best care from the experts available, the medical consultants. One can visit them three times but then one is obliged either to visit a non-expert or to pay through the nose for an expert because of a reduction in the rebate. That is okay if one is rich but not if one is poor. It is another example of a two-tier system of health care.

What are the costs? After the third visit to a consultant, the schedule fee remains the same, that is, $43.50, but instead of getting a rebate of $37, one gets a rebate which can be as low as $18.75. Sure, one visit is not going to wipe out one's savings but if one needs regular care, if one is chronically sick, with each visit costing $24.75-that is assuming one just gets charged the Medicare fee-one will soon need to take out a loan to stay healthy. So, after three visits it is back to one's local GP.

Many GPs are superb physicians, well able to cope with most medical problems, but to deny expert care in many situations can certainly be life threatening. In my own specialty of cancer medicine, many of the drugs used would not have been heard of by many GPs, let alone the problems of using them. So what the Minister is really saying is that if one has a cancer which needs drug treatment one can get that from a doctor who does not even know the names of the drugs, let alone the first thing about the treatment.

There are many other similar examples of caring for the chronically sick. That is the problem. The Government, with its typical bully boy tactics, picks on the weaker members of our society. The ideal is a blend of specialist care and family GP care, but that is not possible with this Minister-unless one happens to be rich, of course. If one is poor one is likely to have to wait not only for elective surgery but also possibly for some life-threatening problems. For example, again using the instance of my specialty of cancer medicine, patients with cancer awaiting urgent chemotherapy are still at present having to wait to be admitted to hospital to receive that therapy with consequent risks to their chances of cure.

This is an area in which in New South Wales we have lies, damned lies and Mr Anderson's statistics. Mr Anderson claims that there are minimal waiting lists. At one stage he even claimed that there were no waiting lists. Clearly, there is distortion here to the nth degree. If one has a hip which needs replacing and one knows, for example, that Westmead Hospital in the west of Sydney replaces only three hips a year, quite clearly one does not put oneself on a waiting list for Westmead Hospital unless one has rocks in one's head. The statistics, of course, will not show any long waiting lists. Obviously one will enhance one's chances of having surgery if one is privately insured.

Despite this, and despite Mr Anderson's claims, it was today revealed that not only are there long waiting lists but also at one hospital, St George in Sydney, 13 people have died while on the waiting list for admission. The average waiting list for surgery alone at St George Hospital was 936 patients. Three hundred and forty-four patients have waited more than 12 months. Either Mr Anderson was incompetent or he lied. In either case he misled Parliament and should resign immediately.

With all these waiting lists we have a major problem. How can we resolve it? At this very moment there are over 9,000 private hospital beds which are unused. If they were utilised properly the problem could be solved at a single stroke. Why can this Government not put compassion above ideology and allow Medicare patients access to these beds? Why is Medicare so expensive? There are many reasons: the basic inefficiency of the system, the lack of any incentive to cut costs and prevent overservicing and the cost of the salaries for the increased number of staff required. For example, during the 12 months following the setting up of Medicare the number of staff employed by the Health Insurance Commission, not including temporary staff, rose from 1,863 to 4,346-2,483 extra staff. Just think what an impact 2,483 extra nurses would have had on our health system.

There is some fat in the system-fat which needs to be trimmed; fat which is encouraged by the bureaucracy of Medicare. For example, again in New South Wales, the number of administrators employed by the Department of Health and public hospitals in 1987 is 8,676. Just for comparison, the number of full time doctors employed is only 3,471. The implication is that it takes 2 1/2 times more administrators than doctors to offer good health care. I do not know why we cannot put our money where it will help the sick and the needy. But no, this Government pushes ahead with its socialist ideology and ignores the sensible, worthwhile options.

The worst feature of all has been the Government's abject failure to maintain the principle of a universal scheme, applicable to all Australians, regardless of their financial position. It has effectively destroyed the principle of universality. It has created two classes of Australians: the first class, the people who are well-off financially, who have immediate open access to private hospitals and unlimited capacity to receive long term specialist care; and the second class, all those on pensions, fixed incomes and low wages who cannot readily afford private health insurance and cannot afford the extra financial burden of continuous specialist care, a burden recently inflicted on them by restrictive government policies. These are the second class citizens and they are compelled to wait in queues for elective surgery at public hospitals for two years or more.

In a civilised community and particularly in an advanced industrial democracy, the health of individuals should never be forced to depend on the size of the pocket or purse. While no health scheme can ever be open ended, it is vital that the basics of health care and delivery should be available to everyone equally and without significant delays. Labor's failure is psychologically as well as physically damaging; it fails to maintain and respect the dignity of the individual. When at its best, the practice of medicine is both a science and an art. Practised solely and predominantly in a clinical scientific approach, it can be dehumanised, soulless and very limited in its horizons.

Good health and medication cannot simply come from the pill and scalpel. The human factor remains imperative. The ill person needs to be assured that he or she will be treated with respect and understanding and that the standard of delivery of medicine is high. Reassurance, the preservation of dignity and confidentiality, the uplifting of self-esteem and genuine interest in the individual and family groups-these are often much more important than just the prescriptions. But it is not sufficient for the doctor-patient relationship to be well developed. The intervention of government within that relationship has given rise to new problems, attitudes and stresses. It is a tragedy within the community, and a failure of government, for the aged and the infirm to come to determine by hard experience that they are regarded as second class citizens entitled to second class health services. We cannot leave our poor and underprivileged without good health care any longer. It is more than an optional extra; it is their right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just heard quite a strange contribution to this debate. The honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods) undoubtedly is a surgeon of high public standing. I was quite surprised not only at some of the expressions he used but also at the way he presented the general case. It was quite a savage onslaught against Medicare, a national and universal health system following the introduction of a similar scheme in the early 1970s, again on that occasion by a Labor government. That system was universally applauded. People knew that without a universal health scheme of that kind there would continue to be many people who, for any number of reasons, would find it difficult or impossible to get any type of health care, and not the first class health care, for example, to which the honourable member for Lowe referred.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1975, in the light of an election which was coming about, a very firm undertaking was given by the Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia on that occasion, who subsequently became the Australian Prime Minister, that Medibank would be maintained. After a few major surgical operations on Medibank, it ceased to exist. It ceased to exist until the end of the period of government of the conservative coalition. I remind everyone that as a result, in March 1983, when the Australian people decided that after seven disastrous years of the Fraser-Howard Government they would change the Government, there were almost three million people-almost one person in every five-not covered by any type of medical insurance at all. It has been suggested that there were some people who chose not to be covered by health insurance for reasons other than the fact that they were too poor to afford it. But the reality is that the vast majority of those people were not covered because they were unable to afford it.

I suppose there are plenty of examples throughout Australia where growing children continue to carry the scars and the disabilities associated with ailments that they had at that time which their parents, because they were poor, were unable to do anything about. One example-I will not go into the details-is a child in my electorate who will carry a disability for the rest of his life as a result of the fact that at that time his parents were unable to afford health insurance and were too proud to do anything about it. Then we have the statements that have just been made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lowe. He referred to the fact that people are increasingly taking out private health insurance. He said that they are voting on this question with their feet. I am surprised that a person from the medical profession would not be sufficiently honest at least to acknowledge the fact that one of the main reasons why people increasingly are going into private health insurance is the intimidatory attitude adopted by doctors. They tell people that if they are covered by private insurance and if they will go into a private hospital, the doctors can operate almost immediately, but if they are going to wait to go into a public hospital, it will not be possible for the doctors to carry out the operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the doctors' fault.
—The honourable member cannot interject from back there, by the way. He should learn the Standing Orders. He has to occupy his seat. Even if he is sitting in his seat, he is not allowed to interject.
—Come on; you are not in school now.
—The honourable member needs to return there.
—I am waiting for your standard speech. Have you forgotten your standard speech now that you have moved your place?

—No. I will come on to my standard speech shortly. If I do, the honourable member might be wearing an embarrassed look as a result, because he knows some of the things that might be included in it. So he should not provoke me to go on to that standard speech to which he refers. I know the one he means. (Quorum formed) For about 10 years it was my privilege to know the former member for Lowe.
—What a great member he was.
—An outstanding member not only of the State Parliament but also of this Parliament. He is a man of great talent, great dedication, great commitment and great compassion.
—He will return.

—Indeed, he will return. The people in Lowe will vote not with their feet but with the pencil on the next occasion. I do not know whether very many people had the opportunity to hear that earlier contribution to which I have already made reference, but I know that Mr Shepherd, the new President of the Australian Medical Association, is on record as saying that he will crush and destroy Medicare. We know, of course, that he has many allies-people who misrepresent Medicare and, incidentally, people who have made the claim that those poor people out in the community for whom they have so much compassion can get out of the surgery if they cannot pay the bill.
—Greed before need.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Grey has said, it is greed before need: if they cannot pay the bill, they can get out of the surgery. Increasingly, of course, that is happening throughout Australia. Particular reference was made to the position of consultant physicians. I hope I am not oversimplifying this, but I think all honourable members know that in general there are three levels of medical care available to people in the community. First of all, we have the consultant physicians, then we have the specialist physicians and then we have the general practitioners. The purpose of being referred to a consultant physician is precisely for consultation and an expert opinion about the particular medical ailment that that patient happens to be suffering from. Having received that expert opinion, it was usual practice for those people either to be referred to the specialist physician or, if that is not necessary, to go back to the general practitioner.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened? In many cases-not all cases, because many of these people are talented and honourable people-increasingly, and these consultant physicians were adopting the role of a general practitioner with continuing visits by these patients. Alternatively, they were adopting the role of a specialist physician for services which would have brought in a schedule fee of about $15 if they had been provided by a general practitioner and which, if they were being provided by the specialist physician, would have brought in a schedule fee of about $24. As a result of the fact that they were classified as consultant physicians and continued to claim as consultant physicians, they were getting between $40 and $45 per visit. Then, when their patients were in hospital, many of these honourable men would visit them daily, despite the fact that it was not necessary. They would say, `Yes, Mrs Jones, and how are you? Let me look at your chart, Mrs Jones. I will take your pulse, Mrs Jones. I will look into your eyes, Mrs Jones'. That would be 45 bucks-and on to the next bed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not on weekends, though.

—No, not on weekends, because they were out on the golf course. An increasing number of these consultant physicians-as I said, not all of them; many of them are honourable men and women with great talent-were quite clearly ripping off the system. For these tasks of going along from one bed to another and saying, `Yes, Mrs Jones', and in the consulting room saying, `I have seen you now; make sure you come back next Tuesday, Mrs Jones--
—And bring your cheque book.

—Yes, they would ask them to bring their cheque book, if they had to pay. But I am talking about this coming out of Medicare. They would say, `Make sure you come back next week' to Mrs Smith, Mrs Jones, Mr Brown, Mrs Turner and all the other people. Of course, the cash registers kept on ticking over. Many of those doctors finished up with an annual income in excess of a quarter of a million dollars-some of them with incomes approaching half a million dollars. Those are the people who are supposed to have all the talent, all the concern and all the compassion. Are these the people who in the future will say to their poor patients, `I am terribly sorry, Mrs Brown. I know that you cannot afford my higher fee, but come back and I will give my service to you gratis.'? Like hell they will! Those doctors will not tell their patients to come back and they will get their services gratis. They will be saying, `Mrs Brown, if you cannot pay the fee, get out of the surgery'. Of course, that has been happening increasingly.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard the sort of nonsense that has just been spoken by the new member for Lowe. A lot of people are concerned about the implications of this. I will repeat one point in connection with Medicare. As I have said before, when we came into government in 1983 there were almost three million people in Australia who, as a result of the dismantling, the disintegration, the destruction and the fragmentation of Medibank by the Fraser Government, were not covered by any type of medical insurance. Without going into the details, I referred to the fact that there is a young growing lad in my electorate, and probably others elsewhere right across Australia, who will carry with him for the rest of his life injuries and ailments because his parents were not covered by health insurance, nor did they have the money to go along and pay for those services. Many such parents had too much pride to seek charity. We have changed that. On three occasions the Australian people have endorsed what we have done. Increasingly, the Australian people are starting to identify those people who have been responsible for the attacks on Medicare. The Australian people are not as foolish as those on the Opposition benches seem to think. At one time it may have been possible for Opposition members to frighten the public, mislead them and misrepresent situations in Australia. But that will become less and less the case.

A number of amendments in the package of Bills before us relate to taxation provisions. The honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), who made a great contribution to this debate earlier, referred to a person earning a very high income. He was not sure whether the details were correct, but he referred to a well-known person in Australia who earned a very high income and who paid about $950 in income tax on the very high income that he had earned.

TALK.START.PARA: —He probably got Austudy too.
—Yes, he probably got Austudy for his children because an income that qualified him to pay $950 in tax would probably have been low enough to entitle him to an Austudy allowance for his children.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to draw attention to the fact that that situation does not apply only to individuals. Let us take, for example, the Vestey company in the United Kingdom which, between 1940 and 1980, paid a total in tax of #26. In 40 years the Vestey company paid #26 tax. In that period, including 1940 to 1945, the Second World War, when the sons of workers in Britain were making the supreme sacrifice in the defence of Britain, companies such as the Vestey company continued to operate and make their profit. That company's contribution during that period of 40 years was about #26.

Some of the reasons for this legislation are to put into operation measures announced in the statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in September 1985 concerning reform of the Australian taxation system. That statement was probably one of the most important ever made in this Parliament because it ripped out of the system once and for all a lot of the rorts, ramps and abuses that had been built into and institutionalised in it by our predecessors. It was necessary for us to tear them out. As a result of that statement and the policies put into place by it, we have done precisely that. Not only, for example, have we been able to ensure that the contribution people make to taxation from their income will be related to their income and will be appropriate as a proportion of their income; we have also found it possible as a result of the changes that have been introduced to haul back the marginal rates of taxation.

Those people on the Opposition benches who claim to belong to low tax parties with low tax policies are the ones who maintained the highest tax rate of 60c in the dollar, and we have been able to reduce the top rate to 49c in the dollar. So now, whenever a person earns an additional dollar of income, irrespective of that person's level of income, he or she will keep at least 50c out of that extra dollar. We no longer have the situation that existed before, when the Liberal and National parties would rip off 60c in the dollar from those people, leaving them with 40c in the dollar. There is no question about which party and which government has been responsible for the most significant and far-reaching adjustments in the Australian taxation system to ensure that the system would operate with equity, that people would make a fair contribution and, at the same time, would not be able to misuse, abuse and manipulate the system-to create blatantly artificial systems to get around it-and that the system would treat everyone fairly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) with the same speech he has made over the 4 1/2 years since the Australian Labor Party came to office. Government members choose to use emotive terms because it enables them to apply collective thinking without regard to individual taxpayers. It seems to me to be a crime against the intelligence of Australian people that, in these general terms and by the use of words such as `ramps', `rip-offs' and `rorts', they capture the imagination of at least enough people to enable them to be re-elected, albeit with a lesser primary vote than the combined coalition parties at the last election. Nevertheless, the result is that they are in government. They choose not to address the conditions and provisions in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3), the Income Tax Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill before us tonight but to generalise in a collective way, and as I said earlier, so that they may avoid the particular issues in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address my remarks tonight almost exclusively to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). It involves in particular changes to sections 46a, 46b, 46e, 108 and 109 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. In my introductory remarks I think it is worth referring to what is involved in the proposed new section 46a. That particular section was originally introduced in 1972. Let met remind the House that when honourable members opposite refer to what has happened over the last 30 years they choose to ignore the three or so years of the Whitlam Government in which they allowed to prevail the things they accuse us of being guilty of. They were unable to change effectively economic management, taxation law and all those things they now accuse the coalition parties of. Perhaps that is why that Government was thrown out of office, but it was only one of the reasons. Section 46a has been amended many times since 1972. There will be three changes which will have some application in the year commencing 1 July 1987 as a result of these Bills before the House tonight. Section 46a comprised 10 pages; now it will be 12 pages of very complex law. That is not unusual these days and, unfortunately, it has implications for professionals in the field, both accountants and lawyers.

Section 46a is directed at the stripper who receives the dividend as a consequence of the stripping operation. Part IVa is directed at the person disposing of shares in the company to be stripped, while section 52a is directed at denying deductibility for artificial losses created via dividend strips. While there are many variations, a basic dividend strip comprises, firstly, the purchase of a company which has accumulated profits; secondly, the stripping of accumulated profits via a dividend; and, finally, the sale of a company at a loss, which is tax deductible. As such there are at least three stages in the transaction at which anti-avoidance legislation might be aimed. We in the Opposition have no argument at all against measures designed to forestall contrived tax avoidance schemes.

Of some interest to the House is the proposed insertion of a new sub-section 46a (12) (a) which is similar to sub-section 46a (12), but which is expressed in terms of assets acquired after 19 September 1985. Effectively, it permits the Commissioner of Taxation to reduce the amount of dividend available for rebate by the cost base of shares disposed of as well as costs associated with the strip. The drafting is reasonably complex because of the need to cope with shares purchased and sold within 12 months as well as shares subject to capital gains provisions. It should be noted that the overall effect of this will frequently be to tax income currently at the expense of capital losses which will be deductible only against capital gains, that is, a tax flow timing problem will almost certainly ensue, not necessarily in the large company situation but in those effective small companies. That effect is due to the interaction of section 26aaa and the capital gains tax laws.

Proposed section 46e is probably of more immediate importance and interest to me. Needless to say, it is drafted in cumbersome terms, and that is a very kind description indeed. It should be observed too that the term `asset' is not the same as that defined generally for `capital gains' in section 160a. So regardless of the debate as to whether cash is an asset for capital gains purposes, it is clearly an asset for the purposes of this proposed new section 46e.

The state of affairs with the stock market in Australia makes some reference to section 26aaa important, particularly in terms of the proposed amendments to sections 108 and 109 which involve conferring on the Commissioner of Taxation greater discretionary power. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who is in the chamber, knows very well that I have had a concern with this matter for many years now, both in government and in opposition. As a result of the granting of another discretionary power, it seems relevant to mention that already, in terms of share trading--
