DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987MEDICARE LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ROCHER

TALK.START.PARA: —I was about to make the point that already the Australian Taxation Office is signalling its intention to profitise gains made by individuals trading in shares for the first time or people who are not classified as share traders, and to capitalise, perhaps I should say socialise, share traders' losses. Whereas in the past only net gains-that is, the total of profitable transactions over a 12-month period derived after the deduction of total loss transactions-were taxable under section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act, it is now more than suggested that only the gains of a profitable transaction will be taxed as income.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Cadman-It is disgraceful.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ROCHER

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disgraceful because losses that previously it was possible to offset can be claimed against capital gains only in subsequent years. It should be obvious to all that traders in any item or commodity can expect losses in some individual transactions, while chasing an overall and eventual profit. After all, that is the nature of business. The chances of new and casual share traders having assets purchased since September 1985 subject to capital gains tax, to offset against those share trading loss transactions, are very remote indeed. Let me illustrate this by giving a simple, but hypothetical example. For instance a trader who made $20,000 from profitable share deals and a $30,000 loss in identical circumstances will be up for $6,000 income tax. His trading loss, although totalling some $10,000, is increased by $6,000 income tax. He or she will still be up for provisional tax the following year unless the Commissioner of Taxation can be satisfied otherwise.

INTERJECT.PARA: So much for the claim of tax fairness in the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-a claim parroted by honourable members opposite time and time again, including the last speaker, the honourable member for Charlton. Somewhere down the track the benefit of any carried forward loss is, of course, diminished as well by the effects of inflation. Even that applies only if the person concerned has a capital gain against which a share trading loss or losses could be offset.

Given the wording of capital gains tax law as it now stands, some measures of fairness in this context would be restored if section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act were repealed, with immediate effect. The profits, or the so-called profits, intended to be taxed are ad- equately snared by capital gains tax provisions. Such a move would forestall the threatened, but nevertheless assumed, discretion residing with the Commissioner which he signals he wants to exercise in a vexatious and, in my opinion, inequitable way. In the meantime, individuals having a flutter in the share market should beware. Those people who have suffered losses in the last week will find that when they come to file their returns or, if not then, when they come to be assessed on their tax returns for the year ending 30 June 1988, they will be in dire trouble because on top of the imposition I have mentioned could well be provisional tax and, maybe, even as a result of ignorance, some penalties.
Mr Braithwaite-A shocking situation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ROCHER

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, indeed. I do not think that it can be overestimated. It is an example of where members of the Australian Labor Party, in their collective attitude to tax legislation, ignore the effects of law on individuals. They ignore equity or they claim, in the most righteous manner, overall benefit to taxpayers in the country.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Braithwaite-They do not think of the person at all.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ROCHER

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not think of individuals, and that is the point I want to stress. Proposed new section 46e is of special concern in the form it takes in the Bill before us. Broadly, it seeks to deny the inter-corporate dividend rebate to a company when these criteria are met: first, a dividend is paid to a corporate shareholder after 4 June 1987; secondly, the dividend is paid out of an asset revaluation; thirdly, before, at or after the time of revaluation, any person disposes of a share in a company which is `related' to the asset holding company; fourthly, at the time this last-mentioned person disposes of the share, the value of the revalued asset constituted 75 per cent or more of the net worth of the asset holding company; and, fifthly and finally, a company-whether or not the recipient of a dividend-has obtained a capital tax benefit out of the arrangement to revalue the asset and pay the dividend. A capital tax benefit is essentially a situation where, had it not been for the arrangement which these measures seek to attack, a company would have included an amount in its assessable income due to section 26aaa, involving sales within 12 months of purchase, or Part IIIa, the capital gains tax provisions.

INTERJECT.PARA: We have had occasion previously to complain about the ever-increasing practice of legislating by Press release, but in the example before us it is being raised to new and totally unacceptable heights. Whatever the merits-I repeat; whatever the merits-of proposed new section 45e as it is now finally proposed, people have ordered their affairs on the basis of the clearest possible statement of Government intent, a draft Bill for an Act of law. The second version now before the House-remember the first was tabled on 4 June this year-was first available for public scrutiny when introduced in this House on 23 September. Some 16 weeks elapsed before those prepared to order their affairs in a way which complied with the Government's proposed legislation over the period of 5 June to 22 September discovered that they could be in conflict with the provisions of proposed new section 46e of this Bill. Fairness, equity and natural justice demand that proposed new section 46e be effective only from 23 September of this year.
Mr Webster-They won't get it from the Government.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ROCHER

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not get it from the Government. That is an example of the collectivist thinking that I have sought to describe already tonight. The changes to the Bill released on 4 June are substantive; they are not simply stylistic or grammatical amendments. It is intrusive to observe some examples of the changes to the earlier Bill in the 23 September model now before the House. The earlier Bill applied only if the shareholder who received the dividend then proceeded to sell his or its shares in the asset holding company. The current Bill applies if the shareholder receiving the dividend or any other person or entity then proceeds to sell his or its shares in the asset holding company or a company `related' to the asset holding company. Another fundamental change to illustrate my point can be found in the fact that the earlier Bill applied only to the disposal of shares after the revaluation of the asset. The Bill under consideration tonight applies to a disposal of shares that occurs before the revaluation of an asset. If that is not a fundamental change, I do not know what is.

INTERJECT.PARA: Apart from these specifics, it needs to be said that the proposed new section has been dramatically widened by the second and therefore the relevant Bill. Regrettably, the only substantial portion of the proposed new section that remains unchanged is the date from which the proposed new section has effect, and that is 4 June 1987. That is both retroactive and retrospective in its application.

A further, but no less important, criticism I have of the proposed new section in its present form is that it provides for a blanket approach to the denial of inter-corporate dividend rebates. Under proposed new section 46E, if one of a multiple number of shareholders subsequently sells his or its shares after an asset revaluation dividend has been paid, all the shareholders will be denied the rebate. Accordingly, and without doubt, an injustice is done to those shareholders who will not be selling their shares. They will suffer penalties even though they have not made a sale or have not had the cash benefits from the proceeds of a sale. That is scurrilous legislation. It is taxing people on proceeds that they simply have not realised.

I cannot stress too much the inequity which arises. People acted quite properly in respect of the 4 June legislation, which, I emphasise, was in Bill form. It was not just the subject of a Press release, although Press releases had preceded it. People acted on the intentions of this Government which has been re-elected. Basic and fundamental changes are involved and I am sure that the observers and advisers to the Minister who are sitting in the officials area know exactly what I am talking about because this could not have escaped their attention. I hope they drew it to the attention of the Government, but I suspect that they did not. This might be an unduly cynical approach, but it seems to me that successive governments have been confronted with legislation by representatives of Treasury or the Australian Taxation Office which they have not understood. Certainly, many of our Ministers, both on my side and on the other side of the House, have not understood the implications of proposals that have been put before them.
Mr Cadman-Keating is too busy preening himself.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ROCHER

TALK.START.PARA: —He is busy preening and he has a lot of overseas duties to perform. Unfortunately, this means that he, like some Ministers who preceded him, does not look at the implications of legislation which is presented to him or, if he does-and I have been generous in giving him and the present Government the benefit of the doubt-he chooses to ignore them. If Ministers have chosen to ignore the implications, they deserve to be condemned for their approach and for their lack of any sense of justice in taxation matters.

INTERJECT.PARA: I might add that the same sort of injustice may be inflicted on some holding companies where the cost of denying the rebate might be borne by people who are not part of any real or perceived abuse. So these people are being roped in because of either a lazy or an uncaring Government inspired by its own message and the assumption that it has created that everyone is perceived to be a tax cheat before the fact. Everyone is being regarded in this way. Indeed, these days, such an assumption applies to pay as you earn taxpayers. In the very near future I would like to have an opportunity to give some very real examples of that. I know that the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent)--
Mr Hollis-A good member.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good member-a good libertarian, if not a good liberal. I know that he would understand what I am talking about.

That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, you have no doubt heard that the Government is considering commissioning a wealth study. I personally do not believe that we should undertake such a narrow politically and socially negative study. Instead, I believe that the Government should heed the advice of the Institute of Family Studies and provide it with the resources necessary to undertake a survey of family well-being. I understand that the proposal for a wealth study was costed over three years ago at between $4m and $6m. Compare such an outlay with the $320,000 research budget of the Institute of Family Studies and one will be forced to question the Government's sudden desire to study the poverty which is so extensive in Australia today. If the Government was sincere about providing research and a database to underpin economic and social policy, it could have increased rather than cut the budget of the Institute of Family Studies in this year's Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: In the United States at the moment a study of the family in all its configurations is being undertaken by the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development. Our own Institute of Family Studies proposes that we undertake a similar study. The problem as the Institute sees it is that none of the surveys it has been able to undertake, with its limited budget, combines in one data set for the same families, information on all aspects of family well-being, standards of living and quality of life. Thus it and the Government cannot tell what combination of factors explains why families are un- stable, not functioning properly or coping with life. It and the Government need information that integrates the three main elements of family well-being-material resources, social supports and personal and social psychological well-being-in one data set, so that comparisons and correlations can be made to test the likely impacts of diverse policies and programs on the family.

Over six months ago, before the Government discovered the political value of anti-poverty rhetoric, and before the media discovered the problem of family credit and debt management, Canon Allan Whitham of the Anglican Church's Home Mission Society called on us to give attention to poverty in Australia. He reminded us that 2 1/2 million of our fellow Australians every day have to choose between clothing, food, rent and the light bill, as they cannot afford them all. He first related the significance of marital break-up to the abuse of personal credit, bankruptcy and economic problems in creating poverty. We should realise that what has pushed so many Australian children into poverty is not Mr Alan Bond's lifestyle but that of their own parents. If that is realised, one will realise why a public exploration of the bank accounts of our wealthy citizens will not necessarily help us fight the long term causes of poverty and disadvantage.

Canon Whitham did acknowledge wealth disparities. He also, however, referred us to the awful truth that it is average persons in our country who are greedy and avaricious, who had, he said-and I quote:
. . . become liars and thieves prepared to take an illegitimate sickie without even considering that to do so would put their finger in everyone else's pockets.

Most significantly, he argued the very important point that our national problems are not primarily economic, but spiritual. A wealth study will not address the question of family credit management. It will not address the impact of family law on the number of women and children in poverty. It will not address the value of questions which underlie the national statistics of poverty, neglect of the aged, productivity, and so on. It will not help us understand why different families use their assets so differently. More importantly, it will not help Australians to understand the nature of our common problems and common obligations in dealing with wealth creation, social policy and support for families and individuals who face hardship. It will, instead, encourage division and resentment.

The proposal for a broad and multidisciplinary survey of the well-being of the family and the interaction of various policies on the family will go a lot closer in meeting those goals. It will also be much more likely to gain bipartisan support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual reports for 1986-87 of the Australian Archives and the Advisory Council on Australian Archives were tabled in the House on 8 October. As honourable members will know, I hope, I am a member of the Advisory Council. Recent debates in this House have centred on privacy. I wish to draw the attention of honourable members to the work which the Archives has been doing in the field of information privacy. For 15 years the Archives has been dealing with privacy considerations as they apply to the release of information from Commonwealth government records, more recently under the terms of the Archives Act. Over this period the Archives has built up considerable expertise in this field. This year the Archives has undertaken a thorough examination of the issues involved in protecting the personal affairs of individuals who have had dealings with government. The results are embodied in a substantial paper which has been seen by the Advisory Council on Australian Archives. The Council thought that the paper provided a most useful and professional contribution in this difficult area. I hope to see the paper published before too long.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the Archives has issued new guidelines as they relate to privacy and access to records. These guidelines deal with questions of access when Commonwealth records contain material on such matters as suicide, adoption, immigration, fingerprint records and transcripts of intercepted telephone conversations. The guidelines are publicly available from the Archives access manual.

The Archives' last two annual reports have referred to progress in planning and constructing a joint Commonwealth-State records repository in Adelaide. The 1986-87 report indicates that this unique project has now been completed. The facility was officially opened in July of this year by the former Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen), together with his State counterpart, the Hon. Barbara Wiese, the South Australian Minister of Local Government.

This is a good example of an enterprising approach to solving a problem. By sharing costs and providing certain facilities, servicing arrangements and equipment in common many thousands of dollars have been saved by both governments. The result has been the timely provision of a facility offering services on which both Commonwealth and State departments in South Australia will greatly depend in the efficient conduct of their day by day business. This kind of co-operative endeavour among government records organisations is something which the Australian Archives seeks to encourage wherever possible. I believe the Australian Archives is to be especially commended for its part in seeing this joint project through to completion.

In recent years, the Archives has put a lot of effort into helping agencies make efficiency gains in dealing with their records. Taking this a step further, the Archives has prepared and just recently issued a handbook for agencies on how to play a larger and more informed role in the process of deciding which records should be kept and which can be safely destroyed. The approach taken is a self-help one which will make agencies more self-reliant in this important field. Pages 4 and 5 of the Archives' annual report show the lively and informative presentation style adopted. The line of development being taken is in harmony with the Government's philosophy of encouraging devolution within government administration where this can be safely achieved.

In conclusion, a word about the need for a high profile public outlet and national headquarters for the Australian Archives in Canberra. Since its inception, the Advisory Council has identified the provision of such a building, proposed by this and previous governments to be located in the parliamentary zone, as a matter of high priority. The provision of such a building is regarded by the Council as crucial to the effective discharge of the responsibilities of the Australian Archives. Such a building is not proposed merely as a monument to the past. The Australian Archives exists to cater for current and future needs in providing a focus for access to government information and records, and it should be able to provide education and extension services on the workings of executive government, in particular, for the community. The concept as developed by the Archives is an exciting one. Provision of this important facility has been delayed for one reason or another for some years. With the completion of the new Parliament House the demand on resources in Canberra will be greatly eased. When that happens, I believe the Government should take a firm decision, and proceed with it, to provide the facility for which the Advisory Council sees such a pressing need. Finally, I would like to compliment in particular Mr Brian Cox, the Director-General, and his very capable staff at the Australian Archives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to spend some time tonight talking about unemployment. Often members of the Government talk about equity, fairness and justice and about their concern for people, but in reality over the last three or four years this Government has shown total incompetence in its handling of unemployment in this nation. We sit here day after day and hear the Treasurer (Mr Keating) go on about the record of the Fraser Government. The simple fact is that the Fraser-Howard Government's record on unemployment is 38 per cent better than the record of the present Government. Australia's unemployment record during the Hawke years has been absolutely disgraceful, and that is one of the reasons why there is a great need to look into poverty in this nation. This Government has kept more people in unemployment than any other government in the history of this nation since the Second World War. That is its record on unemployment. I was pleased to sit here and listen to the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) talk about poverty in this nation. One of the fundamental reasons why we have poverty is the policies of the Hawke Government: it has kept people unemployed, and the time for which people have been unemployed is almost double the time for which they were unemployed at the end of the Fraser years. What is more, the Hawke Government has set in place economic policies that are disastrous for this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to turn now to something that is of particular interest to me as the shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In 1977 we set the community development employment project scheme among Aboriginal communities. This is a scheme whereby Aboriginal communities can choose to have people work for their unemployment benefit. It is a lead to the rest of Australia. Some Aboriginal communities had got to such a low ebb in handling their social situations, whether it be through alcoholism, petrol sniffing or other socially degrading situations, that the elders finally said, `Enough is enough and we have to do something about it'. One of the reasons for this, which they traced back to the social dislocation in their communities, was the fact that so many people had time on their hands and excess money. They felt that there was a need for them to do something productive and worth while. The elders took charge of their communities in a very positive way and said to the Government, `Let us pool our unemployment benefits, the people in our community will work and we will then distribute that money'. There are over 50 of those communities in Australia, setting a lead for the rest of the Australian community.

I suggest to this Government that it might like to do exactly the same thing in other parts of Australia, that is, to allow municipal councils around Australia to handle the equivalent unemployment benefits which go into their communities to produce productive outcomes. I challenge the Government to take up that initiative and to take the example which the Aboriginal elders in many communities in Australia have given, and allow municipal councils to handle unemployment benefits and have people work for those benefits. It is a challenge which this country should take up, because it would be far better off if the Government were prepared to bite the bullet on this issue and have people work for their government benefits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1981, I was a member of a parliamentary delegation to Pakistan and India. On my way to join the delegation, I paid a short visit to Singapore. While there, I visited Parliament House. In the lobby of that building I noticed a portrait of Lee Kuan Yew-depicted by the artist as Leader of the Opposition while making a speech and thumping the table with his fist. I have thought it rather curious that, since Lee Kuan Yew has become the Prime Minister of Singapore, no other member of parliament has had the opportunity to voice his or her dissatisfaction with the Government as freely or vehemently as he did. In fact, shortly there will be no members of the Opposition, since their number has now been reduced to one, casting doubts on the existence of a parliamentary democracy in Singapore. Not only has the parliamentary Opposition been oppressed, but anyone in Singapore today who is even mildly critical of the Government places himself or herself in a position of being locked up and detained indefinitely without charge and without trial. And this is exactly what happened to 22 decent and peace loving young people, most of whom are church and community workers, for their differences of opinion with the dictator.

SPEECH.PARA: On 21 May and 20 June Vincent Cheng, Executive Secretary of the Catholic Justice and Peace Commission, and 21 others were apprehended and detained under the Internal Security Act. They were imprisoned without trial because they were judged by the authorities as a security threat. Although the 22 church and community workers arrested were accused of involvement in a Marxist plot to overthrow the Government of Singapore, organisations such as Amnesty International have confirmed the view prevalent in the international community, namely, that these people have been imprisoned solely for non-violently exercising their right to freedom of expression and freedom of association, rights which we in Australia and those living in democratic societies everywhere take for granted.

While held in detention these young people were not given the opportunity to respond to the accusations made against them. Moreover, whilst in prison they were subjected to prolonged periods of solitary confinement, continuous interrogation under severe psychological pressure by professional teams of interrogators and physical torture. Amnesty International has confirmed that the so-called `confession' made by Vincent Cheng, and broadcast on Singapore television, must also be seen as a result of these interrogation procedures.

Six of those originally arrested are still in prison; the remainder have been released. However, their release is conditional. They have been placed on a restriction order, which means that their freedom of movement and freedom of association is restricted and that internal security agents continually monitor their movements and can interrogate them at any time. Their human rights are being violated. It is now time for the international community to insist that both the Internal Security Act, which allows detention without charge or trial, the restriction order and conditions attached to it and other human rights violations perpetrated by the Government of Singapore cease immediately. Consequently, I call upon the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) to intervene on behalf of those still detained and those whose movements are restricted because of the legitimate non-violent activities in church and community areas, workers organisations and student groups.

It is just not good enough for the Government of Australia or any other concerned government merely to state a concern for human rights violations. Rather, we should express our concern in more concrete ways. We have already demonstrated our strength of opposition to the oppression in South Africa. I propose similar measures to be employed forcefully to put our case to governments which repeatedly violate internationally accepted codes of justice, rights and democracy, especially against such dictatorial regimes in our region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am prompted to rise in the adjournment debate tonight following remarks made in this House by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) on 23 September 1987. I raised the honourable member's comments with him prior to choosing to air them in the House tonight. While I am very aware, as is every honourable member opposite, of the fact that being a shade uncharitable towards members of the Opposition would not be a new experience for the honourable member for Dunkley, I am sure that he did not mean to misrepresent the state of Australia's rural producers when he addressed the House on 23 September. Following remarks by the honourable member for Page (Mr Ian Robinson) about farmers, the honourable member for Dunkley stated:

SPEECH.PARA: They have come from a state of just about absolute poverty under the last Howard Treasury and have been lifted up from those dire straits through the excellent work of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin).

TALK.START.PARA: —Very observant.
—One may think so, but he then went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Farmers are now getting a fair return for the amount of effort they have put into their farms.

I would have thought very few, if any, honourable members opposite-this applies particularly to the new member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice)-would be anxious to run around their rural electorates claiming that farmers are now getting a fair deal for the amount of effort they are putting into their farms. Not only was the honourable member for Dunkley ill-informed and therefore offering a less than fair assessment of the position of rural producers on 24 September, but 10 days later the South Australian paper the Advertiser ran a lead article which referred to the State Secretary of the United Farmers and Stockbrokers of South Australia Inc., a Mr Grant Andrews. I hasten to add, lest it should it be claimed that I have a vested interest in this matter, that he is no relation of mine. Honourable members will notice that his name is Andrews. Mr Andrews said that, unless it rains, this will be a disastrous year for South Australian farmers. In fact, he said that on the Eyre Peninsula, Mr Davis Lewis, the district agronomist, had been quoted as claiming that `the situation is already a disaster'. Many farmers are expecting a harvest yield of only 30 per cent to 50 per cent of the average return. Rain was desperately needed and in an atmosphere as dry as that, as every rural producer in this place would know, the State was ripe for a frost and a frost occurred. Following the speech of the honourable member for Dunkley on 23 September and Mr Andrews's plea on the night of 4 October, on 16 October the Advertiser ran another article about what was, in fact, a major frost throughout the south-eastern part of South Australia taking out 11,000 tonnes of prime wine grape production and seriously affecting the cereal crops throughout the south-east.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not blaming us for that, are you?

—Of course I am not blaming that on the Government, but I am pointing out how ill-advised were the remarks by the honourable member for Dunkley on 23 September. As if that were not enough, this frost was followed by what were expected to be drought breaking rains that were preceded by a massive hail storm. The Advertiser said on Saturday, 17 October, that the damage from the hail storm could reach $50m.

SPEECH.PARA: I am waiting for some semblance of apology from those honourable members opposite for what was a disastrously misleading speech in this House by the honourable member for Dunkley. Not only were grape crops affected by this hail storm which went through part of the Barossa Valley and the Riverland; cereal crops and pea crops in what is the State's key cereal producing area, the mid-north in the heart of the electorate of Wakefield, were absolutely devastated. Pea crops that would have been standing almost as high as the bench finished up little more than two inches off the ground. The Government will feel the results of this sort of rural damage. For example, Roseworthy Agricultural College which is partially funded by the Government had one of the original college ceilings collapse. Loxton Research Centre had major damage to glass- houses, all of which will need to be replaced from taxpayer's funds. But essentially I must point out that what the Government would have expected to pick up in tax revenue from farmers across South Australia, it will not now collect thanks to the drought, to the frosts that followed the drought and to the hail that preceded the drought breaking rains.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to bring to the attention of the House a speech made by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). The Deputy Leader accused the Government of being preoccupied with technology and manufacturing, claiming it was a serious fault in the Labor Government's attempts to lift Australia's exports. Do National Party members really believe that? Do they really want to run down Australia's manufacturing industry? By virtue of that, the National Party wants Australia to return to the 1950s, riding to prosperity on the sheep's back. They have even rejected the high tariff manufacturing years when John McEwen was a Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: This policy runs counter to everything we have being trying to achieve in Australia. This Government has floated the exchange rate. Through the prices and incomes accord, it has brought about a sensible wages policy. Through schemes such as the steel industry plan, the heavy engineering plan and the car industry plan, the Government has brought about a fundamental restructuring of Australian industry. This country is now in the most competitive position on world markets in living memory. Yet the National Party wants to deny all that. It wants to return to policies which abolished the manufacturing sector in our nation. In my State of Queensland, we have one of the lowest manufacturing bases in Australia. Queensland has had the lowest number of jobs in the manufacturing sector since 1982. It spends the least per capita in Australia in providing industrial infrastructure. The manufacturing portfolio is of low priority, being given to a junior Minister. Does the National Party really want the Queensland model to be the Australian model?

The Queensland economy needs diversifying. All its eggs are currently in one basket. In my own electorate we are working flat out trying to attract new manufacturing industry, particularly in Bundaberg and Gladstone. According to the new National Party policy, Gladstone can simply close down. By being anti-manufacturing, the National Party is really anti-Gladstone.

Recently, Bundaberg hosted the Northern Australian Development Conference. The topics for discussion listed the new technologies, yet the Deputy Leader of the National Party criticises `the futility of assisting high technology industries'. The National Party is quite clearly ignorant on economic matters. It should have a word to Austoft, a Bundaberg company that is competing on world markets and achieving success. The National Party should be condemned for advocating policies which simply ignore the great emphasis being placed on manufacturing by businessmen, not only in my electorate but also throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to lodge a complaint about the attitude of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I do not believe that the example he sets in this chamber in regard to his travelling allowance does us any credit. His example really proclaims that anything is acceptable if one is in a position to get away with it. I do not think that that is an encouragement to pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers.
—Order! I think that the honourable member should be a bit careful and bear in mind the fact that if one wishes to criticise another member, one should do so by substantive motion.

—I am looking at the principles rather than the personalities, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think that we all have a responsibility to set an example that will encourage a response from the Australian community. Taxation and the problems associated with it have exercised the minds of successive governments over the past few years and attitudes were prevalent in our society which seemed to indicate that if one could get away with a tax rip-off-a white collar crime-then that was fair game. Both sides of the House condemned those attitudes and took legislative action to deal with them. I believe that the Treasurer is encouraging those attitudes amongst PAYE taxpayers. The integrity that we would like to see those taxpayers exercise in fulfilling their tax obligations is discouraged rather than encouraged.

—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. If the honourable member wishes to get into this type of debate, there are Standing Orders which clearly indicate the way in which he should proceed. If he wishes to put anything of that nature on the record against another member, he must do so by substantive motion and not bring up his gutter-type politics at a very late hour in the House.
—Oh, come on! I am not adopting that approach. If the honourable member wants a boots and all debate, I can get into that.

—Order! Before the honourable member for McMillan entered the chamber I drew the attention of the honourable member for Mitchell to the fact that if he wishes to criticise another member he must do so by substantive motion. I am taking account of what the honourable member for Mitchell has to say and I trust that he will stick to generalities, not specifics.

—Certainly. On the other hand, if we look at the large corporations, we see the attitudes to which I have referred. We see that the thought has been abroad that if one can get away with it, that is fine. That fact has been taken into account and this chamber has acted upon it. The logic of the way in which the Treasurer expressed himself today defies explanation. If we all adopted those attitudes we would all buy a shack somewhere in Western Australia because we would gain greater benefit by claiming a travelling allowance from that State.

—I rise on a point of order. The honourable member is clearly reflecting on the Treasurer and I hope that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will order him to bring his remarks back to the debate to which he should be addressing himself instead of reflecting on the Treasurer. It is quite clear that he is reflecting on the Treasurer and at no stage today did the Treasurer encourage anybody to be a tax avoider. He did not encourage the sort of behaviour that the honourable member for Mitchell implies.
